campaign.story:
This Kickstarter seeks to fund two releases in celebration of the tenth anniversary of Folklore Tapes. The first is an audiophile-grade reissue of one of the label's most sought after editions, Theo Brown and the Folklore of Dartmoor. The second is a new Ten Year Anniversary Book featuring essays and hitherto unseen photography from the collective's many fieldtrips, recording sessions and live performances.
Folklore Tapes began in 2011 as a postal exchange between David Chatton Barker and Ian Humberstone. Ian had recently left Devon, while David remained. Feeling that they had only begun to scratch the surface of their potential for creative collaboration, the pair began a correspondence centred around their mutual interest in Devon folklore. The compositions and research notes they traded would later become the first Folklore Tapes release Two Witches, in the summer of 2011.
David and Ian at Stanton Drew Stone Circle, 2015.
From there, the project grew roots, knots and branches - much like a gnarled old oak tree. The initial 'Devon Folklore Tapes' series was soon joined by others delving into the arcana of different counties, while themed sets, such as 'Calendar Customs' and 'Megalithic Monuments', also emerged from the misty wraithlands. Folklore Tapes soon developed into a fully-fledged collective, with a large cast of contributors - including such luminaries as Sam McLoughlin, Mary Stark, Rob St John, and Arianne Churchman - spread throughout the UK.
The Folklore Tapes Tent at Port Eliot Festival, 2015.
Perhaps the most well-received release to date has been Theo Brown and the Folklore of Dartmoor. This project saw Ian and David embark on fieldwork throughout Dartmoor, guided by the spirit of the late folklorist Theo Brown, whose manuscript collections - held at the University of Exeter - directed their endeavours. The project was released to widespread acclaim in 2014, as a box-set containing seven seven-inch records, a DVD, map, booklet, poster and postcards. The pressing sold out within six months and has remained a sought after collector's item ever since.
For many years, David and Ian pondered the best way to keep the release in print. Simply reissuing the box-set held little appeal. There was a sense that the mixes for the album - alongside the quality of its analogue-to-digital conversion - could be improved upon. As a result, for this new edition Ian went back to the original half-inch tapes and lovingly reworked the audio using analogue outboard equipment. New masters were then made by engineers Bill Sellar and Simon Heyworth at their studio located on Dartmoor itself. David, meanwhile, disinterred the project's 8mm film and artwork, and set about recapturing - though rewilding is perhaps the more appropriate term - their primal content in high definition.
Theo Brown Tour Rehearsals, 2014.
The new edition of Theo Brown and the Folklore of Dartmoor takes the form of a 45rpm double LP set in a gatefold sleeve, with the quality of the audio greatly improved. Also included is a detailed booklet containing all the artwork, research notes and folk-tales featured in the original release. Tucked inside the sleeve are two download codes for the project's audio and film.
The second release being funded through this campaign is the Ten Year Anniversary Book, which is filled with hitherto unseen images and text. Over the past decade, Folklore Tapes have amassed a vast archive of 35mm and slide film photography, detailing their activities on stage during live performances, and on-site during fieldtrips. This behind-the-scenes material will finally see the light of day through this publication, which will also include a full retrospective of David's album and poster art for Folklore Tapes, alongside a history of the label penned by Jez Winship.

campaign.story:
The Cocktail Journey is a guided experience that connects people who love cocktails with expert bartenders via livestreams and beautiful video tutorials. 
 Make Exceptional Cocktails with our expert bartenders every week
 Explore Your Cocktail Ambitions with our on-demand guides and lessons
 Share The Journey and learn with a lively cocktail community
"This is a great way for beginners to learn about cocktails and for more advanced cocktail enthusiasts to up their game. Sign up now, you won't regret it!"
                                     - Jamie, Founding Member at The Cocktail Journey 

Membership starts at just $5 / month!

Make 52 Cocktails in 52 Weeks
A sample of some of the cocktails we're exploring on The Cocktail Journey:
What Backers are Saying:
Don't take our word for it -- check out the Comments Section of this Kickstarter!
 I've learned more than I ever expected in the past 4 months - Kelsey
 I was a bartender.. and this is a fantastic program with expert advice and high production value - Clarke
 Rachel and Shawn are so down to earth and approachable, as are all of their guests. There's no pretentiousness, just a lot of lively discussion and learning! - Diann
 Thursday night cocktail sessions with The Cocktail Journey live streams have been the highlight of our work week - Christina
Why You'll Love The Cocktail Journey
With The Cocktail Journey and our Expert Bartenders as your guides, you'll:
 Make Exceptional Cocktails: Join us wherever you are on your journey, even if you’ve never touched a barspoon before. We go hands-on together, making 52 cocktails in 52 weeks, with live interactive guidance from our expert bartenders and community members.
   Explore Your Cocktail Ambitions: Where do you want to go next? You’ll find the right resources on The Cocktail Journey - on-demand video lessons, bottle guides, access to expert bartenders - everything it takes to elevate your cocktail game to the next level.
   Share the Journey: Cocktails are more fun with friends! Sharing your discoveries makes for memorable experiences for you and your friends -- and within the TCJ Community. Our members spice up the weekly livestreams not just with banter but also with insightful cocktail tips and variations of their own.
What You'll Get as a Member
The Foundational Experience (Foundations Level Membership @ $5/month)
Use the 15 Bottle Bar Guide to establish or build out your home bar so you can make 52 cocktails in 52 weeks with us. Join us as we explore each cocktail in-depth, live or at your convenience and at your own pace.
 Meet the Experts Live!  Each week we make the cocktail together on our livestream. Join us to ask questions, explore variations, and share your successes with the community. 
Reference a robust Cocktail Profile on the members-only website so you can find your favorite cocktails again and again, complete with livestream playback and show notes, cocktail history and pro tips, and on-demand tutorials and education.
Get a weekly email reminder with the cocktail recipe and preparation tips, so you can shop for supplies and prep for the livestream!
  The Growth Experience (Growth Level Membership @ $15/month)
Get the full Foundational Experience, PLUS, elevate your cocktail experience with:
 Beyond the 15-Bottle Bar: Explore additional spirits and liqueurs - whenever we introduce a new bottle, get access to new recipes and livestreams
An expanded library of on-demand education and masterclass style content. 
Engage with your fellow TCJ community members to share your experiences via members-only resources like community groups and channels and (eventually) in-person events and experiences.
Meet the Experts:
Learn More about these Experts, including exploring their bios and where to find them on Instagram at thecocktailjourney.com

Experience Our Livestreams Now!
Join us every Thursday @ 4:30 PM Pacific / 7:30 PM Eastern during this Kickstarter to experience our weekly live events!  Meet our expert bartenders and other TCJ Community members, and make these cocktails with us:
Thursday May 6th - The Margarita w/ Brian Prugalidad & Stephen Kurpinsky 
Thursday May 13th - The Clover Club w/ Veronica Correa
Thursday May 20th - The Gold Rush w/ Megan Balser
Thursday May 27th - The Hanky Panky w/ Stephen Kurpinsky
Preview: The Cocktail Journey Experience
Explore the core content components of The Cocktail Journey: 
Watch this video to learn more about our Livestream Events, the 15 Bottle Bar, Weekly Cocktail Recipes and On-Demand Education (4 min).
PLAY

Explore Education Road Map:
This video dives deeper into the four main areas of education we'll be publishing on the members-only website: bartending techniques, spirits education, cocktail craft, and the elevated home bar experience (3 min).
PLAY

Members-Only Website:
We're building out a members-only website that will be available by August 2021, where members can sign-in to access ALL members-only content, including past livestream recordings, in-depth cocktail profiles, and resources like the 15-Bottle Bar, printable shopping lists, recipe cards and cocktail menus, plus articles, tutorials, and on-demand video education. This is also where we'll launch new features like community channels and new live (and in-person) event experiences.

Membership & Rewards:
The Cocktail Journey is a membership-based experience, with two membership levels, plus a special Kickstarter-only offer for a Lifetime Membership (limited availability):
 Foundations Level Membership: $5/month or $50/year (post-launch rates will be $7/month or $70/year)
 Growth Level Membership: $15/month or $150/year (post-launch rates will be $18/month or $180/year)
 Kickstarter Special: Lifetime All-Access Membership: $400 (one-time purchase). Limited to 150 on Kickstarter (125 Backers + 25 Gift Memberships). Get access to all Foundations and Growth Level Content Forever. Plus special perks and insider info ;)
Gift Memberships
You can give The Cocktail Journey to the cocktail lovers in your life.
Once you become a Backer at any level you can choose to add-on annual or lifetime Gift Memberships; 25 of the total available 150 Lifetime Memberships are reserved for Gift Memberships. 
If you yourself aren't interested in membership (or are already a Founding Member), just back this project at the $1 "Tip Jar" Backer level, and add on gift membership on the next page. Cheers, and Thank You!

Who We Are
We're a passionate team of artists, cocktail nerds, and people who love building amazing community experiences. 
Shawn Michael and Megan setting up for one of our weekly livestreams!

Rachel Eva & Shawn Michael - We're a creative team with a big vision: to help people celebrate with higher fidelity experiences. We are also the founding team behind Standard Spoon, a line of obsessively designed barware launched right here on Kickstarter.  Rachel Eva is a storyteller and loves connecting with you, learning from our members, and crafting the best possible approach to education and experiences. Shawn Michael sets the standards for beautiful content and high quality experiences both on- and off- set. 
Stephen Kurpinsky - a cornerstone of the San Diego cocktail community, Stephen has spent 20 years bartending and managing bar programs, is the current chapter president of the San Diego USBG and National Brand Ambassador for Mr. Black Coffee Liqueur. He has some of the highest and most respectable standards for craft cocktails that we've ever encountered. 
Megan Burgess - a talented photographer (and baker of incredible cookies), Megan handles live event production and takes many of the gorgeous photos that make The Cocktail Journey look soooo good. She's a photo & video production whiz!
Zennia Aquino - a wrangler of creatives and content management guru, Zen keeps us all on track to deliver great content on schedule -- and does it all while being a super-mom to twins!
Chris Fessenden - a start-up mastermind with a passion for the arts and creative communities, Chris is helping us build out the strategy, marketing, and growth initiatives that are setting The Cocktail Journey up to be an incredible experience. 

Why We Need Your Help:
To build out the full Cocktail Journey Experience, we need 1,000 members to support this project. Our backers are critical partners in all of our new projects for two reasons:
1. We design our products (and experiences) in collaboration with our community. Your feedback as we build out The Cocktail Journey is crucial to delivering the kind of education and experience you need and want most. We like making things that people like to use. 😊
2. Building things is hard (and expensive). We’ve already invested a lot to bring The Cocktail Journey to this stage of development, and give you a good taste of what’s to come. In order to build on what we've started, we need the ongoing support of founding members so we can continue building a great team of people, produce more educational content, and improve the members-only experience.

What's Done & What's Next
We’ve already been putting the foundation for The Cocktail Journey in place. Here's our current road map:

What We'll Do With Kickstarter Funds
Like we said earlier: building things is hard, and EXPENSIVE. For this project, most of what we need to do is invest in the creative team that will produce the live events and educational content for The Cocktail Journey. We'll use Kickstarter funds for:
 People: we have an incredible team that is helping us to build education and amazing cocktail experiences for you -- and we need to be able to invest in those people. Most of our project funding will go to support our team so we can continue to build out the full Cocktail Journey Experience.
 Membership Site: we have a little more work to build out the members-only experience at thecocktailjourney.com, which will be the main hub for our community to access on-demand educational content, live events, members-only resources, and to connect with each other.
 Production Needs: the great news is, we already have a lot of the stuff we need when it comes to studio space and gear. We'll use a small portion of the funds upgrading a few things to improve the audio and visual experience and make production more efficient for the team.
 Funding & Stretch Goals
Our funding goal is $25,000. This is the baseline we need in order to launch The Cocktail Journey and explore 52 cocktails in 52 weeks with you! 
What we'd like to create down the road is much bigger than this, and there is a lot more that we can do.  We have a 5-year roadmap to build out some really incredible things ---  but today and for this Kickstarter, we're only talking about what we can deliver in the next year. And some of that depends on how many members we get and what kind of funding we have to work with:
At $25,000, we'll be able to fully implement our vision of weekly cocktail recipes and live events to explore 52 cocktails in 52 weeks with you! We'll also be able to build out the membership site and members-only resources, and begin producing introductory on-demand content.
At $50,000, we'll be able to produce more in-depth and regular content sooner, and begin to expand beyond the 15-Bottle Bar to address other kinds of cocktail education (Think: tiki cocktails, bitters workshops, new craft spirits and liqueurs). 
At $100,000+ we'll be able to invest in our team more fully and have enough resources to provide the visibility and financial runway to implement our 5-year plan (which is very exciting!!)
We'd really like to get closer to the $100k mark with The Cocktail Journey launch this month. If that doesn't happen on Kickstarter, we'll get there regardless with some post-Kickstarter growth strategies to reach the levels of membership we need to build and sustain a great experience. 
You can help (a lot) by sharing this project early and often, and bringing your friends and fellow cocktail lovers along with you on your journey.

Cheers,
Rachel Eva & Shawn Michael
Rachel Eva and Shawn Michael at our home bar -- and studio set -- in San Diego, California
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Regarding Kickstarter Projects in General:

This will be our 5th Kickstarter Campaign. We take these projects very seriously, and have experience knowing what we can commit to, and how to communicate when things don't go exactly as planned. For anyone who's ever started something new, you know that things rarely go exactly as planned! We commit to communicating about any challenges that come up, and what we're doing to address them. We'll also ask for your input to be part of helping us solve challenges that may impact your experience.

Backer Testimonial from Napier Jigger Project: "I received my stainless and copper jiggers today. The quality and packaging are first rate. I know you put a whole lot of effort into delivering a high quality product, while overcoming a lot of obstacles. You did both, in addition to providing backers with great communications around the process and involving us in many decisions."

For The Cocktail Journey:

The biggest risk we see with this project is if we make our funding goal but don't make it to 1,000 members. In order for us to build out the full Cocktail Journey Experience, we need a good base of founding members to help us design and provide feedback on the build-out. If we have a small number of backers (even if we meet our funding goal), we'll be able to deliver on our baseline commitments, but will also need to make membership growth a big area of focus after the Kickstarter ends, which may impact how much content we are able to produce right away.

One of the challenges with building a sustained, long-term project like this is making sure we have the right team to help us get there - and that we have the right resources to invest in that team. We have a 5-year roadmap for what we want to see happen with The Cocktail Journey. For this Kickstarter, we're focusing on what we can accomplish in year 1. If we make it to our funding goal of $25,000 we'll definitely be able to Kickstart this project, but will have a lot of work to do to grow after the Kickstarter ends. We have a plan in place to do that, but it will be more challenging if we only have $25k to work with -- it gets a lot easier at the $50k and $100k funding and stretch-goal scenarios. At those higher funding scenarios, we're also able to deliver more value to backers more quickly: mostly in the form of more on-demand educational content released more frequently.

campaign.story:
You abandoned your old life to work in tandem with the magician: the first person to show you that true magic exists in your world. When something goes horribly wrong and the magician gets himself into a bind he can’t escape, you must step forward to claim the gifts that have been yours all along, before it's too late to help him — or anyone else.

The Shape Of Shadows is a connected path game about show magic and true magic, the tension of asserting yourself as an equal to someone taking you under their wing; and the price you are willing to pay to fly on your own.
The Shape of Shadows can be adapted for players who prefer to write with brevity, using a bullet journal style of notation.
The Shape of Shadows is about a magician's assistant who, for their own reasons, dedicates their career to pursuing stage and close up magic through the mentorship of the magician. Through the eyes of the character they create, players will learn how the magician's assistant started the path they're on, how they chose to work with the magician, and why the risks and danger of learning true magic were not enough to deter them from their studies. Through intricately constructed journaling prompts, image- and word-based puzzles, and utilizing a mundane day planner to create strange alchemical rituals, players will explore the magic of the world they move through, in and out of this connected path game. The core game is played solo, but alongside everyone else who opens the door to the adventure and mystery at the heart of The Shape of Shadows. No two players' stories will be the same, but every player will walk their connected paths together through their play experiences.

A sampling of letters from former assistants for the players to discover in-game.
Connected path and keepsake games are two terms coined by Shing Yin Khor and myself during our collaboration on our previous game, Field Guide To Memory. In a connected path game, players experience unique, solitaire games while simultaneously sharing in a community of others engaging in the same creative spirit alongside them. 

The joy of playing a connected path the joy of show and tell: our intuitive desire to show each other what is precious to us, why we treasure it, and why we'd like to feel compelled to share it with the communities that are precious to us in turn. 
Playtester feedback on The Shape of Shadows was almost unanimous in its enthusiasm.
Both the narrative and core game experience in The Shape of Shadows center on a day planner. As the magician's assistant, much of your time in character will be spent interacting with the magician's planner, scouring it for keys to the doors he’s always kept closed to you, in order to learn what you need to restore him. 
An example of how some players answered game prompts in their planner by using color-coded index cards.
As the player, you will choose one month in a weekly planner to keep track of your character's increasingly strange appointments, while the rest of the planner undergoes a metamorphosis in your hands. Every day of play offers something new. Some days are contemplative, focusing on memory and observation in the form of journaling; others are adventurous and may lead you outside to find a token you need for a ritual circle; and still others involve trying your hand at more tangible crafts. 

Whether you're learning the nuances of different forms of sigil magic and how to work them into the trick locks you use during your close up magic shows; reviewing the finer points of talisman crafting to shield you from hecklers at the comedy club; charming your playing cards so they never tumble from your hands during a waterfall shuffle; or developing alchemical formulas for transmutation (that you can actually make in real life at home during the game!), it all goes in your planner to turn it page by page into a true magician's spellbook.
As far as you can tell, the magician devoted the entirety of his life to seeing how far he could push his skills in the practical application of true magic, and honing the craft of his show magic. Alchemy, cardistry, divination, illusionism, close-up, conjuring — nothing is off the table for him. 
Various letters from former magician's assistants over the years.
Over the course of his life the magician accumulated a veritable dragon's hoard of research materials, ritual components, flotsam and jetsam both figurative and literal (an avid beachcomber, the magician uses his findings often), and piles and piles of correspondence (some of it quite personal).
Almost every day during the game, you will receive 1-2(or more!) photographs and documentation of these objects as part of your gameplay prompts.
Two reward levels (the ILLUSIONIST and the CONJURER) include physical packages of these curiosities, mailed to you as part of the game's closing narrative.


LOCK, $15 (UNLIMITED) 
At the $15 KEY level, you will get added to the player list for The Shape of Shadow's live run in late summer. For the duration of the game's run you'll receive an email with story and activity prompts Monday through Thursday. The game lasts for four consecutive weeks.

KEY, $25 (UNLIMITED)
At the $25 LOCK level, you'll get everything associated with the live game, and a high resolution PDF of the full game text, sent to you after the live run wraps up. After her superlative layout work on Field Guide To Memory, Ruby Lavin will return to design The Shape of Shadows' PDF as well.

SLEIGHT, $40 (UNLIMITED)
At this level backers will get entry into the live game and the full game PDF for two recipients. 

ILLUSIONIST, $60 (UNLIMITED)
PLAY

All digital versions of the game, including the emailed live game experience in late summer, the full PDF, and large envelope of strange and beautiful paper ephemera, as described in the "Artifacts, Art, and Ephemera" section. Includes ephemera from the game narrative that your character or others may encounter during play, a sheet of custom-illustrated sigil stickers, and a sheet of holographic stamps showing a white rabbit popping in and out of a magician's hat. I am mountaineering up an exciting new learning curve and making this reward level unlimited.

CONJURER, $350 (LIMITED TO 60 BOXES)
An example of what a recipient of the Conjurer's box might receive.
In addition to everything at the ILLUSIONIST reward level, you will receive a literal one-of-a-kind collection of beautiful flotsam and jetsam just like the talismans and treasured detritus in the magician's office. Each box is numbered, since no two boxes are exactly the same, and all of them will have at least 1-2 pieces of my original art, in different mediums.

When I conceptualized this reward level, the thought that came to mind was "if a cabinet of curiosities could be ordered through delivery." The high level of care, craftsmanship, and artistic expression I want to put into each of these boxes is the kind of experiential feast I adore creating and sharing with people; and, in order to keep it sustainable, there is a strict limit of 60 of these boxes. 

Each collection box will be made, packed, lovingly fussed over, and shipped out a few at a time in order to avoid bottlenecking my home studio and office. If you back at this level, please note that another backer may receive their box long before you, depending on how many people end up supporting this level.

Creative Contributors
Amal El-Mohtar is an award-winning writer of fiction, poetry, and criticism. She is the science fiction and fantasy columnist for the New York Times Book Review and the co-author, with Max Gladstone, of This Is How You Lose the Time War, a novella which has received several honours including the Hugo, Nebula, BSFA, and Locus Awards. She lives in Ottawa with her spouse and two cats. Find her online at amalelmohtar.com.

Arabelle Sicardi is a beauty and fashion writer currently working on a nonfiction book on beauty called The House of Beauty. 

Banana Chan is a Chinese-Canadian/American TTRPG and board game writer, designer and publisher. She is the owner and co-founder of the publishing company, Game and a Curry. Some of her work has been on Jiangshi: Blood In the Banquet Hall, Van Richten’s Guide to Ravenloft, Scooby-Doo: Betrayal at Mystery Mansion and Questlings RPG. When she’s not busy working on games, she’s busy chasing pigeons out of her home.


Brennan Lee Mulligan is the creator and GM for Dimension 20, and a CollegeHumor cast member. He has taught and performed at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, co-created the webcomic Strong Female Protagonist, and written dozens of LARPs for the Wayfinder Experience summer camp in upstate New York. He recently started putting a little bit of cinnamon in his morning coffee, which he has described as "a real game changer."

DongWon Song is an agent at Howard Morhaim Literary Agency representing science fiction and fantasy for adults, young adult, and middle grade readers as well as select non-fiction. They were formerly an editor at Orbit, a product manager for an ebook startup, and has taught at institutions including Portland State University and New York University.

Jabari Weathers cannot confirm or deny their suspected status as an exiled goblin regent seeking refuge beyond the veil. They presently reside in Baltimore, Maryland, making fantasy and sci-fi illustrations and spinning worlds and fictions for roleplaying games and other interactive projects out of words to keep up their glamour. They've recently written for a variety of indie RPGs, as well as for Wizards of the Coast and Paizo. Other things that they enjoy are strange films, stranger music, singing in public places, and the thoroughly uncanny. You can follow them on Twitter and Instagram and contact them at jmwillustration@gmail.com



Kienna Shaw is a TTRPG designer, streamer, writer, and community creator. They have contributed to products such as Jiangshi: Blood in the Banquet Hall (Wet Ink Games), Sea of Legends (Guildhall Studios), and Candlekeep Mysteries (Wizards of the Coast). She has also self-published micro-RPGs on itchio and enjoys exploration of relationships, introspection, and big feelings through the medium of games.

Hugo award winner Sarah Gailey lives and works in California. Their nonfiction has been published by Mashable and the Boston Globe, and their fiction has been published internationally. Their debut novel, Magic for Liars, was an LA Times bestseller. Their most recent novel, The Echo Wife, is available now. You can find links to their work at www.sarahgailey.com. They tweet @gaileyfrey.

Sharang Biswas has won IndieCade and IGDN awards for roleplaying games, and has showcased interactive works at institutions such as The Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia, Pioneer Works in Brooklyn, and The Museum of the Moving Image in Queens. He has written for games such as Spire, Sea of Legends, Jiangshi: Blood on the Banquet Hall, Into the Motherlands, and Dungeons & Dragons Live. He is the co-editor of “Honey & Hot Wax: An Anthology of Erotic Art Games” (Pelgrane Press), and “Strange Lusts / Strange Loves: An Anthology of Erotic Interactive Fiction” (Strange Horizons).

MET! The first stretch goal is to raise enough to hire a team of eight brilliant creators, all of them master magicians in their own right who understand the nature of true magic and will deliver it in their own unique ways to further build out the world with short fiction, in-character letters, clandestine texts, and other . Both this and the previous stretch goal will be made available to backers at all game levels. The incredible roster of writers and creators will be announced in stages once the stretch goal is met.

 Jeeyon Shim is a second generation Korean American game designer, multimedia artist, and outdoor educator based in California. Her work is defined by her lyrical prose and ability to reconnect people to themselves, their communities, and the natural world that holds them all. Jeeyon’s games have been featured on Polygon, Shut Up and Sit Down, and Dicebreaker, among other publications. Other notables include working as artist in residence at the Heart of the Deernicorn, serving as Keynote Speaker at Big Bad Con, and several years as a program coordinator for an outdoor education company, where she designed live action roleplaying games that taught real world wilderness survival skills to children. She is absolutely, 100% that audience member who involuntarily shouts "HOW DID THEY DO THAT?" after a particularly well executed trick. If you know any magic tricks she definitely wants to see them.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The Shape of Shadows is my third Kickstarter; my two most recent Kickstarters (Field Guide To Memory and The Last Will and Testament of Gideon Blythe) were met with enthusiastic success, both projects funding in their first forty minutes and selling out of all their physical reward levels in less. This game builds further on the scaffold of everything I’ve learned from those experiences.

The game is fully structured and written, albeit in an unedited late-stage draft. The Kickstarter funds will cover the cost of copy editing by Ryan Boyd, and layout design by Ruby Lavin (whose previous layout credits include Field Guide To Memory and Wanderhome), as well as giving me the time I need to attend to the creative and administrative tasks associated with the multifaceted nature of connected path games like this one. Short of Mailchimp’s server going down or a street magician accidentally turning me into a rabbit, I anticipate fulfillment of the text and live game to stay on schedule.

I do not currently have a fulfillment partner for the Illusionist reward level (the flat art and ephemera), but I'm in touch with two or three companies and will contract the most suitable once I know what quantity of printed goods I'll need to ship. While the USPS is generally reliable for domestic US mail, with any physical reward there is always the risk of packages getting delayed or lost in thin air. 

Additionally, the future of international mail sent out of the US is currently hard to read in the cards. I fully intend to work with my future fulfillment partner to send out every single package that is backed and accounted for, but be aware that it could take a very long time for your rewards to reach you. (Due to various plant pressings and organic materials in the Conjurer's boxes, I cannot ship that reward level internationally and it will be limited to US backers.)

My aim is to fulfill this Kickstarter from late July to August, well before the stated delivery dates. Still, I left myself enough buffer to weather most unexpected changes. Overall, I anticipate a strong, efficient, and invigorating Kickstarter campaign, and I am already looking forward to it!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Long-lasting design
I design my games and the skills that I teach through them to be meaningful to the player, and made in a way that will last a long time. When players connect deeply with what they create, they are more likely to keep and treasure their work — thus being far less likely to end up throwing their creations out as waste materials.
Reusability and recyclability
Players will repurpose various pieces of ephemera from their own lives, thereby saving them from turning into waste! 

Many of my materials for the Conjurer's Boxes are sourced from local secondhand shops or my own stores of various odds and ends.

Additionally, many players have collections of journals that they can source from, further reducing the environmental toll of new manufacturing.
Sustainable materials
Players will be sourcing their own journals for play, making impact individual and less impactful.
Environmentally friendly factories
All my vendors are based in the United States, and all the vendors I plan to hire for the Illusionist's printing needs are specifically local to my city.
Sustainable Distribution
All packaging and shipping materials I will personally use to pack the Conjurer's boxes are made from 100% recycled matter. Once I know who I will be working with as my fulfillment partner, I will make sure to emphasize that I expect to use uncoated recyclable paper materials, and if we must use plastics I will strive to opt for packaging that is made from 100% post-consumer goods.

"GATSBY" LIMITED EDITION LETTERPRESS 
Hello! 
We're making one hundred, signed 16x20 limited edition letterpress prints featuring one of our newest and most popular illustrations, inspired by the last line of The Great Gatsby. This is our fifth letterpress artwork with our partner, Boxcar Press. 
 "So we beat on, boats against the current,  borne back ceaselessly into the past."  
The final line of The Great Gatsby, the Fitzgerald novel that defined the jazz age. It was the era that ushered in modernity, a time of material excess, liberation, and intoxication. But even in the midst of the party, Fitzgerald could sense the toll such decadence takes on the human soul.
Like so many other Fitzgerald fans, we adore this quotation and its kaleidoscopic meanings. Gatsby, surrounded by unimaginable wealth, prestige and fanfare, dreams only of a future with Daisy that will recreate their past. And yet, his past is what prevents him from attaining that bright future. All pomp and circumstance aside, Gatsby is deeply relatable. Everyone, in their own way, aspires to their own vision of “one fine day.” Everyone is reaching toward the green light. And like Gatsby, we are all eventually borne, against our will, into the past.
In our illustration, a figure rows toward an ethereal, glimmering girl as her dress forms the bay. Her belt resembles a gleaming cityscape, and a green jewel dangles from a string of pearls.

"And as I sat there brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby’s wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had come a long way to this blue lawn, and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it. He did not know that it was already behind him, somewhere back in that vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.
Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that’s no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further… And one fine morning—
So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."
OUR PRINT PARTNER: BOXCAR PRESS
We've been working with Boxcar Press since our first letterpress run (and first Kickstarter project in 2017). Their work is meticulous and beautiful, and their master printers wow us every time.

The large prints make a bold, tactile statement and are made with archival inks and fine art paper that will last a lifetime.

We print our postcards on thick, premium paper that makes them suitable for framing, displaying or mailing. All of our postcards are printed in California on FSC certified, sustainable paper. We use soy and vegetable-based inks and uncoated paper for a beautiful, elegant finish.

campaign.story:
Tomorrow on Revelation III is a roleplaying game about surviving and overcoming capitalism in a future among the stars. Four hundred years from now, aerospace corporations have traversed the galaxy, colonizing this solar system and ones beyond. You live on the heavily stratified agricultural station Revelation III, where the deck you’re born on determines your profession, privileges, and possibilities.
You are on the precipice of making major changes to the station, but reform is a complex process. Together, you work to improve and transform your conditions by creating meaning beyond productivity, balancing environmental betterment and social imagination with individual survival and persistence.
In Tomorrow on Revelation III, you play until the station is one you would want to live on.
“Tomorrow on Revelation III is a brilliant exploration of anticapitalism, mutual aid, and the complicated morality of participating in a system you never signed up for. The world of the game is beautifully written, delightfully fleshed out but never limiting … far and away the only capitalist hellscape I'd ever voluntarily participate in!” 
– Alina Whatley, playtester
“There’s so much that’s new and elevated with Revelation III. My favorite part is the structure—the movement from character creation to downtime to mission phases. Establishing the setting in science fiction games can sometimes feel overwhelming, but this system circumvents that … you start off in a realm that’s almost GMless where everyone gets to take part in a generative brainstorm that naturally progresses into meaningful character roleplay.” 
– Elizabeth Winkelhoff, playtester
Tomorrow on Revelation III is for 2-5 players and a gamemaster (GM), and can be played as a one-shot or a campaign. In a one-shot, you and your fellow players pick a specific aspect of the station to focus on improving. In a campaign, you build relationships and reconfigure the station over a long period of time, following your characters as they go about their lives.
The game uses its own easy-to-learn original system with a mixture of simple skill checks and moves. Each player builds a character by selecting a background and answering questions about their positionality on the station and relationships to one another. You might play as a merchant, with a penchant for making good first impressions and the inside scoop about the ongoings of the station. Or a freight worker, hauling cargo and befriending the station robots. Or a personal assistant, using your vocational connection to Deck A to secure information and resources your community couldn't otherwise access.
Your character’s background describes their profession and dictates most aspects of their life, such as their social class, the decks they live and work on, and their influence on different parts of the station.  Each background provides background-specific traits and 8 points of cultural capital that can be used on different decks.
The twelve backgrounds are:
Administrator
Engineer
Healthcare Worker
Merchant
Artist
Teacher
Tradesperson
Freight Worker
Labor Supervisor
Personal Assistant
Childcare Worker
Agriculture Worker
Revelation III is divided into six decks lettered A-F, with residents assigned to decks based on their occupation. These divisions is core to the station’s function: Revelation III is primarily an agricultural station, and the continued existence not only of this station but of others belonging to Prodigy depends on the food production that occurs on Deck E. 
The higher the deck, the better the circumstances. Residents may travel to lower decks freely, but up to higher decks only for specific activities and with specially granted permissions. Deck access is governed by key cards. Each deck has its own unique tensions, balancing intra-deck solidarity with competition for resources and mobility.  Genuine relationships of any kind between people across decks are rare and hard won. 
This is all part of the reality you are working to change. 
Tomorrow on Revelation III includes a two page, full color map by Tim Wilkinson Lewis detailing each of the decks described in the book.
After character creation, Tomorrow on Revelation III is divided into two phases of gameplay: a downtime phase, and a mission phase. The downtime phase is one of collaborative storytelling about daily life on the station. Player characters (PCs) can seek out information to aid them in their upcoming objectives, build relationships that increase their cultural capital pool, alleviate conditions, and gather equipment. The mission phase represents the characters’ efforts to improve life on the station. The characters select one or more realities related to surviving, negotiating, and overcoming capitalism that they would like to improve on the station, and collaborate to begin addressing this problem.
Tomorrow on Revelation III intentionally combines slice-of-life storytelling with mission-based gameplay. The responsibility for developing the world and setting elements is shared among the GM and the players. In the downtime phase, the whole group works together to paint a richer picture of the station: players freely incorporate their ideas about the setting and may portray non-player characters (NPCs) in scenes with one another. In the mission phase, the GM controls the setting elements and NPCs, and the players utilize their traits and ingenuity to navigate the adversarial station.
Want to see the downtime phase in action? Check out this audio: 
 Agriculture worker Eli (played by Liz), personal assistant Reighgynn (played by Alina), and teacher Riley (played by Dominique) are planning a heist—they're going to steal medical supplies from the upper decks of Revelation III to redistribute on the underserved lower decks. In these two downtime scenes, the PCs hack the station's transit system with the help of Kettle the robot and conduct a black market deal to acquire supplies. GMing by CJ. Audio editing by Anna Hibbert.
Your cultural capital pool is determined by your background, and starts off highest on the decks where you live or work. A Deck E agricultural worker has no cultural capital on Deck A (and a Deck A administrator has none on Deck E) because they have little to no experience with the deck in question.
In short, cultural capital is a numerical representation of a PC’s cultural competency on, and general knowledge about, the decks of Revelation III. Cultural capital is applied to skill checks.
Tomorrow on Revelation III features:
Design by Dominique Dickey and Charles Jamie Linton 
Graphic and layout design by Vee Hendro 
Cover illustration by Aleta Pérez 
Map illustration by Tim Wilkinson Lewis 
Interior illustration by Sadia Bies 
The book includes the complete setting, rules, and a starter module for quick play.
The digital edition is a full color, illustrated PDF of the game.
The print edition is a 5.5" x 8.5" softcover book with a full color cover and a black and white interior.
At $9,750 stretch goal, the physical copies will be printed in color!
Here’s the budget distribution:
 $4,200 for layout, map, and art.
 $1,000 for printing and production.
 $800 for Kickstarter and BackerKit fees and taxes.
After the campaign ends, we will be utilizing BackerKit, via which backers can manage pledges and pay for shipping. We fulfill the pledges ourselves once we receive the print edition. Delivery will begin in September 2021.
US shipping will cost an estimated fee of ~$5 (via USPS media mail).
International shipping will cost an estimated fee of ~$15 (via USPS International First Class).



Dominique Dickey is a writer, editor, cultural consultant, and all-around RPG hooligan. In addition to creating TRIAL, a narrative courtroom tabletop role-playing game about race in the criminal justice system, Dominique has written for Thirsty Sword Lesbians, Sea of Legends, and Monte Cook Games. Updates on their work, pets, and tea preferences can be found at dominiquedickey.com, or on Twitter @DomSDickey.
Charles Jamie Linton is a game designer, writer, and dramaturg from the San Gabriel Valley. He is the creator of the haunted objects rpg Bring Down the House and the trans superhero rpg Those Of Us Who Know Better. You can find him on itch.io and Twitter at @NearFutures and more work at cjlinton.com.
Vee Hendro is a graphic designer specialising in roleplaying and board game projects including the layouts of Good Society (Storybrewers) and Visigoths vs Mall Goths (Lucian Kahn). Her portfolio is at veerpgdesigns.com and on Twitter @Rocketeer_Vee.
Aleta is an illustrator and screenprinter in Minneapolis, MN. They specialize in highly textured and detailed landscapes. When they are not drawing many, many tiny lines, they can be found playing a lot of FFXIV or hanging out with their cat Princess Zelda. Their work can be found at aletaillustration.com and on Twitter at @afiregender.
Tim Wilkinson Lewis is an artist and illustrator in Cambridge, UK. His specialities are quixo-cartography, puzzles, fantastical documents, and things like that. He's worked on Spire, Aphelion, Sigmata, Havoc Brigade and others, and some very inaccurate maps of real places too. His website is timwilkinsonlewis.com, his comics are at yeshiveoverlord.com, and he's on Twitter as @twl_corinthian.
Sadia Bies is an artist who works in various mediums with a passion for insects, robots, and the fantastic. They have been a full time illustrator for the past year with a focus on bringing ttrpgs to life. You can see their work in projects such as Sleepaway, Gun&Slinger, and Glitch, as well as their own games they release on itch.io.
Ryan Boyd is an editor, writer, and podcaster based in Southern California. Give them trouble on Twitter at @ryandroyd.
Jabari Weathers is a fantasy illustrator, writer and game designer who primarily works in tabletop roleplaying games. They reside in Baltimore MD, though their true versal genesis is of an unknown origin. The strange, uncanny and beautiful is their bread and butter. You can find their work at goblinprincete.com, and you can follow them on Instagram (jmwillustration) and Twitter (goblinprincete). 
Kazumi Chin is a writer and game designer. They are the author of poetry collection Having a Coke With Godzilla, as well as indie games such as Rogue 2E, Invincible Sword Princess, and Reverie. They believe in a world without prisons or policing
Jonaya Kemper is a New Jersey-born badass activist, artist, educator, designer, writer, and games scholar who looks at play as a means of liberation for people of marginalized identities. Her work often involves the themes of intersectionality, storytelling, and autoethnography as a means to create more inclusive futures and explore a more diverse past.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is our first Kickstarter project, but we're very fortunate to be working with a team of wonderful and experienced professionals. We’ve budgeted carefully and your pledge covers payment to the team, shipping and production costs, and associated fees.

Steps we’ve taken to guarantee fulfillment:

1. Shipping is added after. We’ve eliminated the risk that our budget won’t cover shipping costs by charging shipping later via BackerKit.
 
2. It’s just the game! As cool as it would be to create Tomorrow on Revelation III merchandise, our only physical deliverable is the book.
 
3. Work is already well underway. All of the writing for the core book is complete, with the exception of stretch goal modules and custom content from the high-level Kickstarter tiers. This content is quite minimal and has firm due dates. Following the receipt of this content, the book will undergo copyediting and layout and then be ready for print.
 
It's possible that editing or layout may take longer than estimated, or that the printer will experience delays. Barring these potential problems, we expect to finish the book on time and get it into your hands by the September 2021 delivery goal.

campaign.story:
The village of Stonetop is your home. Maybe it wasn’t always, but it is now. And the world out there is darkening, like the sky before a late-summer storm.
These are good people, here in Stonetop. Your kith and your kin.
If you don’t step up to protect them, who will?
Stonetop is a “hearth fantasy” tabletop RPG set in an Iron Age that never was. The players portray the heroes of an isolated village near the edge of the known world. Their adventures focus on dealing with threats to the village and seizing opportunities. These aren’t rootless mercenaries seeking fortune and glory; they’re exceptional people, taking risks on behalf of their friends, family, and neighbors.
Like most tabletop RPGs, Stonetop plays out as a conversation between the game master (GM) and the players, with dice being rolled at key moments to determine which direction the story goes. The game can be played in short runs of 2-4 sessions (each about 3-4 hours long), but is best experienced over a dozen or more sessions.
Stonetop is “Powered by the Apocalypse,” using a system and framework similar to games like Apocalypse World, Monster of the Week, or Masks: a New Generation. It started as a setting guide for Dungeon World, but over 5 years of development and playtesting, it’s become a standalone game. Knowledge of Dungeon World may ease your entry into the game, but it's not a prerequisite for play.
Printable play aids include all of Stonetop's core "moves"—the rules that drive the game.
Features of the system include:
 A rich and well-realized world of gritty Iron Age fantasy adventure, providing enough detail to ground play immediately while leaving plenty of room for the players and GM to make the setting their own.
 9 distinct types of player-character (see below), each with their own reasons to look out for their community and seek adventure beyond its walls.
 Rules for governing and improving the village itself across the seasons and over the course of years.
 Rules for overland travel that capture the excitement of setting out into the unknown and the relief of returning home after a long time away.
 Hand-drawn maps depicting the village of Stonetop itself, its immediate surroundings, and the extent of the known world.
 An extensive setting almanac covering important regions, points of interest, neighboring settlements, creatures of the wild, and eerie remnants of past civilizations.
 A collection of unique magic items, each with special rules for unlocking its mysteries, powers, and dangers.
 Guidelines and advice for the GM, including step-by-step processes for collaborative customization of the village, adventure creation, and shaping a developing campaign.
“I had a chance to play this with a small group, including one person who usually didn't enjoy RPGs. We only played one session, and he still talks to me about how special it was to him. I would play it again in a heartbeat.” —William H., Vox Arcana Podcast
Click through for full-size page spread
A close-knit community burns bright at the edge of the known world, surrounded by mystery and danger. Rainwater collects in the Cistern; iron is shaped at the forge; magic is rare and fearsome; the will of the gods is discerned from the shapes of the clouds. Only the bravest venture far from the Ringwall, but upon these few the future of the village depends. 
Enough setting detail is provided to start everyone on the same page, but as the players create and introduce their heroes, they begin to shape the world to their personal and collective interests. The game text establishes a foundation upon which each group builds their own unique version of Stonetop.
Although extensive guides to the village, its environs, creatures, and other elements are included, this material is designed less as a “setting bible” and more as a toolkit full of prompts and resources for the players and GM to exploit.
Click through for full-size page spread
"I love the setting, from the ancient ruins and wild places haunted by fae, spirits, and much stranger things (hypnotic baboon-headed snakes!) to the magic that demands sacrifice and promises terrible consequences. Every setting detail is richly evocative and meant to be played, not just read, with countless hooks, prompts, blanks, and questions that have spurred my creativity and my players’ enthusiastic collaboration." —Matt Wetherbee, playtester
At the start of a new game, each player creates one hero to play. There are nine different archetypes, each with a unique set of possible backgrounds, abilities, and connections to the village, all defined by the player during the first game session: 
Each playbook is designed to hold "inserts" for tracking things like inventory, the Marshal's crew, or the Ranger's animal companion:
Click through for a PDF of the Seeker's playbook.
Interior of the Seeker's playbook with inventory insert
“I love it. The character creation is evocative and really feels like play... It creates not only your character’s backstory and relationship to other player characters, but also to Stonetop and the NPCs in Stonetop. When you are done with session zero, not only are you psyched to play your character and interact with the other player characters, but you are attached to the village.” —Christo Meid, playtester
The village of Stonetop has its own character sheet, or “playbook,” with stats, traits, and improvements to be unlocked in play. This playbook drives much of the game. For example, the village’s "Fortunes" directly affect what new threats or opportunities each new season brings, and the players must manage the community’s "Surplus" to avoid disaster when winter comes. As a game of Stonetop progresses, the village playbook changes in response to the victories and failures of the player-characters. And as the village changes, so do the threats and opportunities that heroes face.
Click through for a PDF of the steading playbook.
"I didn't know how much I needed a game that let me play out Our Town or Main Street or Gilmore Girls in a fantasy setting until I played Stonetop and realized it might be the only game I needed. Stonetop not only helps players create amazing adventures. It also creates a persistent, believable place. Players will come to care about that place and the people who live there deeply." —Emily VanDerWerff, Vox
The game includes dozens of magic items and locations ("arcana") that the heroes can acquire and learn to use. Each has special rules for unlocking its mysteries, tapping its powers, and—for the most powerful items—the consequences of doing so.
These arcana are designed to be printed as two-sided cards, to be given to players as handouts.
Click through for PDF examples of major and minor arcana (spoiler alert!)
"Stonetop's unique take on magic items—requiring effort to understand and activate and each coming with their own set of costs and consequences—is fresh, rewarding, and surprisingly intuitive. Each Major and Minor Arcana has a character of its own that drives its story forward, each one naturally forming a story hook that is as unique as the character who wields it." —Chris Thompson, playtester
The goal of this campaign is to fund the printing of two high-quality hardback books:
 Book I: Stonetop contains the core rules and extensive guidance for the GM. ~400 pages.
 Book II: The Wider World and Other Wonders is a setting almanac that details the regions, sites, monsters, and arcana (magic items) unique to Stonetop. ~250 pages.
These books will be 5.5"x8.5" ("digest" size), hardback, printed offset, and jam-packed with beautiful pen-and-ink illustrations by artist Lucie Arnoux.
Here's an early mock-up of the books to convey their intended size:
Mock-up for scale (cover designs not final)
And here's a mock-up with a more stone-like feel, showing the stretch-goal slipcase that will be included with every set of books:
Click through for a higher resolution image.
All backers will receive PDFs of both books and additional play aids. The PDFs will be thoroughly bookmarked and hyperlinked to maximize ease of use.
"What can I say about Stonetop that hasn’t been said already? I could wax lyrical at length about the wild grandeur of the setting, the clarity of the GMing techniques, the evocative poetry of the playbooks, how well the moves bind the game around the village and its material human concerns, the balance it finds between unique worldbuilding and blank spaces crying out to be made your own.
"Instead I’ll just say this: for four years now, this has been the game I come back to time and time again, always bringing new friends with me. I’m playing in a campaign now and still I know that in months to come I’ll hear the call again, pull on my GMing boots, and go wandering once more up to that little village at the top of the world." —Luke Jordan, game designer, Games from the Wildwood
Anyone who backs at the Print + Digital level has the option to select additional rewards, in the form of art prints and/or a custom character illustration by Stonetop's artist, Lucie Arnoux. These add-ons include:
 [SOLD OUT] Two 5.8" x 8.3" (A5) black-and-white giclée prints of two of Lucie's favorite  illustrations from the books, signed by Lucie.
 [SOLD OUT] An 8.3" x 11.7" (A4) black-and-white giclée print of the map of the wider world of Stonetop, signed by Lucie. 
An 8.3" x 11.7" (A4) black-and-white giclée print of a full-body character portrait, drawn to your specifications and signed by Lucie. Original art may be purchased separately, by arrangement with the artist.
Unsigned prints of one or more of Lucie's hand-drawn maps will be available as add-ons after the close of the campaign.
Clockwise from top left: Green Lord ruins and Jaq the spriggan; custom character portrait; map of the wider world.
Our basic funding goal covers everything essential for running and playing Stonetop, in print and PDF form. Beyond that, we only want to reach for things that add significant content. We may add stretch goals as opportunities develop over the course of the campaign
 [GOAL MET!] $17,500+: Markdown conversion. All game text converted and made available for free public use under a CC-BY-SA license. Tech-savvy users can then turn this into ePub or web pages at their leisure.
 [GOAL MET!] $20,000+: Digital play aids. A full set of form-fillable PDFs and other material to assist with online play.
 [GOAL MET!] $22,500+: Arcana Uncovered. Six more Arcana (4 minor, 2 major) in printable PDF form. 
 [GOAL MET!] $25,000+: Adventure Starters. Three different situations, packed with mystery, opportunity, and danger, to get your party started. 
 [GOAL MET!] $27,500+: More Arcana Uncovered. Six more Arcana (4 minor, 2 major) in printable PDF form.
 [GOAL MET!] $30,000+: More Adventure Starters. Three additional adventure starters.
 [SURPRISE ACHIEVEMENT!] $40,000: Slipcase. A sturdy, lovingly-designed cardboard container for both books. This had been on my wishlist from the moment we decided to break Stonetop into two books. See this update for a mockup.
 [SURPRISE ACHIEVEMENT!] $42,500: Hand-drawn map of Gordin's Delve. A bird's-eye view of Stonetop's closest neighboring settlement, drawn by Lucie.
 [GOAL MET!] $45,000: Hand-drawn map of Marshedge. A bird's-eye view of the bustling town down east, where Brennan and his Claws hold sway, drawn by Lucie.
 [GOAL MET!] $47,500: Annotated Actual Play. Hobbes LeGault, a longtime resident of Stonetop, will produce a series of annotated actual play videos with Jeremy running the game. Annotations will highlight GM moves as they are made, rules being referenced, player choices, mechanical interactions, and any missteps noticed in retrospect.
 [GOAL MET!] $65,000: Foundry Virtual Tabletop system for Stonetop. A full integration of Stonetop's mechanics, components, and setting material into the Foundry platform, allowing for a comprehensive online play experience.
 [GOAL MET!] $85,000: Holdfast Station. Lampblack & Brimstone will publish a new standalone science fiction game inspired by Stonetop, in PDF and print-on-demand forms! See this update for details.
 Jeremy Strandberg (game design, writing) is an instructional designer and software trainer living in Madison, WI. He's the creator of Homebrew World and Defying Danger, the RPG. He maintains the gplusarchive.online, and writes about RPGs at spoutinglore.blogspot.com.
 Lucie Arnoux (illustration, maps) is a UK-based artist whose work includes reportage, children's books, set design, and comics. Her graphic memoir is set to be published by Random House/Jonathan Cape in 2021.
 Jason Lutes (layout, art direction, production) is a cartoonist, game designer, and educator living in Vermont, where he teaches at the Center for Cartoon Studies. He is the author of the graphic novels Berlin and Jar of Fools, and publishes RPG books as Lampblack & Brimstone.
After all costs for the project are covered, any profits will be shared between the creators, with 10% going to Lucie, 20% going to Jason, and 70% going to Jeremy.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I (Jason) have successfully run three previous Kickstarter campaigns: Bingo Baby, a comic book based on a play session of the game Fiasco; Servants of the Cinder Queen, a Dungeon World adventure; and The Perilous Wilds, a Dungeon World supplement. Each project has been slightly more ambitious than the last, which has allowed me to gradually improve my knowledge base and set reasonable goals.

Content and art is 75% complete for Stonetop, so the main challenge I see is making sure that the printing and fulfillment of the two books goes smoothly. There may be delays, for instance, if I ask for extensive corrections after seeing the printer's proofs, or if other aspects of production don't meet my expectations. For previous projects I have shipped all rewards myself, so going with third-party fulfillment is also an unknown.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content: PLAY
I'm gonna save most of the gushing gratitude and bewilderment for tomorrow. Right now, I just want to introduce our final playback:

The final-day push is well underway, and we continue to welcome newcomers to our not-so-small, not-so-isolated village.  Welcome, one and all!
I've noticed that we're piquing the interest of folks who are intrigued by the setting and premise of Stonetop, but who aren't familiar with Powered by the Apocalypse games. It's definitely a style of play that can feel strange if you've never experienced it. 
Even if you're a PbtA veteran, each game comes with it's own agenda, principles, moves, and unique perspective. is no different.

Every time I come back to this page (and let's face it, it's been pretty often today), the numbers keep ticking up. We passed 2,000 backers around lunch time, and 10 hours later, we're over 2100. That kind of growth feels almost... magical.
Speaking of magic, and growing things, I think we're passed due in meeting...

campaign.story:
Cerebos: The Crystal City is a tabletop roleplaying game about exploration and self-actualization. It’s also about crossing a surreal desert by train, visiting improbable cities, and experiencing sublime understanding among uncommon vistas. It’s about homesickness and lumpy beds and brand new stew and finding a coda for the broken song in your heart.
The player characters are travelers from the City by the Sea, bound to mementos of the past. Even after their identities have been worn away by the endless desert, they seek Cerebos. Through motion, reflection, and the actions of their fellow passengers they rediscover who they were and decide who they will be when they reach the Crystal City.
Illustration by Shel Kahn
Each traveler is limited by their physical touchstones, but they are also empowered. Anyone lugging a coffin full of roses or a bismuth teapot through disorienting light and memory-shattering weather must have had a good reason – or at least what seemed like a good idea at the time.
Those who travel the road to Cerebos do so for many reasons. A starting character might be:
A choleric puppeteer with a flashy harlequin’s cape. She carries a distressed marionette and a flask of bitter syrup.
An out-of-sorts gentleman of the road. He carries a hooded lantern, a satchel of mushroom jerky, and wears a tight hat.
A wisp of a figure caught on the wind. They wear a broken monocle and an ironwood key and carry a parasol with a hidden compartment.
The travelers meet at a railway terminus. They experience flashbacks, overcome unexpected events, and ride the rails to the world’s beautiful imperfections. Trust doesn’t come easy when the dining car is infested with chandler beetles and the sister cities of Orm and Calyx are competing for sacred fools, but maybe it’s the only thing that will keep everyone going.
Illustration by Shel Kahn
Travelers change based on new experiences, but their pasts have already been decided. Each player secretly determines another traveler’s past, which is revealed in play through flashbacks. They may learn they’re a demon (metaphorical or otherwise) with the power to foment change. Likewise, they may be a proponent of order and constancy.
Neutrality is a sucker’s game, whether the travelers lurch toward found family or explode in a pressure cooker of misfits and malcontents. By the second leg of the journey a traveler may discover:
The choleric puppeteer’s family corrupted the City by the Sea. Cerebos is said to have a grand puppet theatre where the performers are all masked. She is a seeker of truth, the ideological linchpin of the journey.
The out-of-sorts gentleman is a gnome who misfiled his taxes and has been trapped in the body of a lighthouse keeper. The central tax office in Cerebos can clear up this misunderstanding. He is a saint, encouraging the seeker to hold true to her quest.
The windblown wisp was an ambitious scientist who extracted the memories of a dozen people before falling prey to their own procedure. The only cure, the last Human Optimization Project Encephalograph unit, has been shipped to the Crystal City. They are a demon, celebrating the freedom of the road and the limitless future.
The train’s conductor moves the travelers along, setting the journey’s tone and modifying the rules. An adventurous conductor guides the travelers through a world of danger and megafauna, cataloging the limits of human experience, while kindly ol’ Mr. Wumpus is more suited to cozy, rabbit-shaped hijinks.
Illustration by Cynthia Yuan Cheng
Cerebos is inspired by games like Sunless Sea, stories of fantastic cities like Invisible Cities and Kino’s Journey, Infinity Train, family road trips, prog rock album covers, purgatory, and quarter-and-mid-life crises. These stories fuel a robust engine for telling stories about change, hope, stability, risk, stagnation, want, giant crabs, vichychoisse, and comfortable cushions.
The system is light and easy to learn, rewarding imaginative solutions and collaborative character growth. It requires two six-sided dice, character sheets, and name tags or another way of sharing private information. A typical story requires three to four players and an optional gamemaster and lasts one to two sessions.
Illustration by Cynthia Yuan Cheng
The 80-page game includes:
Complete rules. Incompatible with the world’s most popular role-playing game!
Over 30 Stops. Fantastic cities, deadly tourist traps, and more than a few works of giant stone anatomy, each with a unique travel keepsake. (Update 2021-04-03: Including all stretch goals met to date, the Stops tables will now have 78 entries.)
Over 30 Events. Weather, fellow passengers, and unique properties of the rail, each with a unique travel keepsake. (Update 2021-04-03: Including all stretch goals met to date, the Events tables will now have 78 entries.)
4 Conductors. Modify the genre and rules of the rail with Adventure, Psychogrit, a Musical Journey Through Space, or an All-Ages Fairy Tale. (Update 2021-04-03: Including all stretch goals met to date, the core rulebook will now feature seven Conductors.)
Advice for improvising collaborative scenes that support imagery-rich character growth
Puns and textual delights for the discerning collector of RPG paraphernalia
A catalog of inspirations, annotated to highlight the role of travel, cities, trains, and self-discovery within liminal spaces
The primary text is already written. If you'd like a closer look at the game, check out a preview of the text, the character sheet, and some sample Stops and Events.
The preview contains a summary of play, an introduction to conductors, traits, touchstones, the core dice mechanics, and what it means to be a saint or a demon.
Pre-release Reviews
"Cerebos is such a delightfully paced and thoughtful game about journeying and seeking, the unreliability of memory and the joys of collaborative myth-making. As a train enthusiast and lover of strange objects described well, this game was immediately compelling to me. The art by Shel Kahn and Cynthia [Yuan] Cheng and elegant and understated design work by Francita Soto makes the game absolutely shine. This game is going to burrow into the heart of anyone who has been dreaming of riding cross-country in the viewing car of an Amtrak train."
 — Shing Yin Khor, co-author of Field Guide to Memory
"A wonderful game about a neglected genre: the journey-as-metaphor. Zach Welhouse gives you everything you need to take your own train ride through surreal worlds, invisible cities and empires of the heart."
 — Jason Thompson, designer of Dreamland

If you're an online gamer, this is the reward level for you. You get:

If you're feeling fancy, give this reward level a try. You get everything that comes with the digital edition, plus a limited edition hardcover with natural-coloured paper, heat burnished faux-leather covers, and a ribbon bookmark. This hardcover edition will be available only via this campaign, and will not be reprinted.

Note: For backers outside Canada and the United States, physical rewards will be sent via surface freight. This is done to keep your shipping costs reasonable; under present conditions, international airmail would cost more than the reward. International backers should expect to receive their physical rewards 8–10 weeks after shipping begins.

As with any journey, leaving the station is only the beginning. Each stop along the wall will add more content to Cerebos: The Crystal City – more Stops, more Events, more Conductors, and even more art for the core rulebook. Any physical add-ons that include these items will also be expanded at no extra cost as these goals are reached.
$4000 CAD (reached!)
"Relics and Reclamations" (Stops table) by Paul "Ettin" Matijevic – That which is lost often finds itself in the most peculiar circumstances. From an ancient observatory that contains a stolen star to a bath town built over a dumping ground for unwanted words, the travelers soon learn they’re not the only ones wrestling with treasures from the past.
"Hauntings" (Events table) by Will Mendoza – The desert is littered with bones and restless spirits. So is the train. A ghostly child cries softly in the dining car. A scraping sound emanates from an ancient suitcase. A grinning shape stands over the beds of sleeping passengers. Who are they and what do they want?
$5000 CAD (reached!)
"Lost Aviaries" (Stops table) by Pam Punzalan – Aviaries on the edge of lost possibilities float through the sky. Their massive flora could be from experiments gone rogue or magic long lost. Beyond a few settlers, all beings in the aviaries are delicate, clockwork beauties – or blindfolded, doll-like angels with mechanical wings that do nothing but watch.
"Surreal Coming-of-Age Anime" (Conductor) by Ashley Flanagan – Although Duke Akira affects distant grace and charm, he rules every aspect of his train with uncanny intensity. His enigmatic obsession encourages a journey that grows darker as the train nears the Shining City. As the conductor manipulates the travelers into surreal, ominous situations, they must decide whether to rebel against his control – and how.
$6000 CAD (reached!)
"Clearly Cursed Trees" (Stops table) by Natalie Ash – Ranging from the almost-mundane to the truly fanatical, these trees have a mystical history explored in the relics left with them, and a strange present that could prove perilous to the unwary. Are they natural or created? Who enacted these strange rituals there and what did they leave behind?
"Shadows on the Tracks" (Events table) by Amelia Gorman – Bats flutter, wolves howl, a full moon rises behind a crumbling garret... attached atop a locomotive? These Events bring the suspense and shadow of a good Gothic novel aboard the train. Unexpected letters, immured oddities, and strange ailments to train cars and passengers alike breed delightful unease and add a stronger sense of place to the train itself.
$7000 CAD (reached!)
"Wayfaring Strangers" (Events table) by Kevin Snow – Inspired by the historic development of the American west, travelers will encounter freighthoppers, attempted robberies, striking workers, and long, rolling landscapes that settlers claimed were barren.
"Folk Horror" (Conductor) by Madeleine Ember – Grimlight is an unsettling horror. A nightmare in a person suit. Low, slow voice; mud seeping from under its collar. It incrementally sheds its disguise. It knows the secrets of this country, and seeks to escort passengers to where the mundane is peeled back, revealing the seriously strange beneath.
$8000 CAD (reached!)
Journeys give heart to the poet and the artist alike; at this level, the number of illustrations in the core rulebook will be doubled, providing further atmosphere and additional oddities to inspire your game.
$13 000 CAD (reached!)
Community copies – We believe in paying good fortune forward. At $13 000 CAD, we'll set aside twelve copies of the Cerebos limited edition hardcover to be donated to libraries, school gaming clubs, and other institutions.
