updates.update_content:
Hello, all! 
Back again for another update--we've got a little bit to talk about, and I've got a lot to show y'all. Since you've been so patient, let's start with dessert!

Sneak Peek: Bayou Vesper

Hey everybody!

I know it's been a while, but I kinda hate it when I Kickstart something and they send me weekly updates that are like "Hey! Nothing new to report, just here to say we haven't run off to a tax haven with all of your money!" I want to make sure we have some stuff to talk about when we bother you. 

And now we do! First up...

CHECK OUT THIS MAP

updates.update_userinfo: Update 6: The End Of A Jaunt, The Start Of A Journey
updates.update_content:
IT IS DONE
Home again! Our humble ship is once again berthed safely in a familiar port (if now lade a bit heavier with plundered riches). We credit you fine folks for bearing us safely through the storms, it was a hell of a ride!

Tired of Zine Quest yet? We get it.  Hopefully this'll be fun rather than taxing. Not much business to attend to, mostly just checking in and showing y'all some new stuff but I did want to go ahead and announce that our map is going to be drawn by our good friend Qwynto!

updates.update_userinfo: Update 4: Stat Cards Are A Go!
updates.update_content:
Alright! Another stretch goal blown through! There's a lot to talk about here, so indulge me if I start with the meat & potatoes. First, the price point/how you get them.

Fifteen bucks is  only very slightly above cost, but we wanted them to be a fun cool thing that we got to do if y'all showed us enough support rather than another way to make more money, and the more folks that say "Yeah I'm willing to pay for that", the better quality we get to make them. There'll be a new pledge tier available right after this update goes up where all physical backers can up their pledge by fifteen bucks to get the cards added in.  Also, if you've pledged at the Denizens level, just know that the new plan is to make the "Bearers of Welcomed Flesh" tier be exactly what you are currently getting PLUS the cards. Turns out this is the only way to get cards and original art as a tier without maybe making Robbie do more sketches than we previously agreed upon.

Hey everybody! 
Been a couple days so time for another update.
Maps!
Hell yeah! We get a real sick map! No news on the artist yet, we're in close talks but we're not quite ready to announce. As far as what it looks like, I think we're closer to reality. There's two main things I wanted from the map. It needed to:

updates.update_userinfo: Update 2: Int'l Shipping, More Sketches, Maps 'n Cards
updates.update_content:
Daaang! 100+ backers, 200% funded & y'all already gobbled up all of Robbie's sketches (for now, more on that below). That's pretty wild.  I guess that deserves an update, huh?

INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING
Alright, so we've got pretty good news here. After a quick chat with the nice lady from the post office, I'm pretty sure we'll be able to ship zines pretty much anywhere for ~$12. We'll be keeping all the large-form original art tiers US shipping only because their size complicates things, but all the other tiers are going international! Pretty Dope.

I guess by the standards of all these crazy folks out there getting funded in 15 minutes and such, 5 hours isn't a giant brag, but still--it's a huge deal to us.

Thank you. We mean it.

There's a few things we need to touch on:

campaign.story:
Foot Trodden by Simon J Woolf & Ryan Opaz
All stretch goals reached! Just €2,000 separates us from the record books (most funded wine publishing project ever on Kickstarter). Will we make it?
What would you think of, if we said the words "Portuguese wine" to you? 
Most people would probably think of something sweet and red (port wine) or a bargain-priced, fizzy white (Vinho Verde).

But Portugal is so much more than just Port wine or cheap Vinho Verde. It's full of exciting and diverse wines, traditions and stories to tell. Yet we're consistently surprised at how few people have penetrated the surface of this rich culture and its vinous treasures.
Maybe that's because there's never been a book that really penetrates the soul of Portuguese wine - a way for other people to fall in love with the country like we did.
We decided it’s time to write that book. 

Foot Trodden will take you on a journey from Portugal’s past to its future and from north to south. Over the last three years, we travelled the entire country to find the most compelling narratives and the winemakers who are putting Portugal on the global map. Now, we want to convey that experience to you, on the page.

We unearthed ancient traditions and winemaking methods (like foot treading) that look like they came from the last century. But we also met dynamic young winemakers who are taking this rich heritage and making it uniquely their own.

For a book to really transport you, it has to connect you with the story. Think of Foot Trodden more like a novel, less like a text-book. But while words are important, images convey emotions. So with a photogenic country like Portugal, we’ve included a generous number of Ryan's specially taken photos to provide you with the ultimate armchair travel experience.
Beautiful organic vineyards at Vadio, Bairrada
Foot Trodden is our second collaboration. We crowdfunded our first book, Amber Revolution - How the world learned to love orange wine, right here on Kickstarter - and it’s become one of the most successful wine books ever to launch from this platform.

Not only did we deliver Amber Revolution on time and on budget, it also got top billing in the New York Times and won a coveted Roederer wine writing award. It's been translated into five different languages and is about to be reprinted for the third time.
Will you help us make Foot Trodden an even bigger success?
 WHY ARE WE CROWDFUNDING? 
Self publishing and crowdfunding allows us to have a direct link with you, our audience, and we believe that results in a better book. This model gives us far more creative and editorial control, so we can deliver the book that we know Portugal deserves.

Foot Trodden isn’t just for wine fans. It’s a book about Portugal and its history, seen through the lens of wine.  We've put together the same crack team of designers and editors who brought you Amber Revolution, to ensure that it's a beautifully designed book too - one that you can't resist picking up and browsing, before settling in for a good read.
If you missed the opportunity to travel in 2020, Foot Trodden will help fill that gap, from the comfort and safety of your home.

For the wine-geeks amongst you, we haven't stinted on the technical information though! There's plenty of detail on the wines and the winemaking methods.
Foot Trodden is for you whether you are wine curious or wine expert.
Excerpt from Chapter 2 - Dão (click to enlarge)
THE REWARDS
When you support this project, you'll be one of the first people on the planet to get this book in your hands (way before the official publication date). And every supporter gets their name printed in the acknowledgements section of the book, as an extra special thank you.
There are some special treats on offer. We’ll be hosting an exclusive luxury tour of Portugal’s Alentejo wine region in November 2021 (travel restrictions permitting). We’ll take you into the vineyards with the winemakers to taste and discover the real Portugal for yourself.
Our handpainted 'azulejo' tile with the Foot Trodden motif
Don't miss the custom made azulejo-style tile. It's the perfect memento that you helped make this book happen, and a link to another of Portugal's artisan traditions. These tiles are being manufactured and hand-painted for us specially for this project
The tile features our foot treading motif from the front cover design. PLEASE NOTE - as the tile is hand-painted, you may notice small variations between the sample design shown above and the final item. This can include slight colour variations as this is a handmade item.
Mockup showing the framed art print
We love art prints, so we decided to make a super limited edition based on the book's front cover design. There are only (and will only ever be) 50 of these babies and they are gorgeous: Hand numbered and printed on heavy 300 gram archival paper, using the giclée technique to ensure they will last for many decades. You won't be disappointed, your walls will love you.
Foot Trodden - Fine art print (image)
We're also offering a high quality 100% organic cotton T-shirt with our stylised tile design. You can select your size and cut at the end of the campaign!
T-shirt front (logo) and back (text)
We will give you the chance to add additional rewards to your pledge, before the campaign ends. So if you decide you want to add an extra book or a T-shirt, we'll make it possible.

If you'd like a larger quantity of the book, or any other customised reward bundle, please contact us and we'll make it happen.
 WHAT'S IN THE BOOK 
Through eight chapters and roughly 250 pages, Foot Trodden takes you on a journey from north to south, from the past to the future. The diversity of characters, landscapes and wines will have you salivating for your next bottle of Portuguese wine - and dreaming of the moment when you visit these historic winemaking regions.
Some examples:
Meet a Parisian with Portuguese heritage, who almost has a nervous breakdown as he tries to breath new life into century-old abandoned vineyards in the Dão.
An art teacher discovers a love of wine via his meetings with a Buddhist monk, and decides to grow grapes in the wettest part of Portugal, following Steiner’s biodynamic philosophy.
A winemaker near Lisbon keeps a unique medieval wine style alive, even though it took 20 years to convince the EU to give it legal status.
In the Alentejo, a secret society thrives in several small villages where a clay pot winemaking tradition lifts the lid on 2,000 years of history. 
Professor Arlindo - a leading talha winemaker and his winemaker daughter Teresa
Excerpt from Chapter 2 - Alentejo (click to enlarge)

WHAT'S THE MONEY FOR?
Our funding goal of €9,900 will cover the first printing of Foot Trodden. If we only raise this amount, we will fund additional costs (design, editing and layout) from other sources including our own pockets. Our core project costs total €18,500.
If we're able to raise additional funds thanks to your generous support, we can scale up various aspects of the project - including doing a larger first print run.
When budgeting, we've taken a range of factors into account, including the fees and taxes that we need to pay on any amounts that we fundraise, and additional costs such as packaging materials and shipping from the printer to our fulfilment centre.
STRETCH GOALS
 #1 > EUR 12,000 - Goal reached!
We want Foot Trodden to be just as beautiful as Portugal itself.
Portugal is all about handmade crafts and old traditions, and we want to express that on the book's cover. With a bit more budget, we'll use techniques such as a linen-weave hardback cover or embossing to add texture and interest.
Extra spot colours and varnishing will also be used to lift the design.
With your help, we can make this book a work of art, as well as a fantastic read.

 #2 > EUR 17,500 - Goal reached!
There's an amazing wine story on the island of Madeira - and we'd like to include it in Foot Trodden.
When the pandemic hit, all our plans for research in 2020 were delayed. Right now, we don't have the material we'd need to include a chapter about Madeira in the book, but we strongly believe it deserves to be included.
We're hopeful that we can travel to Madeira just before our print, layout and design deadlines, but it involves a number of additional costs - travel, accommodation, and the additional work on photography and layout for one more chapter.

#3 > EUR 25,000 - Goal reached!
Not just a book, also a podcast
We met so many amazing winemakers with stories to tell, and there is a wealth of material that won't fit in one book. So, this stretch goal will allow us to create, edit and publish a podcast featuring in-depth interviews with many inspirational winemakers and growers. Plus you can listen in to our discussions and find out how our ideas about Portugal and its wine developed.
The Foot Trodden podcast series (six episodes) will be available exclusively to Kickstarter supporters on its initial release.

 #4  > EUR 40,000 *NEW*
Feast your eyes over the whole of Portugal on a fold-out map
There was always going to be a map or two in this book, but if we get to this level of funding, we're going to make it a whole lot slicker. We envisage a three-panel fold-out full-colour map, depicting all the regions in Portugal that are covered in the book.
For practical reasons, the map will show you Portugal in a horizontal format, similar to this antique example - looking up towards the Atlantic.
We have a designer lined up to create our re-imagining of this beautiful vintage map, clearly depicting all the wine regions and signposting the stories in the book.
 #5  > EUR 45,000
An exclusive web portal listing all our recommended wineries
We're constantly discovering new winery projects and promising winemakers. We can't squeeze them all into the book, and we didn't want to create a gazetteer-type of section, because it would be out-of-date by the time we go to print.
So instead we'll create an exclusive website, with access just for subscribers (that's you!), which lists all the wonderful winemakers whose wines we like to drink, together with information, contact and visiting details. This website will be part of the same platform that hosts our podcasts.
If you have a copy of our previous book, Amber Revolution, this will be a bit like the back-section of that book, but online and thus way more dynamic.
It's the perfect resource if you're planning a trip to Portugal, and we'll update it as we go along. 

 #6  > EUR 50,000
Record breakers!
If we reach this level, we just became the most-funded wine publishing project on Kickstarter *ever* (topping out the amazing effort from Steve de Long's wine maps of the world project in 2019). This would mean so much, because of the profile that we can give to Portugal - and the message it sends out that people care about this wonderful wine nation.
THE SCHEDULE
We've been researching this book since 2018, and we're more than halfway with writing and photo editing. Here's how the schedule will unfold in 2021:
 WHO WE ARE 
Simon J Woolf is a British wine writer and author, currently based in Amsterdam. He is known as a specialist on topics such as natural wine, organic and biodynamic winemaking. Simon has written about Portugal for Punch, Decanter and Catavino amongst many others. He is the founder and editor of The Morning Claret, and is widely published internationally.
Ryan Opaz is an American based in Porto, and has been writing about and photographing the wines of Portugal and Spain for the past 15 years. Founder of the award winning wine blog Catavino.net and CEO of Catavino Tours, he now spends his time guiding travellers to the hidden culinary and vinous treasures of Portugal.
 OUR PREVIOUS WORK
We collaborated on Amber Revolution - How the world learned to love orange wine which was published in 2018.

Today we'd like to share a bit of the product development process for the ceramic tile that we're producing. The idea behind this tile was not only to create a truly unique reward for backers, but also to celebrate another of Portugal's artisanal traditions beyond wine.
Azulejo is the predominantly Portuguese style of tiling, distinct from the Spanish alhambra tradition. Azulejo tiles often tell a story, and are frequently more than just abstract motifs. The name itself comes from the colour blue ('azul' in Portuguese) - and the typical sky-blue colour is what you'll most often see.

campaign.story:
Today I went for a nice long walk. I saw a bunch of crows that aren’t usually in this neighbourhood. I made sage and rose tea when I got home… that always puts me in a good place. And in the evening I got a call from an old friend. It was so nice to catch up. Not a perfect day, but beautiful, and in ways I wasn’t expecting.
So, how did that happen to Frogsworth?

Precious Little Animal is a one-player game about noticing the good things in your life, and sharing them with an imaginary animal friend.
The cover of the Precious Little Animal zine

How it Plays
Play for 15-30 minutes, at the end of each day, for seven days.

In Precious Little Animal, you’ll take a few minutes at the end of the day to reflect on what happened that day: what you did, what you’ll remember, and what you enjoyed. At the same time, you’ll be writing a story about a cute little animal. You’ll take a few things that happened to you each day, and have them happen to your animal, too.

Make a little animal friend.

On the first day, you’ll write about (or draw!) a little animal. On each day you’re playing, you’ll write down three good things that happened that day. Then you’ll figure out how those things happened to your animal. Maybe your call with a friend was a visit from a friendly Raccoon. Maybe your hour of uninterrupted work time was their quiet hour in the vegetable garden. Maybe your moment of noticing just how blue and clear the sky can be happened just the same way to them.

Your journal of your own life will also be a record of theirs.

In my experience, this practice of writing three good things has become more difficult during times of intense suffering and uncertainty - but also more vital and more satisfying. I hope that through this simple week of journaling, players will share my experience of being more attuned to moments of contentment, and find simple joys glittering and urgent like shards of glass in the dirt.

What People Are Saying
"I had a lovely video call with 3 friends, and she had an owl, a hedgehog and a snake over for tea. I had a quiet night, and the mouse stargazed and wished on a shooting star. Precious Little animal helped me see goodness in my own life that I otherwise may have skipped over or forgotten." - Jenn Martin, game designer, and Production Manager for Bully Pulpit Games

"Precious Little Animal has been my treasured nighttime companion for the last week. Each night I get a chance to not only reflect on what I'm grateful for, but also to see those things through the lens of my animal, both interrogating and expanding on the source of my joy." - Sean Nittner, game designer, Big Bad Con organizer, Actual Play host, and project director for Evil Hat Productions

"There is something unquestionably wholesome and cozy about searching for the good things in your life with the aid of an an adorable animal avatar. I recommend taking the time to introduce yourselves to them and seeing your good fortune through their eyes." - Colin Young, playtester

"Playing this game was a gentle, consistent reminder to be sincere with myself." -  Sandbank Diner, playtester

"I felt really happy after playing." - baimo, playtester

What’s Included
This game is meant to be simple, accessible, and friendly, whether you love role-playing games or have never tried one before.
So it’s a 6x9” 24-page zine, printed in black and white on recycled paper, and stapled together. If, like me, you learned about everything from comics and music to sexual health and queer history from photocopied b&w zines, I think you’ll love it.
Zine Quest is about reminding ourselves that making games doesn’t necessarily mean years of development and production; sometimes you get a good idea down on paper and share it with the people who’ll love it. For that reason, this is a very simple product. I’m working with my campus printer to put some black ink on recycled paper, and that’s it. All the illustrations and text were done by hand in about a week. I loved making this game.

The Digital Edition:
With a PDF copy of Precious Little Animal, you can read along on your screen, and make a play journal in a separate notebook or document. 
INCLUDES:
Digital Edition (PDF)
ESTIMATED DELIVERY: April 2021
The screen version of the PDF - you can use this on your computer, tablet, or phone to read through the game page by page.
The Print Edition:
All print backers will get the PDF version. In addition, you'll get one 24-page, 6x9" staple-bound copy of Precious Little Animal. With that, and a pen or pencil, you can start playing right away.
INCLUDES:
Digital Edition (PDF)
Print Edition (Black & White Printed Zine)
ESTIMATED DELIVERY: July 2021
*NEW* Print for Two:
All print backers will get the PDF version. In addition, you'll get TWO 24-page, 6x9" staple-bound copies of Precious Little Animal. With that, and a pen or pencil, you and a friend can start playing right away.
INCLUDES:
Digital Edition (PDF)
2x Print Edition (Black & White Printed Zine)
ESTIMATED DELIVERY: July 2021

Shipping
Print copies will be shipped out via Canada Post Lettermail.
When you make your pledge, you’ll be asked to select a shipping cost - it’s $2 CAD for backers living in Canada, and $3 CAD for everyone else. Pretty simple! Because of the size and weight of this zine, I can ship it out inexpensively - but that means it may take a longer time than you might be used to.
Backers in Canada should have their games within 2-3 weeks. Backers in the United States may need to wait up to a month. Backers in other countries may have to wait up to three months. If you’re worried about this, get in touch with me and we can talk through the details more fully.

Keeping it Simple
This game is done.
It’s a beautiful pile of paper, at the moment. It’s been playtested and enjoyed by enough people - including myself - that I’m totally happy to send it out the door right now. The purpose of this Kickstarter campaign is to fund the print run and shipping, and hopefully get the game to more people than would have known about it otherwise.
So it’ll stay simple. I hereby promise: no printing upgrades, no expansions, no merchandise. No stretch goals of any kind! In the true spirit of #ZineQuest, I just want to get this thing into your hands as quickly as possible.

About Me
Precious Little Animal was written and illustrated by Alex Roberts. Alex makes games, writes fiction and nonfiction, tweets too much, researches the applications of game-making to expressive arts therapy, and loves a little toast and tea in the morning. You might have heard her podcast Backstory, or played some of her games, like Star Crossed, For the Queen, Hero Dog Saves Town, or POP!. She’s contributed to dozens of other games, worked in game production for Bully Pulpit Games and Pelgrane Press, and offered workshops and presentations about game-making around the world. 

Thanks
BIG thanks to all my playtesters: Eva, Colin Young, Sean Nittner, Kelley Vanda, Aaron Damon-Rush, Jenn Martin, Sandbank Diner, baimo. I am also indebted to Jenn and Steve for their feedback, and to Paul, who generously gave me a handful of printer paper when I ran upstairs a few weeks ago, loudly demanding some - this game might not have gotten started without you.

And oh my gosh if you’re still reading this: thank you for checking out this project!! Remember that if you can’t back the KS, that’s totally cool: telling your friends about it, or sharing on your social media channels, is a big help I also deeply appreciate!

If you’re as stoked about this game as I am, or have any questions or anything, contact me and let’s chat! helloalexroberts@gmail.com

This is my first solo Kickstarter, which is one of the reasons I’m keeping this as simple and straightforward is possible.

PRINTING
I am stoked to be working with Zap Copy, the print shop run by my local student union. I’ve worked with them before and they how to print on spec, deliver on time, and keep communications open. Absolute pros! 

FULFILLMENT
Once zines are done, I’ll be stuffing them into envelopes with all your lovely names on them, and sending them out via Canada Post. Shipping times may be longer than you are used to (less than a month for Canadian addresses, about a month for USA addresses, and 1-3 months for other countries), but you’ll be kept informed every step of the way.

TRANSPARENCY
Most importantly, I’ll be providing backer updates throughout the printing and shipping process. If anything does go wrong, you’ll know right away what’s up and how I’m going to fix it.

I’m always here for feedback and questions!

campaign.story:
Where the Wheat Grows Tall is an old-school fantasy adventure for low level characters inspired by Slavic myth. Deeper than a dungeon crawl, this adventure is filled with personalities and relationships boiling beneath the surface. Cross the old stone wall and discover a different world that follows different rules in twenty keyed locations.
The Abandoned Farmland
The adventure begins at the abandoned farm of the Polotnikov family. Spirits linger, and signs point to power beyond the wall. From here, players can choose from a variety of goals or entrances, weighing history for themselves.
The Noon Lady & The Midnight Maiden
The far side of the wall is governed by two ancient fey: The Noon Lady & The Midnight Maiden. Once wild spirits, then bound local gods, their idols now decay, forgotten behind forbidden fields. There they would quietly lay, but love and greed have upset the quiet balance and the Noon Lady reigns tall with scorching dominion.
The Field
The field beyond the wall is a mystery to explore, full of simple encounters and locations to draw the party deeper into the field, both literally and figuratively. Entreat with the ghosts of old wars, explore the rootbound tunnels of the Poleviks, or befriend Trull, the timid troll guarding the field’s solitary bridge.
 The Zine
For Zine Quest, Where The Wheat Grows Tall will be printed  in a black & white digest format (5,5 x 8,5) and will feature over twenty black & white illustrations by Evlyn Moreau.  Stat blocks will be written to be compatible with old school game systems.
Writing, testing, and editing are complete. Our plans for layout, printing, and distribution expect to deliver the PDF in May and the printed zine in June.
The Team
 Evlyn Moreau - Art & Writing

 Dai Shugars, GMDK - Layout
 Exalted Funeral, Monkey’s Paw Games - Fulfillment
The authors: Evlyn and Camilla

International customers can get copies of the zine by backing at a special PDF tier. When zines have printed, you’ll get a discount code to pay for a reserved copy. You’ll get the PDF at the same time as other backers and your shipping cost will be accurate to your specific location.

campaign.story:
Okay folks, there was a time in my life when I was all about zines.  I still love the things but hate figuring out how to store 'em.  From where I write this I can see a giant tub of zines dating back to the 80s and 90s, and shelves awkwardly stuffed with game and art zines.   Silkscreened and risograph zines just put me over the moon.  
Zine making, though, sort of fell away.  I made a zine as part of an artwork at Socrates Sculpture Park in NYC.  But it's not something I do anymore.  Why not?  WHY?  
Okay, I will.  I will make a zine.  I want to do this.  I am excited. 


(three hours pass) 


I Made a Zine
And I am zining the fuck out of this zine.  
Back in my day, I hoarsely declaim while waving my cane, zines were quick and dirty and often embarrassingly personal.  Inside that majestic blue tub there is a possibly -infinite- number of diary zines detailing the random thoughts of punk rock teenagers in small towns in the midwest.  And that, THAT, that is what I am decanting into this thing I am making you.
It's a zine that I never made back when I was in high school, a fantastic imagining of what I might've done.  And it's a game.   A game for three players.  
Nay, not just a game, a simulator.  A teenaged Tim Hutchings almost-virtual-reality experience in which you and your two brave companions  (I am actually choking with laughter as I write this) get to be me for an evening.  And I tell you how to play D&D, among other things.  In fact, the name for this zine was originally Tim Hutchings Tell You How to Play AD&D because it's true and it's an homage to Rodney Anonymous Tells You How to Live, a music program hosted by the lead singer of the Dead Milkmen--my favorite band at the time described in this zine.  
There's a Gimmick?
This zine is being printed in three colors--red, blue, and yellow and the colors that blur in between.  It will come with three pieces of plastic gel--red, blue, and green.  When you hold a plastic piece to your eye you will experience ZINE MAGIC as the colors are, more or less, separated out and hidden drawings emerge!  Complementary colors turn black and the others (mostly) disappear.  Magic.
So the top image here is the opening page spread in the zine.  The three images below it are the same spread viewed through different colors of plastic.  I took these photos of the screen through a piece of plastic.  These are early test photos and I've improved the system since then.
I'll say this again in a different way:  There'll be a mess of blue, red, and yellow lines, look at the pages through various colors of plastic and some lines will disappear while others emerge.  PLAYERS SEE DIFFERENT INFORMATION ON THE SAME PAGE THROUGH THE COMBINATION OF MAGIC AND SCIENCE THAT IS COLOR THEORY.  LIKE THIS.
FYI this was stupidly hard to figure out, even with the groundwork laid down by Carnovsky and other sources.  I 
Disclaimer:  This is going to work, more or less.  The blues are pretty dark and you'll need a bright place to play.   But it should work.  But maybe it will fail?  Probably not.  

This is one of the three colored layers that make up one page spread.
Are There Two Gimmicks?
Sort of.  Maybe the second isn't a gimmick so much as a stance.  This is a zine in concept and making.
This isn't really a gimmick as much as my commitment to the format:  I don't know if this zine is any good.  I am making it in character and that character is me.  I'm channeling young Tim and, to be frank, young Tim was an idiot.  He makes dull old Tim look like a genius.  
Zines are messy, they are poorly thought out, mistakes are fixed with white out and anger and the anger gets worse because the white out wasn't given enough time to dry and fuck I've ruined my pen.  Zines are shat out quickly and you don't look at it because it's gross, you just stuff it all into envelopes and mail it to other people like yourself and get things sent to you in return.
This zine is messy, its poorly thought out.  I had no white out so I only had anger to fix mistakes with and that doesn't work at all.  
I sat down and wrote this zine in two or three hours, starting at 11pm.  I was bleary and confused by the end.  I worked like a teenager whose about to lose his access to free copies when his buddy goes off shift in half an hour.  
In short, it's a zine being a zine.
Are You Being Some Sort of Elitist Grump About What Zines Are?
No!  Well, yes, but NO.   I'm telling you what zines mean to -me- and what games mean to -me-, and how my experience within the medium affects what I am making for you right now. 
But for me a zine is something different.  The word 'zine' fires my blood in a way that ain't like most other folks making things here.   I don't want anyone to be disappointed because the thing I'm delivering has fundamentally different goals than  most of the ZineQuest 3 projects.
Okay, Okay, Give Some Specifics.
Okay, I guess I can do that.  
You're getting THREE digest-sized, sixteen page zines (they are all the same zine).  It'll be full color, probably printed by McNaughton Gunn--those are the same folks that printed Thousand Year Old Vampire.
You'll get three small squares of plastic with the zine which will allow the eyeball magic to emerge.  Probably they'll come in a little envelope that'll be tucked into the zine.  
This is a sort of game for three players.
I am timing this so that the zine will come out of the printer at the same time as the secret TYOV companion book.
UPDATE:  In the interest of gaming on the cusp of post-covid I am providing THREE copies of the zine to Kickstarter backers.  That way you don't have to hunker around one book and breath up each other's air.  You're still only getting one pack of plastic viewing bits though.
Secret TYOV companion book?  
Yes, it's an add-on you can get when you Kickstart this project.  You'll also be able to pre-order it through the regular thousandyearoldvampire.com site.  Let's maybe talk about that in the faq or something.  
So There Are Add-ons and Stuff?
Yeah, that's new to me to.  Kickstarter has it set up now so that you pledge for a reward tier and then there are add-ons that should appear beneath the pledge.  You can add on copies of Thousand Year Old Vampire, the companion book, some pins (including a new one!) , and another zine game I'd made.  
Again, while one person is seeing this image the other two players are seeing coexisting images that are completely different.
All Right Then, So Tell Us About The Game.
Can't you just trust me?  No?  Well, that's sensible I guess.  
The game is pretty light.  Three players peer through their plastic pieces and see information that is unique to their colored piece of plastic, more or less.  The players tell the story of a slightly idealized, barely remembered amalgam of summer evenings of youthful freedom when I could drive but still have no responsibilities.  And I go play AD&D with friends.  
You negotiate the story together, each player operating from a different body of information.  You might find a use for dice for part of the game, but they aren't required. The authorial voice in the zine flickers between the viewpoint of Young Tim, the memories of Old Tim, and a sort of dispassionate aping of zine makers I've absorbed into my being.  
Is That Really A Game?
Oh don't be that fucker.  I mean, it doesn't really have rules or goals or even a real structure but neither do zines.   There's just an amorphous knowledge of how it works, an arc of excitement and disappointment.  
Couldn't This Just Be Three Separate Booklets?
Oh jeez, you're right.  I, uh, guess that it wouldn't be as clever?  
Actually no, I'm going to double-down on the color thing.  It's important to the structure of the experience that you are given a messiness of information blended together on a single page and each player looks at that mess through a different lens and pulls out strings of meaning.  It's like a memory, which this game is about.  And it's like being a person who is a child and an adult and smart and an idiot all at once, flickering constantly between states as you move between different social spaces and nodes of responsibility.
But I guess that'll be the PDF format.  Three separate PDFs, one for each player to allow online or print-and-play.
Were You Serious About This Being Made Quickly Or Is That A Fake Authenticity Thing?
The authenticity and roughness of the work process on this is me being true to my own understanding of what zines do in the world.  It's also me working off some of the hyperpolished perfection of that vampire game.  
It's an homage to John Porcellino, Funkapotamus, punk zines, and all the little diary zines with drawings of suburban landscapes that I do so love.
Anything Else We Should Know?
I'm excited about this!
And don't poke yourself in the eye with the corner of a piece of plastic.   Seriously.  Do this at your own risk.   Wear safety glasses or something.   I'm going to put that on the book, no shit.
You Should Probably Say Who You Are.
Oh, yeah.  My name is Tim Hutchings.  I'm a game maker and a college professor and used to be a reasonably accomplished fine arts guy.  If you are here you probably know the game Thousand Year Old Vampire--I made that.  It won four big awards and I'm very proud of it.

Risks and challenges
I think I have this one under control. I'm working with a trusted printer, a very competent fulfillment shop, and have enough back up money to patch over any awkwardness. 

The bits of plastic are the only outlier here. I'm working with a lighting company here in town to get the gels matched exactly (they have a special gel scanner, of all things). The gels are expensive but not that pricey once they are cut down to small pieces. 

I'm feeling pretty good about this, folks.

If I was looking for failure points I'd be afraid that something might be screwy with the gels (I'm working with recommended pros), that there is some color error with the printer (they are super competent), or that there is some idiotic layout error (the printer is good at catching this stuff, but there are bound to be some tiny issues that are my fault). 

I think it'll work, though.

campaign.story:
Menagerie of the Void is a storytelling game for one player.
You play as the keeper of an ancient menagerie, created by a long-gone society and still operating. You create the story as you play, writing down some details, deciding how to care for the exhibits, and drawing cards to see what happens next. 
It takes about an hour to play, using a booklet/PDF of about 22 A5 pages, a bunch of index cards, and a deck of regular playing cards.
You are the pilot of humanity's 2nd faster-than-light ship, reaching into interstellar space, ready to explore the great, dark unknown. 
Something malfunctioned. The stars are wrong. And through the window you can see an old, dusty planet, from which a beam of light emerges to engulf your ship, and an alien presence integrates with your systems. Your gut lurches as you lose and regain consciousness—now you are standing in a hall of groaning, rusty engines, a dead creature lying on the floor before you, old and dry. 
A burst of pain as a metallic arm retreats from your head, having implanted a cybernetic module in your brain. Through it, these old automated systems speak to you:  
This is the story of how you were compelled to try and eventually failed, as many have before you. 
Main inspirations are the episode “Stewtopia” of Voyage to the Stars and Weird Worlds: Return to Infinite Space. If you are familiar with some indie games, this plays on similar vibes to those of The Wretched or Mothership, but you manage a sad zoo.
First you Discover the Grounds by drawing borders on some index cards (the blocks of your zoo) and randomly laying them in four-by-four grid. 
Another Cycle Begins, and a new exhibit might arrive at the menagerie; you'll create this strange organism, then guide the machines to assemble a habitat for it.
Then, Problems Pile Up: Draw a playing card to see what happens. A lot can happen. Answer provocative questions to create some weird fiction. 
Then, Do Your Part, to try and gain some control over this mess. 
Then, Another Cycle Begins… 
You start with one control and try to get more, but fail, as deviancy increases relentlessly. Eventually either you gain 5 control or the last block is destroyed, and It All Ends. 
Managed by me, Eran (@nnesk), best known for the webcomic Crystal Heart and its successfully Kickstarted RPG, as well as for editing the (also successfully Kickstarted) RPG of legendary noir investigations, City of Mist. I am part-time editor and game designer (portfolio), and my work was featured by Goodman Games, Mongoose Publishing and En5ider.  I'm a 40yo straight-ish skeptic cis male, London based ex-Israeli, happily-forever-GM. I try to know the world and leave it better than I got it.
Graphic design and logo by Vee Hendro (@Rocketeer_Vee).
Monstrous art by Michael Malkin (@Ronamis_), Jaime Mosquera (@elsombreronart), Lord Zsezse Works (lordzsezseworks.com), Angela Quidam D (@quidamangela)
Editing and design consultation by Mitchell Salmon (@MQSalmon) and Jonathon Boyle (@ResidentBard)
Using advice from Uri Lifshitz, Aviv M. Icel, Simon Brake, Matheus Sant’Anna, Marx Shepherd and my wife Dassi Elber-Aviram. 
Mostly to pay for the people above. Printing and shipping takes about a quarter of the budget. The game itself is done and playtested. 
Is there a stretch goal?
At £3,800 ($5,260) I'll have the money to fully develop the The Zoo Management Game (placeholder name), a spin off based on the "engine" of Menagerie, which should feel like Theme Park meets Pokemon. It should be about managing visitors and giving them a great experience, attracting more visitors, and handling fun and weird exhibits.
If it happens, all backers will get this game in PDF, no printed version planned.
Was there another stretch goal?
Since we passed £2,800 (about $3,800), I'm able to order an original audio piece several minutes long, like a theme music for the game, which will be given to all backers. I'll also build a public hour-long playlist which includes this and other suitable pieces, to listen to in the background as you play. 
Can I get another physical copy?
Yes, just add £5 on your PDF & Print pledge, and contact me (through Kickstarter, in a tweet or in an email). My details are on the top right, and I'm very approachable! 
How does shipping work?
I'll be sending everything from my home (London, UK). It's a thin envelope and costs are expected to be low, so I believe any Brexit disruptions or taxes should be low as well.
What are the Pre-Weird reward options?
Creating your own strange alien organism is part of the fun, and the game provides you with provocative questions and inspirations. But maybe it's the end of a long work day, and you don't have it in you to imagine some new stuff right now, and you just want to push a few crazy beasts into the game and see what happens. 
Backers who invest in a pre-weird option will get twelve unusual organisms pre-weirded, for your use. The organisms include name and description, and they'll be sent by email or Kickstarter message, after the PDF is delivered.
And the Personal Oddities? 
These backers get the 12 pre-weird organisms along with six additional bizarre creations, unique to them. That is, I write each group of six exhibits for each backer, not replicated. There might be a few repeating tentacles, but that's the nature of void zoology, I guess.
What is Zine Quest?
Menagerie of the Void is a #ZineQuest project; this is Zine Quest.

updates.update_content:
Hello all! 
The "expandalone" continuation of Menagerie of the Void is currently in development. I hope it'll be finished by the end of July, at which point all backers will get the PDF (not with the same high-quality level of layout, I'm afraid).
If you'd like to take a peek, I'm being quite open with the design process - here's the game! It's pre-alpha, not even ready for a playtest, barely suitable for reading, so I would only recommend you look at it if you're curious to see how things are developing. Please note that a lot of the text is rough, still in draft quality. Much of it is phrased in strange ways, because it's just thought-dump (and my mind was elsewhere, I've written this while also watching Dropout's Mice & Murder).

That's it, all of the physical zines are on their way to you.
If it doesn't arrive in two weeks, contact me - and a replacement shall be arranged! 

You also should have received an email from itch.io, with your unique key for the game, allowing you to keep the copy with your itch account, if you have any. If you didn't get it, check yer spam or message me!

Thank you everyone for funding this game, it's been a great experience for me. I would to hear about your game sessions, or even just your general thoughts about the game - I'm a creator, I live and die on feedback. I would appreciate any review you leave on itch (there's a button to the right of the screen; you'll need to add the game to your collection with the key link, first), including unfavourable ones - it's a good way to learn for next time.

A hundred people among you - let it be known that the game is on its way! 
About a hundred more - later this week or early next week!
Happily, this is all proceeding according to plan. The next step, aimed for mid-summer, is the variant game - Fun Happy Zoo Pokemon Theme Park Name To Be Changed Later.

Happily, the prolonged process of getting proofs and prints is finally coming to an end so tomorrow midday (London) I'm locking addresses - if you moved home or otherwise changed address, now is the time to change your survey answer (or give it in the first place, if you haven't yet; check your emails and spams from Kickstarter). 
Shipping next week!

campaign.story:
You’re gonna play a professional killer attending the 20th high school reunion of the Class of '99. It also happens to be your 20th reunion. Unbeknownst to you, there are seven other professional killers in attendance. You will mingle and reminisce, and then, when the time’s right, you’ll decide if you’re ready to pull the trigger (or draw your sword or whatever.)
Pressure Drop is a one-shot larp (about 2-4 hours long) in the American Freeform tradition that explores what happens when people who do terrible things have to face those who knew them best. It's inspired by the film Grosse Pointe Blank though you needn't be familiar with that movie to enjoy the game.
Playing Pressure Drop 
Here's how play goes:
Before the game the facilitator will read through the game and familiarize themselves with the game, the workshop, and the safety tools. Then they'll prep the play materials (printing some stuff out, cutting a few things out, making a playlist, finding a stapler.)
Then everyone gets together and gets ready to play. This means going over the safety rules to make sure everyone is taken care of (people are more important than the game!) and doing a little Action Sequence workshop to practice what it means to perform combat in this game (see below!)
Then everyone gets together and makes their characters. There are eight assassin archetypes. I will not be stretch-goaling to a ninth assassin archetype. If I think of another one before the zine goes to the printer I'll include it. If you have an archetype you think I should include please send it to me and I won't even charge you more to include it if it's a good idea. Wow what a magnanimous game designer. If I don't think it's a good idea please don't cancel your pledge. You can also just hack it in there later, I have literally no control over what you do with this game once it's in your hands. Wow pretty scary stuff!
Okay anyway then after you pick your archetype there's a sorta mad-libs-style character creation to generate your backstory (who you were in high school, who you have fond memories of, etc. etc.) this is collaborative and fun (people have told me it's fun if it's not fun please don't ask for a refund of your pledge.) You also find out who your target is (it's another player's secret identity.) You also find out what is Your Song while this song is playing you'll have to confess your secret identity to someone. Hope they're not also an assassin (they are.)
Then there's a bit of introduction to the game and you start playing! It's almost as awkward as a real reunion, you get to see people you haven't seen before! Lie about who you are and what you've been doing with your life! Try to grab a bit of the fleeting emotion of the last time you were truly seen before your shitty job and lack of meaningful human connection ground you down to a thin paste! Typical reunion shit!
Then you maybe get to try to kill each other.
Then the game is over!
Since the character generation is random, you could in theory play this game infinity times. At that price you can't afford not to buy this game! In all seriousness though I've facilitated this game like five times and it's still a blast.
Action Sequence
One of the cool things about this game is at the end you get to decide if you want to partake in a action sequence to try to take out your target. Or maybe you decide not to or maybe you decide to just try to protect your best friend who you haven't seen in twenty years TWENTY YEARS!
I was inspired by Evan Torner's Hell is Other Vampires for the low-speed/turn-based action sequence he devised to capture a bit of strategy without bogging the game down with a ton of rules. 
The effect is a little bit of kids playing pretend (I get you with my sword! I shoot you with my SMG!) but wrapped in just enough game to let you think strategically. The playtest materials are available on itch pwyw if you're interested in checking them out.
The Zine
I'm keeping this simpler than My Jam (which by the way we did before the first zinequest so if you think about it something something.) My goal with the layout is that you can just open up the staples and play if you want, or print the pdf or make copies or whatever.
Unless this super blows up I'll be printing at home on a laser printer on French paper. Maybe the cover will be like neon green or something. I've been really into neon green lately. If this super blows up I'll find a printer to work with.
I also wanna have some art! I think it's a nice little addition to the physical zine, and I love working with awesome artists! This art will only appear in the physical zine!
For this project, I'm working with Filipa Namorado an illustrator with a background in graphic design whose work is informed by shoujo manga and mid-century children’s literature. They are passionate about fashion, gender and sexuality, having written and illustrated their own picture book about gender diversity. Here are some of the early sketches they've sent over of the eight character archetypes:
Design Process
I watched Grosse Pointe Blank like a hundred times. Not really as part of the design process just because it's a brilliant film. It's so funny and violent and the soundtrack kicks fucking ass.
Then Jeff and I wrapped up My Jam and I was adrift with no design projects, so this kinda trickled in. You can probably see the relationship to My Jam. Both have music, both have high school.
Then I wrote up some playtest materials and tried it out at Dreamation 2019. Got some good feedback, made a few small changes, then ran it again at Big Bad Con 2019. Then we stopped being able to do larps because of a global pandemic. Come to think of it why am I kickstarting a larp in the middle of a global pandemic. Anyway. Please ignore that and back my project anyway. I'm sure we'll be back to mingling with strangers in no time haha nervous laughter.
Anyway the game is done. I don't plan to keep designing. I might edit the copy a bit from what's available on itch, but mostly I just need to do a print layout of the game as it exists.
I wrote down a bit of my iterative process on my itch devlog for the game. If you want more insight check it out!

Hey everyone! Things are going pretty well over here! I just got the final cover art from Filipa and wanted to share it with you all!

Hey everyone! Thank you so much for your support! I'm so thrilled to be able to bring this larp to you all especially in physical form!!!
As a treat I wanted to give you all a peek into the characters of the game (or at least the assassin personalities.) campaign.story:
Apothecaria is a solo journalling RPG in which you take the role of a village witch creating potions for the unfortunate villagers, adventurers, and monsters that come to you for help. The potions you create and the stories that unfold come together to create a beautiful journal that is unique and personal to you. Fill pages with drawings of ingredients, stories of run-ins with thieving fairies and sleeping giants, and recipes for the potions you have created to keep you right in the future.
With loads of unique ailments like Fairy Fever, Candlesick, and Yeti Chest, Apothecaria aims to capture the humour and feel of games like Theme Hospital and Stardew Valley with the cosiness and wonder of Studio Ghibli films.

Backing at the Physical level gets you:
A beautiful A5 copper-foil titled 56 page zine
5 thematic postcards featuring art by Adam "Forange" Törn 
2 postcard minigames about the secret life of Familiars and making Wands
3 A6 expansions featuring Ailments and Reagents by Chris Bissette (The Wretched, D36), Matt Sanders (Sealed Library), and Jack Harrisson (Artefact, Bucket of Bolts)
A potion sticker
And we've unlocked a 9 track OST which will have a track for each of the foraging locales!
Each new patient brings a new ailment that you will have to find a way to cure. Hover Hives, Partial Petrification, or even just a Hangover, you will have to make up a potion to cure them. Check the tags for each ailment and write them in your journal. Then, check through the regeant's list to find what plants, fungi, or animal bits you need to set them right. Once you've made your list, its time to go foraging.
There are 9 unique locales in Apothecaria where regeants can be found but it isn't a matter of just choosing the right one, you'll also have to deal with the random events found within. Sail with ghost pirates, stroll with druids, climb precarious cliff faces and trudge through magical swamps. 
Once you've managed to find your regeants, it's time to make the potion, noting down the recipe as you go. If you make it in time, the patient pays and is cured of their ailment. Use that money to upgrade your cottage with regeant farms and better tools.
If you're too slow... well, hopefully it wasn't too serious.
As you progress, you'll unlock new locales and more challenging ailments which will see you grow from Novice to Expert Witch over time.
As the seasons change, you'll also have the opportunity to go to Celebrations in the village. Go to the festive dances with an NPC of your choice, take part in sled races, baking contests, rowboat races, and even chat with old ghosts.
The changing seasons also mean that certain reagents become easier or harder to find, changing up the best recipes for potions and keeping things fresh.
Advanced Ailments (pre-playtest, not final layout)
56 pages packed full of Ailments to cure, Reagents to find, Tools to use, and Locales to explore. 
I'm going for a found journal style of thing so Apothecaria will be full of field sketches and notes from the previous witch, giving you an insight into who they were and why they disappeared. The sketches you see in the banners are the sort of things you can expect to see throughout the book.
To play you'll need: 
- A deck of playing cards
- A journal
- Something to write with
And that's it.
£2000 - Extra Art - Unlocked!
If we get this much I will commission Adam ''Forange'' Törn to create another beautiful postcard like the one being used as the cover image. The initial postcard serves as the introduction to the setting and explains more about how you've ended up the witch of High Rannoc.
£2200 - Familiar Tales & Wandcraft Postcard Games - Unlocked!
As a witch, the two most important things in your life are your familiar and your wand. These A6 size mini-games let you explore the secret life of your familiar and give you a way to create, use, and sell wands.
£2500 | £2800 | £3000 - More Art! - Unlocked!
If we get through these stretch goals I will comission more postcards that show off the special locales such as Dreamwater Depths, Blastfire Bog, The Cloud Isles, and The Strange.
£3200 - Papercraft Golem and Mimic - Unlocked!
Fold Up Toys have created an awesome papercraft of the Moonstone Crystal but there are other unique tools that I'd love to see brought to life.
£4000 - Guest Designers - Unlocked!
Once we reach this goal I will pay a few of my designer friends to write up some new ailments and reagents that expand upon the world outside of High Rannoc. The designers who have agreed to help are:
Jack Harrison - Mousehole Press
Creator of Artefact, Orbital, and Buckets of Bolts (which is on Kickstarter right now). 
Matt Sanders - Sealed Library
Creator of The Sealed Library, Glittering Hoards, Dead Emperors, and much more
Chris Bissette - Loot The Room
Creator of Wretched & Alone, Under The Floorboards, Dice Souls, and more
These guest expansions will take the form of A6 postcards with a few new ailments and reagents on each.
Hot damn those went quick.
Alright, last one.
£8000 - Unlocked! - Soundtrack by Christopher Michael Roberts
Christopher did the amazing soundtrack for Artefact and if we can get to this level, we'll be able to put together a 9 track OST with a beautiful ambient song for each locale.

A PDF copy of Apothecaria and a Digital Postcard welcoming you to High Rannoc as well as a print file for an awesome papercraft of the purifying Moonstone by Fold Up Toys as pictured below.

Print+ PDF Bundle - £12 (RRP £15)
An A5 saddlestich print copy of Apothecaria with a copper foil cover and a Physical Postcard welcoming you to High Rannoc as well as the rewards from the Digital Only tier. You will also get a potion sticker and a 150gsm A5 printed papercraft of the purifying Moonstone by Fold Up Toys for you to cut out and put together. (You will also get the print file.

Double Trouble - £24
Everything from the Print + PDF Bundle x 2. Two print copies filled with all the juicy stretch goals we've unlocked along the way.

Get print and PDF copies of Apothecaria as well as my solo map drawing games DELVE, RISE, and UMBRA. Like the Print + PDF bundle, you'll also get a Physical Postcard, potion sticker, and a 150gsm A5 printed papercraft of the purifying Moonstone by Fold Up Toys for you to cut out and put together. campaign.story:
The lighthouse was an ordinary structure, except for the fact that it was balanced on the very edge of the universe. It had, some speculated, been standing since the universe began. Maintained by a solitary keeper, the lighthouse has been keeping travellers and spaceships from falling off the edge. Its steady beam can be seen galaxies away and is used as a guiding star for navigators. 
You are the current keeper of the lighthouse. Whatever happens, you must keep the light running. You and the lighthouse live perched on the edge of the universe. It is a rocky, mostly barren place (it would look like any rocky island back on earth) where it is beaten by solar winds and sometimes run into by space whales. Not all of it is terrible though, high in the top of the lighthouse you get to witness strange lights dance, the solar winds whispering fortunes in your ears, shoals of sky fish migrating past. Maybe you'll find some solitude and peace in the under the dark, lonely sky. Sometimes a lone traveller may even cross your path. 
The Lighthouse is a solo journalling game best played at nighttime before bed or for when you can't sleep. The Lighthouse is about running a lighthouse in space. It is played with a dice, a coin and pack of cards. Roll the dice and flip a card to get a prompt. Flip a coin to see how you go about the task. Record your duties, thoughts and observations. Your notes in the logbook will be a record of your time in the lighthouse and the lighthouse itself. 
Each night in the lighthouse will be a little different, you may have less tasks to do or one task that takes a while. You have space to write as many or as little words as you would like, maybe you can only spare 15 minutes to play or maybe you have time to sit down and write a long entry. The game is designed to be played over and over as you and the lighthouse evolve, change and get to know each other. It is reflective and meditative.
Each logbook entry begins with your observations of the weather. You and the lighthouse are at the mercy of the weather at the edge and so mishaps are very likely to happen. Maybe you'll need to fix something, replace a panel, clean up a breakage, refill the tea in your flask. The oil in the lamp will need refilling through the night and the wick may need to be tended to. Once you've done that, sit down and take some time to Observe those passing by from the lighthouse's balcony. Maybe you'll spot a pod of space whales migrating to the next galaxy or a spaceship going on its merry way.
The physical zine is currently 24 pages long and measures 148 x 105mm (A6 size). It will be stapled and will be a small zine! 
If stretch goals are reached, the zine will be roughly 32 pages long. The cover design is not final and will probably change during revisions. 
There is a little paper craft cut out of a lighthouse at the end that you can put over your phone light for some tiny ambience. The zine will be professionally printed on uncoated 150gsm matte stock with a 200gsm cover. 
Very rough test print of the zine! Layout and imagery may change in final revisions
Goal
The funding goal covers printing for 80-100 zines plus a test print. I want to do a test print to ensure the final zine is perfect! I was going to skip this step but I really want to make sure I can deliver a great quality zine. 

Shipping costs:
Shipping costs is not included in the pledges and are added on separately. Shipping will be sent with a stamp and does not include tracking. International shipping from Australia is very expensive and the stamp is the cheapest way to do it. The small zine size also makes it cheaper to ship. I'll be sending the zines in sturdy card mailers or thick envelopes (depending on what I can source) to protect from damage. 

Single zine shipping costs:
Domestic shipping (Australia): $3
International shipping (Everywhere else): $5

x2 zines shipping costs:
Domestic shipping (Australia): $3
International shipping (Everywhere else): $10
Since this is my first kickstarter, I want to keep everything really simple! I'm offering a digital copy of the game or a physical copy with a digital copy thrown in. 

PDF copy: 
This is a digital copy of the zine. If the stretch goal with the mini game is unlocked, the pdf will include it. PDFs will be delivered through itch.io!

Physical copy: 
The physical copy of the game is currently 24 pages long, and will be extended to include the mini game if the stretch goal is reached. You have the option of buying one copy or two copies. Physical copies come with a digital PDF. 

After Kickstarter:
The game will be available on itch.io and I aim to sell physical copies of it on my online shop. The quality may be slightly different as I'll be printing it myself and I may change the graphics. So basically, this cover, imagery and print quality is a Kickstarter exclusive thing!
These stretch goals are really simple as I want to make it easy for me to achieve and won't impact the overall project timeline. 

 $300 - UNLOCKED - A mini game: Beach combing on the Edge of the Universe 
This mini game is about wondering along the edge of universe and collecting things that have found their way to the edge of the universe. This mini game is fully written and is a tiny exploring game. This game can be played after or before the main game.

 $400 - UNLOCKED - A postcard/mini art print  
This is a postcard that can also be a mini art print! (Will be A6 size 105x148mm) Postcards are awesome, and what a better way to send a little love to friends or family.

 $600 - UNLOCKED - Entries from keepers past 
Many keepers have disappeared from the lighthouse during storms or other mysterious events. The logbook has kept every one of their last entries and they will be collated in a little side zine or maybe to the back of the game. (Haven't figured this out yet) They will be little stories in the form of logbook entries of the strange events some have witnessed over the passing millennia. 

More stretch goals may be added depending on funding levels!
Here's a rough plan for the project. I will share images and updates when each task is finished! 
Writing & art needs to be completed. This should not take too long as the game is already 80% written and almost fully illustrated.
Once content is done, layout and design needs to be finalised. The layout is almost completed as it is!
The next step is to get a test print of the zines. I'm using a local printer that should take 1-2 weeks at the most to arrive. 
Once the test print has arrived, I'll check over it for errors. Once everything is all good, I'll order the zines! Yay! 
 When the zines arrive, it's packing time. I'll package and ship out the zines myself from my little studio. I have a planned delivery date for June to give me space just in case things take some time to complete or to get to me. 
Hi, I'm Ella, a writer and graphic designer living at the bottom of the world. I write solo journaling games about strange worlds. I'm really not sure what I'm doing but making zines seems to be the thing I want to do at the moment! 
Take a look at my other work: lostwaysclub.itch.io 

Thank you!

campaign.story:
New stretch goals added for the final push!
A thousand years ago, we built twelve giant mecha to fight a cataclysmic war. We called them Thrones. Ten survived that great war: ancient weapons with storied histories of battle and betrayal, but also symbols of dominance and entitlement. Possession of a Throne bestows wealth, power, and dominion over whole star systems.
That's why you're going to steal one. 
Stealing the Throne is a tabletop roleplaying game of exciting mecha heist action for 3-5 players. It’s GMless, and requires absolutely zero prep to play. In just a few hours you’ll build a Throne, a titanic mech with a thousand years of drama-filled history. You’ll devise the elaborate security systems that protect it, and then play to find out how your crew of thieves take them apart.  
A mecha heist rpg / 3-5 players / GMless / 1-3 hours / zero-prep 
Gameplay consists of three phases. In the Planning phase, you’ll decide which of the ten surviving Thrones you’re going to steal, and where you’re going to steal it from. Together you’ll learn a little about its history and its capabilities, and figure out why you have to steal it. 
Mockup of the zine cover, featuring Glaive of the Cenotaph by Galen Pejeau.
During the Heist, players take on one of three rotating roles: Throne, Thief, and Backup. The Throne sets a scene by describing the fiendish security measures the Thief must overcome to advance towards their prize. The Thief faces the challenge, making use of flashbacks and calling on assistance as needed. The Backup helps the Throne by adding details and roleplaying NPCs, and comes to the Thief’s aid if the situation gets dicey.
Once the security measures are defeated and the Throne secured, the thieves make their Getaway. This is everyone’s chance to finally take control of the giant mech in a rapid-fire montage of big action and (potentially) big reveals. Will your thief escape with the prize, go out in a blaze of glory, or perhaps reveal themselves a traitor?
Inspirations
Stealing the Throne is inspired by Ocean’s 8, Fast Five, Rogue One and Leverage ("Let's go steal us a giant mech"). Add in some Battletech and a dash of the decommissioned Jaeger scrapyard sequence from Pacific Rim: Uprising. 
The rules draw from Lovecraftesque by Becky Annison and Josh Fox, Sol Survivor by W.H. Arthur, HEIST: Get Rich or Die Trying by Allie Bustion, and John Wick’s Wilderness of Mirrors.
Try it now!
The basic rules for Stealing the Throne are available right now! You can find them in the December 2020 edition of the fantastic in*die zine. Just $4 gets you all the rules you need to try out Stealing the Throne, alongside five other games, supplements, articles, and even a photo-comic by excellent indie designers.
Spread from the example of play. The final zine interior will be black and white.
If you’re curious about how the game runs, you can find a detailed example of play here. In it, the thieves Alabaster, Berkeley, and Camden team up to steal Glaive of the Cenotaph from a gala event at the Museum of Art, Culture, and Warfare. 
What are people saying?
"At the end of our game of Stealing the Throne, we all sat back and thought ‘damn, I want to see a movie of this!’" - Logan, Amble Studio
"We pulled off an epic heist with zero prep required. The prompts in the rule-book don't restrict you at all but make it easy to come up with unique and exciting story lines. I can't wait to see what the art will look like!" - Mark Bowker, playtester
"It's like Macross meets Ocean's 8." - Marx Shepherd, host of Yes Indie'd Pod
"The game elements worked together beautifully to ensure a GM-less experience that was full of tension, surprise and challenge. From designing the mecha before we battled with it, to taking turns playing as the enemy, to having the option to self-sacrifice, it all came together to leave our group awestruck at the result." - Hailey Cooperrider, Amble Studio
"I was blown away by how much gripping story we created together with so few constraints. Play it! This one’s a real narrative design gem.” - Jason, Amble Studio
The zine will feature a gorgeous full-colour cover illustrated by Galen Pejeau. The interior will be black and white, 24-28 pages, staple bound. Printing will be handled by Mixam UK.
Here’s what you’ll find inside:
Complete rules for action-filled heist one-shots.
Four sample Thrones to get you playing straight away.
Funds from this Kickstarter will pay for beautiful full-page art of the sample Thrones, by four supremely talented artists: 
 Galen Pejeau's illustration of Glaive of the Cenotaph already graces the cover. Inside the zine, he'll provide an illustration of Tensword (Twitter's darling).
 Sam Tung will work on Belly Laugh (a favourite amongst playtesters). 
 Si Sweetman will bring us The Burning Soldier.
 Brandish Gilhelm will illustrate the final Throne, Justice Above.
Alongside this artwork you’ll find inspiration in the form of Throne-specific tables, prompts, mech systems, history, or defences. You can use them as quick-start playsets to launch your games, inspiration for building your own Thrones, or prompts to fall back on if you need a mid-game creativity boost.
Community Copies
Every Throne and Ancient Hero backer, and every five backers at the Thief level will generate one digital community copy for folks who are unable to afford the cost of the zine. Any reason, at your discretion, absolutely no questions asked. Community copies will be made available at itch.io.
I’m Nick Bate, designer of Stealing the Throne. I’m an Australian game designer, freelancer, and former galactic archaeologist living in the UK. I've written scenarios and setting material for Over the Edge 3rd Edition, Modiphius’ Infinity, and Bulldogs!, and have work forthcoming for Technoir, CrashCart, and The Map is not The Territory.
I've also designed games about doomed expeditions to mysterious monuments, daring sky pirates, and dimension-hopping explorers. Alongside Stealing the Throne, I’m currently working on Speed Daemons, a Forged in the Dark game of illegal mech racing.
Galen Pejeau is an illustrator and occasional game designer who lives in Indiana with his partner and suspiciously adorable daughter. He raises chickens & bees and distills his own whiskey, and while this branch of his career has come as a bit of a surprise, he is happy that you all are enjoying his big robots.
Sam Tung is a storyboard artist and tabletop RPG designer. He is the illustrator and co-author (with his regular collaborator Sam Roberts) of Escape From Dino Island and has storyboarded numerous feature films, television shows, and commercials. He is currently storyboarding Metroid Prime 4.
Si Sweetman (he/him) is a freelance illustrator specialising in mecha design. He has worked on indie tabletop properties such Armour Astir: Advent, Last Shooting, The Veil: Inheritance and another of Nick's projects, Speed Daemons. He is currently art directing an unannounced project with Bloom Digital and finishing up a series of Patreon illustrations for Friends at the Table's 6th season, PARTIZAN. 
Brandish Gilhelm is the creator of Runehammer in all its forms. A lifetime artist and D&D head, he's now expanded into publishing, novels, synth composition and more. You'll find him drinking german beer in Philly.
Support at this level (£4 GBP / $5.50 USD approx) for a digital PDF edition of the zine, as well as a plain text version. Distributed via Backerkit and itch.io.
Join the crew for the greatest heist in history! Backers at this level (£8 GBP / $11 USD approx) will receive a print edition of the zine, along with the PDF edition. Postage will be charged when the zine ships.
Ten Thrones survive. Which one will you steal? Backers at this tier (£18 GBP / $25 USD approx) receive a special print edition of the zine, along with the PDF edition. I will personally sign and annotate each zine with additional prompts, secrets, or Throne systems. Each zine will be a unique artefact. Postage will be charged when the zine ships. Limited to 10 only!
Your heroism echoes down the thousand years since the Thrones fought in that first cataclysmic war. Backers at this tier (£100 GBP / $135 USD approx) will receive all the same rewards as the Throne tier, including a signed and annotated physical zine. In addition, I will work with you to develop your own unique Throne. You’ll provide me with a name and some ideas, and I’ll turn them into a playset like the other examples in the zine. The custom playset will be in PDF, separate to the final zine. Limited to 2 only!
Shipping
Shipping will be charged after the Kickstarter is complete, via Backerkit. Current estimated shipping costs for a single zine are:
UK: £1.83
EU: £4.25 (approximately €4.80) 
Rest of World (including USA): £5.85 (approximately $7.95 USD) 
Please keep in mind that postage costs may rise before delivery. I promise to keep you informed as shipping approaches.
Now that we're fully funded, it's time for stretch goals!
FUNDED! - At £1250 Jane Hermiston will join the team as layout consultant! Jane's considerable layout skills will help make the zine as gorgeous as it can be.
Jane loves the the playful, and the clever. They are a long time gamer with a creative design attitude; they're truly nerdy about creating unique visuals that spark your imagination. They've worked as layout artist - and now layout coordinator - for in*die zine, as well as on a range of other tabletop projects: from one-pagers to D&D. 
FUNDED! - At £1650 Dr Melody Watson will join the team as editor! Melody will deploy her impressive editing skills to whip the game's text into the best possible shape.
Melody is a specialist RPG editor, game designer and mech-loving science-fictionist from Adelaide, Australia. She's edited a diverse range of games, including Lancer, dungeonpunk, and the ENnie award-winning Thousand Year Old Vampire, and has written for numerous others. When she isn't polishing words, she serves the whims of three gremlinous cats and makes her own weird games about robots, history, and dogs in space. You can keep up with Melody's hijinks on Twitter and check out her portfolio at melodynova.com.
FUNDED! - At £2200 Galen Pejeau will provide additional interior art for the zine! We've already funded gorgeous full-page illustrations of four Thrones. If we hit this stretch goal Galen Pejeau will provide additional illustrations for the interior of the zine. Could be spot illustrations, could be border art. We'll figure something out!
FUNDED! - At £3000 I will develop rules for solo Throne heists! Solo RPGs are one of my favourite discoveries of the last few years. (I've even written one.) I think there's a solo play variant of Stealing the Throne just waiting to be designed. If we hit this stretch goal, I'll make it happen! (These variant rules will be supplied in PDF format for all backers at the Backup level and above.)
At £4000 I will commission an illustrated star chart! This map might cover a stellar cluster, a galaxy, maybe even the whole Local Group. It will be filled with plot hooks from a thousand years of history: sites of ancient battles, mysterious objects, interstellar dominions. (This map will be supplied in PDF format for all backers at the Backup level and above.)
At £4500 each contributor will receive bonus pay! Thanks to your generosity, each of the contributors to Stealing the Throne will receive a $50 USD bonus on top of their agreed rates. More pay for artists, layout experts, and editors!
At £5000, even more bonus pay! Should we hit this frankly outrageous goal, each contributor will receive a further $50 USD bonus. Can we make it this far?
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my first Kickstarter, and in the spirit of ZineQuest I’m keeping things simple. The rules for the game are already written and playtested, and they’ve been past the expert editors and designers in the in*die community. All that remains is to design the sample Thrones and layout the zine. I’ll be doing the layout in Affinity Publisher, which I’ve used for all of my previous games. 

This is also the first time I’ve printed a physical product. I’ve been communicating with more experienced members of the local design community, some of whom have produced very similar zines. With their help and guidance, I’m confident I can navigate the complexities of Mixam printing and shipping.

Life can always throw up challenges, of course. The artists and I have already been in communication about timelines, but any significant changes in circumstances may cause delays. I’ll be in touch with the artists regularly, and will make sure to communicate any complications with backers. The health and wellbeing of all contributors will be my main priority, of course.

Lastly, there are possible Brexit impacts. The zines will be printed in the UK, but the artists are paid in USD and CAD. Any falls in the GBP will therefore increase my costs. I’ve built in a healthy buffer to my funding goal to account for this.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
