campaign.story:
The year is 30XX. Envoys blaze across the dried out seabed of what folk once called the Gulf of Mexico, riding rigs made of salvage beneath a psychedelic sky...
Ahoy! I’m D G Chapman. I’ve written official adventures for Mothership, games for World Champ Game Co., and last year I participated in ZineQuest 2020 with my liquorice fantasy zine BUTCHERY. I also write the Graverobber’s Guide and make things for your table like GRAVEROBBERS, GoGoGolf! and Bastard Magic.
After releasing BUTCHERY to backers last year, I was inspired to go bigger and better for this year’s ZineQuest! I’m revamping an old project of mine, Journeylands, in a magazine format with brand new mechanics, eclectic art and maybe even some other fun surprises stuffed inside.
 J’lands is a travel-based adventure system in which one or more players create and customise vehicles called rigs to wander a psychedelic solarpunk world. It’s like One Piece meets that episode of The Simpsons with the space coyote.
In this issue, players are envoys tasked with delivering supplies across the Journeylands - and, of course, having all kinds of adventures along the way.
Inspired by the best of the OSR genre with procedural overland mechanics that facilitate both classic GM’d and solo play, it’s all about player-driven exploration, overcoming challenges, and achieving personal goals in a hopeful setting.
art by Krzysztof Maziarz
Journeylands #1: Coral Canyons is the first instalment in a (hopefully!) ongoing series. Issue one of the magazine will be…
☀️  A welcome wagon, introducing readers to the anticanon of the Journeylands through art and gameable setting info. The ultimate travel guide!
☀️  A starter kit, streamlining and tutorialising the basics of play for 1 or more players. Journey solo or with your game group!
☀️  A complete package, containing all the rules and tools needed to begin your journeys. No need to wait for future issues!
£111 - Funded!
£222 - A Wish For A Fish! Guest writer Tucker Hanley, creator of The Hungry Dungeon Master, will contribute some uniquely flavourful material to the Journeylands. New possibilities for your game, plus an original recipe you can try at home!
£333 - Cassetteland! Guest writer Giuliano Roverato, creator of Bakto’s Terrifying Cuisine, will contribute a new location and new ways to adventure in the Journeylands. Check out the incredible work on display at Roll 4 Tarrasque for more!
£444 - The League of Oddly Similar Barterers! Guest writer Reynaldo Madriñan, co-creator of the highly anticipated BREAK!!, will contribute these faintly familiar characters to the Journeylands. Feast on the BREAK!! devblog and get hype!
£555 - More art! We’ve got a range of talented artists from all over the world contributing to this project, so let’s keep on truckin’ with even more visual goodness.
£666 - ???

By backing this Kickstarter campaign at the Trailblazer level as part of ZineQuest 2021, you’ll receive a free copy of Journeylands #1 on release, including any stretch goals we reach during the campaign.
I hope to see you in the Journeylands soon!

updates.update_content:
The finish line is in sight! Beyond that... the horizon!
Only one day left of our campaign! Let’s put the pedal to the metal.

One last recommendation time!
Where the Wheat Grows Tall is a faerie-themed rural adventure for old-school systems by Evlyn Moreau and Camilla Greer. I remember Evlyn from back in the G+ days of the OSR, her art has always stood out and it’s so great to see her still creating! This looks... well, just look at it, it’s phenomenal.

Just a short lil update today to say we have less than 3 days left until Journeylands is funded! I’ve been polishing the manuscript and making sure all the artists and other contributors are lined up and ready to go - as soon as the campaign ends, the journey begins!
Now is the time to share the campaign to make sure everyone has a chance to be on board! Something as simple as a post on social media can help weird little projects like this one find their audience. Thanks for all the support so far - let’s go all out for the home stretch!

Well then.
First off, please allow me to once again thank everyone who's backed the project so far! Im so thankful that you've all expressed an interest in Journeylands and given your valuable support in making it happen. You rock.

Zinequest is very much underway, huh? I don't know about you, but the sheer volume of fantastic projects and ideas I've seen people excited about has been a little overwhelming!

😭😭😭
I can't quite believe it... Journeylands is real! Thank you all so much!!
I'll post a proper update soon - I was unprepared for this haha
Of course, this is only the beginning! Let's keep pushing for those stretch goals! Whether you've backed the project or not, the easiest way to help it is to talk about it. Share on social media, with your friends and gaming circles, anyone who might be interested!

campaign.story:
What do bounty hunters and their crew do when the galaxy no longer needs them?
In A Complicated Profession, they start new careers HOSTING INTERGALACTIC CRUISES for fickle passengers in lawless space.
Create a ragtag crew of ex-bounty hunters, their jaded sidekicks, shabby droids and shady accomplices. Then, pick a hosting role and start a new business together on your very own ship.
Draft cover of A Complicated Profession, with art by ginkgo.whale (layout not final)
A Complicated Profession is a 40-page sci-fi RPG zine for 3 to 5 players. It's intended to be played over 1 or 2 sessions of 3 to 4 hours.
It's a light-hearted, GM-less storytelling game that’s ideal for a one-shot. It could also be a funny way to end a larger sci-fi campaign like Edge of the Empire or Scum and Villainy.
Although it’s easy to learn, each play-through of ACP is varied and rewarding due to:
a choice of 8 hunter roles and 8 host roles (64 different combinations!)
a choice of 9 themed event playbooks, playable in any order
player-created ship assets that you’re rewarded for using
randomly generated contracts and passengers
You can succeed or fail to some degree, but the main aim of ACP is to create a memorable and amusing story together, with prompts and pick lists to help if you're short of ideas.
It's possible to play the whole game non-violently if you wish, as there are no combat mechanics. Of course, you could also play it as a swashbuckling shoot-em-up if that's what your players (or passengers) would enjoy.
Choose your past hunter role from a choice of 8
Then pick your new host role on the ship
A Complicated Profession was inspired by Stewpot: Tales from a Fantasy Tavern by Takuma Okada. This means both games share a few core mechanics:
A past and present career - in ACP, you select your old hunter role and a new host role. Each comes with a unique choice of possessions and experiences to help you tell your story. For example, you might choose to play an outdated droid turned entertainer or mystic mentor turned janitor!
An evolving character - in ACP, you start with 2 character sheets, but by the end you'll have ripped up or deleted your old role. You'll throw away your previous possessions and use your new, customer-friendly name.
A collection of slice-of-life scenes - in ACP, you select from a list of themed playbooks that depict memorable events or highlights during your 3 contracts.
Quick setup and simple world-building - in ACP, you use pick lists and answer prompt questions to fill out simple sheets for your character's look, species, backstory, corner of the galaxy, home spaceport and ship.
I've written a full list of available roles in ACP explained #1 in the updates section. 
Example character sheets from the first draft of A Complicated Profession (layout not final)
Choose from pick lists to help build your world
Sounds cool, but what do you actually do?
COMPLETE CONTRACTS & ENTERTAIN PASSENGERS
Your main goal in A Complicated Profession is to fulfil 3 randomly generated contracts.
When you create a contract you'll draw cards to select a set of passengers and the type of contract they've requested. For example, they could be thrill-seeking soldiers, retirees looking for a culinary experience, or a sports team having a party before the big game.
Do your best to give your passengers what they're looking for while dealing with events. After each contract, someone will play a special event as a passenger to judge your efforts...
I've written about contracts & passengers in ACP explained #3 in the updates section. 
Fill out simple contract and ship sheets as you play; to look back on your crew‘s performance and have a physical record of your session
CHOOSE & PLAY EVENTS
Players take turns choosing themed event playbooks from a menu of 9. 
You'll choose 3 main events to play during each of your 3 contracts. Whoever chooses the event is the lead player, but everyone is involved!
You'll answer questions and narrate improvised scenes using story prompts. Deal with problems such as unplanned excursions, special meal requests, ship invasions, unexpected romance and much more!
There's also regular special events including procuring player-created items from your home spaceport, judging the crew's efforts and a reflective final event to provide a satisfying ending.
I've written more about events in ACP explained #2 on the updates section.
Event menu and example event from the first draft of A Complicated Profession (layout not final)
DECORATE, EQUIP & POPULATE YOUR SHIP
As you play, you'll earn the chance to create ship assets, including:
decorations - consolation prizes to help fill out your ship and create scenes
useful items - which can be anything you want, but can only be used a few times
NPC crew members - to fill vacant host roles and provide assistance
The better your crew perform, the more ship assets you'll gain.
Describe your ship together, then add to it as you play
An example of how ship assets work together
ROLL SOME DICE!
Events are resolved with a simple (D6) dice pool. You'll get bonus dice for utilising certain ship assets and your character's experiences.
The best result you roll dictates whether your crew succeeded. Success leads to rewards, but fail and you'll have to explain what went wrong.
I'm Jason (he/him), a designer from Southampton, England. 
Like most of you reading this, I've played TTRPGs, video games and tabletop miniature games my whole life.
This is my first RPG project, although I was lucky enough to contribute a playbook to Jack Harrison's solo TTRPG Artefact.
My gaming group tends to struggle for time, with a few hours a week to play together online. I'd like to focus on games that can be satisfying to play in short bursts, or can be completed in 1 or 2 sessions.
You're doing this all by yourself?
No. I love writing but my Indesign and art skills are super limited. Luckily, I have a great team of creatives to help me deliver this project and make it look amazing, including:
Layout by Vee Hendro - a graphic designer specialising in roleplaying and board game projects, based in Sydney, Australia. She's been an instrumental part of many projects including Good Society: A Jane Austen RPG (Storybrewers Roleplaying), Visigoths vs Mall Goths (Lucian Kahn), and Uk'otoa (Darrington Press). Vee is also an award-winning game designer and co-founder at Storybrewers Roleplaying. Her graphic design portfolio can be found at veerpgdesigns.com.
Artwork by Nuša Štiglic aka ginkgo.whale - a freelance illustrator, comic book artist and graphic designer from Ljubljana, Slovenia with 7+ years of experience. You can see examples of Nuša‘s work on her website, ArtStation, or here:  
Jungle Bedroom Design, by ginkgo.whale
Sushio Vending Machine, by ginkgo.whale
Loft, by ginkgo.whale
Promo video credits:
Video art & animation by Nuša Štiglic
A Complicated Profession logo by Sanja Zamuda 
Video soundtrack by S0und like 
In addition to the rewards described below, backers at all levels will be sent a first edition PDF of the game, with my own basic layout and some stock placeholder art. 
This will be sent very soon after the campaign finishes so you can begin playing ACP!
Backer levels include:
LEVEL ONE (PDF) - You'll get a PDF copy of ACP as soon as professional layout and artwork is completed. All stretch goals included.
LEVEL TWO (PDF & zine) - You'll get a PDF copy of ACP and an A5 physical zine as soon as professional layout and artwork is completed. All stretch goals included.
LEVEL THREE (PDF, zine & stickers) - You'll get a PDF copy of ACP and an A5 physical zine as soon as professional layout and artwork is completed. All stretch goals included. I'll use some of the game‘s artwork to create a bundle of 3 stickers. This level is really to help fund the project, but stickers are fun right!?
LEVEL FOUR (PDF, zine, stickers, custom dice and custom playing cards) - You'll get a PDF copy of ACP and an A5 physical zine as soon as professional layout and artwork is completed. All stretch goals included. I'll use some of the game‘s artwork to create a bundle of 3 stickers, 3 custom D6 dice featuring the ACP logo and a pack of custom playing cards. Everything you need to play ACP (except 2 to 4 awesome friends).  
Example of the custom playing cards and card back
LEVEL FIVE (5 zines, 10 stickers) - You'll get five A5 physical zines as soon as professional layout and artwork is completed. All stretch goals included. I'll also include a bundle of 10 stickers. This level is for anyone looking to buy several copies for a store or a gaming club at a discounted rate (equivalent of one free copy).
ALL LEVELS - Any kickstarter purchase of A Complicated Profession will fund an equal number of community copies of the game. This means that when the finished PDF is eventually launched on my itch.io page, anyone in need can claim a copy, no questions asked.
Shipping costs
Shipping fees are not included as part of your Kickstarter pledge. 
Shipping will be calculated and collected after the campaign ends (using BackerKit).
Estimated shipping:
For a single physical copy within the UK: around £1-3
For a single physical copy outside of the UK: around $5-10 USD 
If you‘re outside of the UK and worried about shipping costs, please do consider the PDF-only option in LEVEL ONE! 
Due to the changeable nature of international shipping, the LEVEL FOUR option may incur VAT charges if you do not live in the UK. Again, please consider backing a lower-level option if you're worried about incurring extra costs or hassle!
 £1,500 - FUNDED - UNLOCKED! 
Initial artwork, printing and professional layout is covered and the best version of A Complicated Profession I can make will be in your hands or hard drives later this year.

£2,000 - MORE ARTWORK - UNLOCKED!
I'll be commissioning 12 more pieces of artwork from Nuša. These will accompany all of the in game events/playbooks and replace all of the stock art I'm currently using.

 £3,000 - LO-FI SOUNDTRACK AND ANIMATION - UNLOCKED! 
I'll be commissioning a 30-40 minute lo-fi beats soundtrack and looping animation for ACP. Music will be composed by Christopher Michael Roberts, creator of the critically-acclaimed soundtrack for Artefact by Jack Harrison (and the upcoming Orbital soundtrack).

 £3,500 - PASSENGER NAME AND SPECIES GENERATOR - UNLOCKED! 
I'll be creating a quick reference sheet to help you come up with suitable names and species for your passengers when creating a contract.
If you backed the digital version, this will be included in the files. If you backed the physical version this will be a separate printed reference sheet (probably postcard-sized).

£4,000 - CUSTOM MIRO BOARD TEMPLATE FOR ONLINE PLAY - - UNLOCKED!
I'll be creating a custom Miro template to help facilitate online play while COVID-times continue (or for when your friends don't live in the same city).
Miro is a free online collaborative tool that is super user-friendly. You can sign up for free, add the template that I create and then invite your friends to join the board.
It will include all the player sheets that need to be filled in as you play, including character roles. So everyone will be able to see each others characters, your shared world, your ship assets, and contribute to filling in the contract notes.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I already have the first draft of A Complicated Profession written and in a basic PDF layout.

I’ll need to wait for the full set of artwork and the professional layout to be completed. I may also make some design tweaks if I receive feedback from backers after the first edition is sent out.

Printing will be fulfilled by Mixam in the UK, which are an established company that many others use. 

The main risks I can think of are postal issues, mostly outside of the UK. I have no idea if coronavirus is still going to affect shipping time or costs, but I hope the impact will be less by the time the physical zines are ready to ship later in the year. Brexit seems to have pushed up shipping prices outside of the UK, reflected in the estimated costs above. 

This is my first kickstarter project, so there's a small risk I haven't thought of something important. I've kept it intentionally simple to ensure I can do my best to deliver everything on time.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Bucket of Bolts is a game of iconic spaceships and their infamous captains for one player.
She may not look like much kid, but she’s got it where it counts!
The Bebop. Serenity. The Millennium Falcon. 
You can’t have a good space story without an iconic spaceship. Of course, more often than not, the heroes of the story aren’t flying some shiny new cruiser. Those are for the wealthy, the elites—not our lovable scoundrels. No, they fly the bucket of bolts—the outworn, patched-up junker held together with hope, prayers and duct tape.
The eponymous 'bucket of bolts'
These ships weren’t always hunks of junk though—they have long and storied histories, and might even have been respectable vessels at some point. We only ever see a slice of that story though, a single captain and their motley crew. 
This game flips the perspective.  

The Game.
Bucket of Bolts is a hack of Artefact, my game from last year's ZineQuest. Instead of creating a magical item, this time you'll be telling the story of a single spaceship. You’ll create a brand new freighter, fresh off the manufacturing line, and explore its history through each of the people who captain it. Your ship will change as the decades pass - new names, new parts, fresh paint, fresh starts - until your story draws to a close.
You’ll choose your Captains, bringing them to life with names and details, and create stories of their time with your ship using prompts and tables. When you‘re ready to move on, you’ll choose a Fate for your ship. Maybe it’s traded away fairly, but more likely it’s stolen, captured or even wrecked. You might drift for a while as you wait for your next Captain, or the seat might still be warm when a new one takes over. Either way, the galaxy will change around you, and you’ll see it all from the view in the cockpit.
Like the original Artefact, it’s a great way to spend an hour or two; sketching, world-building and storytelling in your own company. It's also a fantastic way to generate really unique ships for tabletop games like Edge of the Empire, Traveller or Scum & Villainy, with rich backstories, fun details and tonnes of personality.

The Zine.
Format 
A little paper prototype of the zine opening.
I'll be using a new format for the physical rewards. Beak zines take an A3 sheet of paper and fold it into an 8-page A6 booklet. This process leaves one side of the paper blank, that people sometimes use to make a poster.
One of the things that's always bugged me about Artefact is how much flicking around the book you need to do as you play the game. I thought—why not use the blank side of a beak zine for all of the game's content; the tables, questions and prompts you’ll need during play. So that’s what I’m doing.
In Bucket of Bolts, you’ll be able to read through all the rules in the booklet and then unfold it into a complete reference for play. Pretty neat huh?
And here it is closing!
Paper
Extract comes in a range of lovely colours.
Of course, I'm still taking every opportunity to make this little zine a deluxe product. I'll be using one of my favourite paper stocks, G.F Smith Extract.
As well as having some seriously impressive environmental credentials (it's made from recycled coffee cups), it's also just a lovely paper that comes in some great colours. I’m partial to Mustard, as you can see in the prototype, but we’ll see when the print samples arrive.

Ink
Copies of ARTEFACT, outside on a sunny day.
As with my previous projects, I’ll be using Risograph to print the book. That means rich, vivid shades with the aesthetic of screen printing, but viable for large-scale print runs. It’s also one of the most sustainable ways to print, with soy-based inks & low energy machines. It’s going to be beautiful!

Illustration
Torben is very excellent at drawing spaceships.
Speaking of beautiful, I'm also commissioning Torben Bökemeyer again to do some awesome illustrations for the game. Spaceships are his bread & butter, and I think his sharp, detailed style is a really good fit for this game. You’ll have seen his key art at the top of the page, and he's already hard at work on the game's cover.

Collector’s Edition
I'm looking forward to an excuse to get wild with paper & ink combos...
I’m also offering a Collector’s Edition of the game, exclusive to the Kickstarter, packed with bonus printed matter like art prints, stickers and random tables.
It’s all paper stuff, but I think it’s gonna feel pretty special.
Any ’game content’ (such as random tables) will be available to all as a digital download.

Accessibility
Like Artefact and Orbital, the digital edition will also be fully-compatible with screen readers. A second version will also be provided to support a range of visual processing needs. Once again, Yubi will be handling the accessibility design of the digital files.

Community Copies
Every backer of Bucket of Bolts, physical or digital, will also be contributing one digital copy of the game to be available for free for those who need it. Thanks!

Stretch Goals
This is intentionally designed as a small project, but I've still got some cool things to announce if we break past our funding goal :)

Delivery.
Timelines
I’ve got a draft of the game written, and I’m happy that the core concept works as well for spaceships as it did for magical items (after making a few changes to the design). I’m hoping to get a playtest version out in a month or two, with the full digital version being delivered in late spring/early summer and the physical edition following soon after.

BackerKit
As with my previous projects, I’ll be using BackerKit to manage fulfilment. This time, though, I’m collecting shipping fees through Kickstarter so you shouldn’t need to add funds in BackerKit unless you’ve selected add-ons.

Orbital 
Orbital header art
My previous project, Orbital, is going to print imminently which means that the bulk of the work for that Kickstarter is done. I’m not shipping out the rewards myself, and the stretch goal content is coming along nicely. I’ll continue to actively manage the project, but barring any catastrophes it shouldn’t take up much headspace.

ARTEFACT: Reviews & Remarks.
I’m so happy with the way Artefact has been received. Here’s hoping I can recapture some of that magic for Bucket of Bolts.
If you’re a returning backer: hi, nice to see you again! I hope you also enjoyed Artefact :)
Print copies of Artefact
"It combines a little bit of writing and a little bit of drawing with a lot of storytelling to make a game that is one of the most relaxing and mindful experiences I have had this year." - Shut Up & Sit Down
"This is a great system agnostic supplement that could fit on any gamer’s shelf". — Pulp Culture Museum
"It was a wonderful game that once I started, I had a hard time putting down. I probably spent 8-9 hours on the game over the course of a quarantined weekend, and ended up with a story that pulled at my own heart-strings." — Play Every Role
There are also lots of lovely comments on the game's itch.io page.
~
Thanks for reading!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my third project now, so I'm getting pretty confident in successfully delivering rewards. I've intentionally pitched a smaller-scale project this time, to fit around my existing life commitments. I'm using familiar software, processes and people, so there shouldn't be any surprises.

During the delivery of my first two projects there's been a global pandemic, Brexit, sabotage of the USPS and international mail strikes. We've also welcomed the arrival of a second child into our family. We've figured it out. I think barring any serious family issues, we'll be fine. And, as always, you can expect a minimum of one update a month, keeping you in the loop.

campaign.story:
You are little people who walked into a big war. The Doomslord’s forces were gathered in the Broken Land, and your fellowship played a small but crucial role in their fall. Now, laden with stories to tell and burdens to bear, you set off on the journey home. But the Doomslord’s Hunters are still out there, and it’s a long way to walk…. Back again from the Broken Land.
❈     ❈     ❈     ❈     ❈
Back Again from the Broken Land is a tabletop roleplaying game of small adventurers sharing stories on a long walk home. It is meant to be played in one or two sessions. The game is inspired by the emotional, even bittersweet stretches of The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.
Back Again from the Broken Land is Powered by the Apocalypse. This is the tried-and-tested, story-forward system of wonderful games from Apocalypse World to Masks: A New Generation to Bluebeard's Bride. It's perfect for low-prep and no-prep one-shot gameplay, though you can also use it to play a short campaign of two to three sessions if you want to delve deeper into the characters' journeys. All you need to play are three six-sided dice, three-to-five players plus a GM, and a willingness to spin an emotional fantasy yarn together.
In Back Again from the Broken Land, you play as small adventurers returning to your hometown after playing a humble but crucial role in the fall of Doomslord. The game begins after the great war with the Doomslord, and the the stories you tell with determine the details of the adventures you've had and the home to which you return.
Like many Powered by the Apocalypse games, Back Again from the Broken Land has you build your character from a playbook. The following playbooks are available:
Playbooks of Back Again from the Broken Land
Other key game elements of Back Again from the Broken Land are Moves, Burdens, and Stories.
Moves are things you can do in the game that have important narrative and mechanical consequences. Sometimes you'll roll dice to see how the move goes. The game features homeward bound moves for the more reflective parts of your journey (these moves include chart a course, negotiate an obstacle, gaze into the distance, and share a meal) and peril moves for times when the Doomslord's vengeful Hunters are right on top of you (these moves include run, hide, and make a desperate stand).
Burdens represent the physical and emotional tolls of your adventure. You begin the game with a few unnamed Burdens, and seek to give names to them by telling stories. (Moments of danger and difficulty can lay on more burdens.) Once given a name like "a broken promise" or "a fallen comrade's cloak-pin," a Burden can be faced and cleared. The tone of your epilogue upon reaching home will be determined by how many named and unnamed Burdens you have left.
Stories are just that: stories you tell along the way, perhaps huddled round a campfire or in a moment of respite after a tense chase. Stories help define your past and give you ways to name and clear Burdens. The game includes lots of story prompts and evocative details to help inspire your stories. Some story prompts by way of example: "How your weapon was shattered," "The service you paid for with a song from home (and the verse you omitted)," and "How you made contact with the Doomslord in a place that should have been protected"
  To get a sense of the game in action, check out this Youtube playlist of Actual Play sessions!  
 You can also learn more about the game in this video review from Tony Vasinda of Plus One Exp, which he put together after playtesting the game! (The photos Tony uses in this video are from the Codex: Home version of the game, featuring art by Amanda Lee Franck and layout by Lu Quade.)
 Leah has written about designing GM materials for the game here on the Gauntlet Blog.
 Alexi has been a guest on two podcasts to discuss Back Again from the Broken Land. On Yes Indie'd he chats about the game, and on Plus One Forward he not only chats about the game but also runs a brief actual play segment:

Back Again from the Broken Land was originally published as a feature in Codex magazine's fall 2020 issue Codex: Home. It met with an enthusiastic reception, and we are very excited to revise and expand it into a full zine.
The zine will be a 40-page, 8 ½ x 5 ½ saddle-stitched booklet. The basic version will include black-and-white wraparound cover art. The Kickstarter-exclusive special edition will feature a wraparound color cover. Our cover artist for both versions is Emily Cheeseman. Here are her in-progress sketches for the zine's cover:
Emily Cheeseman's cover sketches for Back Again from the Broken Land
Layout on the zine will be by Todd Crapper. Here is a sample spread he created to give a sense of the zine's interior:
Todd Crapper's layout sample for Back Again from the Broken Land
We are excited to be running this campaign as part of ZineQuest, an initiative by Kickstarter to encourage the creation of RPG zines. Follow us on Twitter to see us highlighting our favorite other ZineQuest zines throughout February! 
Intimate yet effortlessly mythical, Back Again from the Broken Land captures the elegiac hope of Tolkien’s Lord of the Rings while creating something also new.
—Rosamund Hodge
It was a genuine delight playing this storytelling game that feels like a bittersweet montage at the end of a giant fantasy movie. The burden of hope, the clarity of sacrifice, the soul-healing power of a lovingly made breakfast.
—Cow Shea
Having never played a role-playing game ever before, I didn't know what to expect! But my daughters (7 and 9 years old) and I had so much fun diving into Back Again from the Broken Land. They are desperate to play again.
—Haley Stewart
Back Again from the Broken Land gave us a great framework to create characters and tell stories about how the heroes come home after their great adventure, what parts of themselves they left behind, and how maybe they didn’t really want to make it back at all. It’s versatile enough to let you tell a sad epilogue about a turncoat who hopes he’s been redeemed at the same time as that of returning hero who may not remember how to be the person she used to be.
—Chris Newton (@inarvan)
I wouldn't consider myself a fan of Tolkien, but Back Again from the Broken Land is one of my favourite fantasy RPGs I've played recently. What really makes it sing is the way it centres on telling stories: bittersweet, funny, melancholy, and sometimes tense, but always heartfelt.
—David Morrison
Back Again from the Broken Land is a game that remembers that the heart of an enduring fantasy story isn't the swashbuckling or the spell-slinging, it's, well, heart. The mechanics brilliantly encourage players to view their current challenges through layers of backstory, so we really feel how the scenes at the table are so crucial in our characters' own narratives. I've never come out of a one-shot as invested in my party as when playing Broken Land.
—Brian Lagoda
A character's backstory is often critical to understanding the meaning and emotional power of the situations that they are confronted with. This seldom finds expression in most games, given the focus on immediacy and action that necessarily dominates play. Back Again From the Broken Land lets us experience the act of one character getting to know another by requiring the characters to tell stories that are meaningful to who they are and who they wish to become.
—Brandon Brylawski
An emotional journey, with a bittersweet mood mixed with great friendships scenes. Those moments felt alive, thanks to the prompts and ideas of the game.
—Nicolas "Gulix" Ronvel
In Back Again from the Broken Land, the group jointly weaves a dense net of stories, a unique experience that I found very enjoyable and rewarding. Even a tiny story bit brought up in a half-sentence can grow to a thick strand of the emerging plot, all from the perspective of small but not-too-childlike people. Back Again from the Broken Land is often serious in its tone—after all, threatening Hunters are on your heels—but is seasoned with an ample amount of cozy and moments of surprise and wonder.
—Philipp Doebler
UNLOCKED $1000—New playbook: The Stargazer
At $1000, we'll add a new playbook to the game: The Stargazer. Back home, they called you a starry-eyed dreamer. How will you shoulder the burden of your foresight?
UNLOCKED $1300—Six new locations for Journey Path
At $1300, we’ll add six new locations to the game: a whole second Journey Path to give you more variation and replayability! In the game as it appeared in Codex: Home, we included these locations:
The Steel-Sown Field
The Great Sapphire Bridge
The Frozen Maw of the Earth
The Torchlit Swamplands
The Labyrinthine Canyon
The Toadstool Forest
If we hit this stretch goal, we’ll double the number of locations with another half-dozen sites for your fellowship’s journey.
UNLOCKED $2500—Hand-drawn map of the journey home 
When we reach $2500, we’ll commission a map from Stentor Danielson (check out their work at Mapsburgh) which will include all 12 Journey locations that you’ve unlocked.
All pledge tiers will receive a printable PDF of the map, which we encourage you and your players to annotate along the way. By the end of your adventure, you’ll have a record of your game that looks like what one of your characters may have left behind to inspire another generation of adventurers.
As for the print-tiers, we’ll be adding the map as the endpapers to the zine, so that the moment you open the game, you’ll get your first glimpse of the Broken Land, and what lies beyond it.
UNLOCKED $3200—Meguey Baker writes The Haunted
If we reach $3200, Meguey Baker of NightSkyGames will be creating The Haunted playbook for Back Again from the Broken Land. Meguey is the designer of Psi*Run and 1001 Nights, and the co-creator of Under Hollow Hills and, of course, Apocalypse World. The Haunted playbook is for a character hailed as a hero but plagued by doubts: “Was it enough, did you really achieve what you set out to do?”
UNLOCKED $3800—Print-and-play Deck of Details
Back Again from the Broken Land comes with a list of evocative details for the players to draw on. Whenever you start to tell a story, you can incorporate a detail like:
Fire climbing a house like vines
Oars scattering silver water in the dawnlight
The face of a friend under the cloak of a stranger
A drink with the scent of shorn grass
 When you draw on one of these details in a story you tell, you take Advantage on your roll.
At $3800 we’ll add a print-and-play PDF deck of these details for backers at all levels. The deck makes it easier to consider your options, and can even be a tool for setting the tone of the game.
 UNLOCKED $4400—Original Poem
We love the iconic poems that open great fantasy novels (“Three rings for the elven kings…” “When the Dark comes rising, six shall turn it back…”) and we think your game of Back Again from the Broken Land deserves an opening like that.
At $4400, we will write an original poem, “The Lay of the Broken Land,” and include it in the zine.That means backers at all levels will get to enjoy an evocative verse from Alexi Sargeant, co-designer of the game and sometime paid sonneteer.
UNLOCKED $5000—Epidiah Ravichol writes The Imposter
if we reach $5000, Epidiah Ravichol will create The Imposter, a stretch goal playbook for Back Again from the Broken Land. Epidiah Ravichol is a seasoned creator of indie games, responsible for the Jenga-based horror game Dread and the swords-and-sorcery blockbuster Swords Without Master.  The Imposter is someone who got swept up into the fellowship only because they were impersonating a folk hero for personal gain, but has since (perhaps?) found the hero within.
UNLOCKED $6000—Interior playbook art from Emily Cheeseman
If we reach $6000, our cover artist Emily Cheeseman will also create interior art. She’ll do portraits for all nine of the included playbooks. Take a look at Emily's gallery to see why we're so excited about this prospect!
UNLOCKED $7500—Pay raise for everyone
If we reach $7,500, everyone working on the project will get a raise. We’re thrilled about what our collaborators have brought to the game, and we want to share more of the profits with our fellowship. At that goal, we’ll boost rates for everyone by 10% or $50, whichever is greater.
UNLOCKED! $10,000—Music for "The Lay of the Broken Land"
At $10,000, we’ll sing in celebration—literally. If we hit that final goal, we will hire a musician to set “The Lay of the Broken Land” to music. Backers at all levels will receive the final recording.
Social Goal: 25 #BackAgainStories on Twitter—Recipe PDF
Learn about #BackAgainStories here. If we get 25 of them, we’ll send all backers a PDF of a soup recipe—something the adventurers tore in haste from a cookbook back home and brought along on their journey. The recipe will be something tasty you can make for real in your home, and the page will also have marginalia from an adventurer with modifications made to the recipe on the long journey.
Cloven Pine Games is an indie game design house. Check out all our games here on itch.io, and follow us on Twitter @ClovenPineGames.
Alexi Sargeant (co-designer) is an award-winning game designer creating indie roleplaying games under the banner of Cloven Pine Games. When he's not running or playing games, he's a writer and editor living in Princeton, New Jersey. He's contributed design to games like Trophy and Urban Shadows: Second Edition. His game 002: License to Eavesdrop was a winner of the 2019 200 Word RPG Challenge. His game Secret Science Sewer Siblings was nominated for an ENnie Award, and his game The Great Soul Train Robbery was nominated for an Indie Groundbreaker Award.
Leah Sargeant (co-designer) is an author and freelance writer interested in theology, hospitality, and statistics. She is the creator of the RPG Bring Home the Babe, a game for one player and one GM about bargaining with the fey to rescue your baby sibling. She also created This is Not a Place of Honor, a GMless game about creating safeguards around a terrible danger and watching them change and crumble over time. Her games can be found at Sea Change Games on itchio.
Meguey Baker (stretch goal writer) first heard The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings trilogy read aloud at age 6, about a year before she started playing D&D. Since then, she has wandered many places and had many adventures there and back again, including co-designing Apocalypse World and a host of other games with her husband of 30 years, Vincent Baker. She currently has three children all taller than her, three cats of various sizes, and three sewing machines.
Epidiah Ravichol (stretch goal writer) is an author and game designer known for Dread, Swords Without Master, and his fiction published in the sword and sorcery magazine Worlds Without Master. He resides in the Northeast of the United States of America with his wife and fellow game designer Emily Care Boss and his calculator collection.
Emily Cheeseman (cover and interior artist) is an illustrator inspired by fantasy, folklore, and tales of adventure. She works as a freelance artist based out of Orlando, Florida. Find her work at emilycheeseman.com.
Todd Crapper (layout artist) is a graphic designer and a two-time ENnie-award-winning game designer for Killshot: The Director’s Cut and High Plains Samurai: Legends. He's also a freelancer game and graphic designer for other publishers such as Third Eye Games, NerdBurger Games, and many more. Currently living in the middle of nowhere over an hour outside of Ottawa, he’s currently working on future games like Pandora: Total Destruction, Ironbound: Guardians of Novala, Survival of the Able, and many more. And he’s eager to talk about games, play games, smell games… ok, maybe just the first two. You can learn more about his games at brokenrulergames.net
Stentor Danielson (map artist) is a cartographer, cat wrangler, and environmental studies professor based out of Pittsburgh. Find more of their cartography work at mapsburgh.com, and check out the games they designed at playglittercats.com.

Risks and challenges
The core game is written and playtested. We'll be playtesting a few updates and expanded playbooks before we move to layout. This is Cloven Pine Game's second Zinequest Kickstarter, and we've used our first experience to come up with a more realistic timeline. In our first outing, we were delayed by three main factors—the global pandemic, learning to do layout start to finish for the first time, and the birth of our first baby—just two weeks before Zinequest began. 

This time around, we expect things will be smoother on *nearly* every front—we and our collaborators have adjusted to quarantine life, layout training for The Great Soul Train Robbery means we're approaching the work with confidence, and as for the baby... well, she's sleeping more but is big enough to pull our games off our shelves and eat them, so it's a wash.

Overall, we know more about how to pace ourselves through production, and we're confident about our projected timeline.

campaign.story:
Hi, I'm Richard. I'm a farmer, educator and regenerative agriculture expert dedicated to helping folks make a good living farming, and live a good life whilst being of benefit to the whole.
Chances are you’re here because you know me as the co-owner and director of Ridgedale Farm, from Youtube, or as the author of the groundbreaking manual Regenerative Agriculture, which raised over €380,000 in pre-sales on Kickstarter a year ago.
Having built up a wonderful and sincere following on social media and through my previous work, I want to use my platform to shine a light on some of the unsung heroes who are doing pioneering work and changing the face of local integrity food production.
In 2020 we interviewed around 70 of Europe's leading regenerative farmers, including many of our past students. I recently decided to compile their stories, in their own words, into a physical book. I had not initially planned to do this, but whilst putting together an ebook to accompany the summer tour, I was so touched and moved by the passion, innovation, and dedication of all that people were sharing.
I want this book to be the first of a series, and so this Kickstarter serves as a 'proof of concept'. If there is a demand to bring this into print, I can imagine creating at least 1 or 2 further books as part of the project.

What is in the book?
The draft of the book has already been created; and at around 275 pages, it features more than 40 European farmers across all manner of scales and different types of production. From vegetable growers to holistic graziers, pastured poultry to on-farm butchery; it's got a breadth of farms from less than a hectare up to hundreds of hectares. We gave the farmers a basic outline to structure their writing, but wanted people to also tell their stories in their own voices. To summarize, the book contains the 'do's, the don'ts and data' from all these incredible farms. The stories tell about land acquisition, investments, design, enterprise development, tricks and tips, economy, and advice for others following in their footsteps.

Who is this book for?
This book is an incredible resource for;
People wanting to start a career in regenerative farming.
Regenerative farmers who are in the first years of their enterprise and are seeking inspiration, camaraderie, and insight into what others are doing.
Existing farmers seeking to overhaul their business and land plans into smarter and more ecologically positive models.
Educators in the field.
Why I think it is important
There is something vital about hearing from a diversity of people with entirely different budgets, access to land, visions, and contexts as well as cultural opportunities and limitations. People very easily get too focused on 'internet celebrities' and fall into the trap of thinking things 'need to look a certain way'. I want to support, connect, and uplift some of the amazing people you might never hear about, and normalize the reality that things can look anyway!
There is something very important about observing the first years of implementing farms and businesses that are lost later into maturity. The first years at Ridgedale allowed us to offer the most influential and powerful training in the field, and I have been acutely aware of exposing people to these early developmental phases. To hear reports, reflections, and advice from hundreds of other farmers across all contexts is a very powerful thing.
We need stronger communication and deeper sharing across the network. I have witnessed the power of promoting and connecting other farmers and wish to continue this.
As a leader in this field, I am constantly asked for references to people doing certain farming practices in different countries. These books aim to be a resource documenting all the best examples.
What are the next steps?
I have already successfully self-published two books and sold them to over 90 countries around the world over the last few years. We are running this Kickstarter to gauge interest in this book upfront, so we know that we can afford a print run.
If the interest is there, I would like to make the second book (also focused on Europe) in the next few months.
If this goes well I would like to make a third book focused on the USA/Canada, where a large part of my following is located, and where we have had quite an influence.
If that goes well I would consider a follow-up book covering other areas.
  2020 showed the fragility of many fundamental systems to people all over the globe, even to those who were not already aware. Yet what I heard consistently over the year interviewing regenerative farmers was 2-300% increases in sales. There's never been a better time to get into farming, and the demand for local integrity food is constantly growing. I dedicated my life to documenting and sharing smart ways to go about farming as a business whilst restoring soils and ecosystems and producing better products than any store can offer. Now it's time to share the stories of many of our students and others who have forged their own place in regenerative farming.

A note on shipping
Shipping physical books globally is not without its challenges. You'd probably be amazed how often books are delayed, damaged, or actually just disappear. Shipping from Sweden is extremely expensive, and throughout 2020 with COVID the postal services in different countries seemed to have somewhat of a meltdown, with delivery times reaching up to 3 months. We recently had a record of a book showing up 6 months later! Because of this, we are now switching over to FedEx to be able to offer much quicker shipping, tracking, and hopefully better-handled books. Let's hope it is a good choice!
Thanks for checking this out!
Richard

Pyramid was the monthly PDF magazine for serious gamers, created by serious gamers. Each month, Pyramid delivered articles about a specific theme, from modern-day superheroes to post-apocalyptic gaming to magic on the battlefield. Most of Pyramid's articles are either generic, suitable for your game system of choice, or designed for GURPS, one of the best choices for serious gamers for over 20 years.
During the magazine's PDF run (Volume Three), each issue of Pyramid was devoted to one of three general themes: past, present, and future.
Now, with your support, we're launching the newest incarnation of this gaming magazine! Pyramid Volume Four, if this campaign is successful, will continue where the previous volume left off – with three new PDF issues covering the three classic themes of past, present, and future.
NOTE: This campaign is for three new issues only and is not a promise of any issues beyond those produced as part of this Kickstarter project. If there is enough interest and demand, we may return to Kickstarter in the future to expand Volume Four beyond these three issues.

Tough Poets Press is thrilled to start the new year off by publishing a new expanded edition of one of the most unique American novels ever written—Mangled Hands by Johnny Stanton. This book truly defies description, but here's an excerpt from the back cover of the original 1985 Sun & Moon Press edition:
"For years, Manged Hands was passed among New York poets and fiction writers in manuscript form, and its author, Johnny Stanton, developed an underground reputation as one of the most gifted writers of the generation directly influenced by the New York Poets. . . . Mangled Hands stands between Laurence Sterne's Tristram Shandy and Gabriel Garcia Marquez's One Hundred Years of Solitude in style and spirit."
Left: Cover of the new Tough Poets Press edition of MANGLED HANDS / Right: Author Johnny Stanton, mid-1980s (Photo by Anthony J Morenzi)
I could only find one online review of the novel from the year it was originally published. This is what the Washington Post had to say:
"Johnny Stanton's Mangled Hands is such an oddity that it confounds description or comparison. . . . Mangled Hands is so unusual and original that many readers with a serious interest in fiction will find it liberating." (Click here to read the full review.)
And here are some excerpts from reviews found on Amazon and Goodreads:
"This is perhaps the strangest, most visceral and mind-warping thing I’ve ever read." // "A singular reading experience." // "As mad as it may seem to the conventional reader, this is a strange and wonderful novel that any purveyors of strange fiction should not miss." // "It is a subliminal life changing book." // "Great, great book . . . that brings to mind Burroughs and H Miller."
ABOUT THE NEW EDITION
This new edition of Mangled Hands contains the complete text of the 1985 edition published by Sun & Moon Press. Also included is a new introduction and recent interview with Stanton and his wife, the poet Elinor Nauen, by George Salis.   
Book Specifications
Format: Paperback
Pages: 312
Dimensions: 8.27" x 5.83" x 0.78"
Weight: 0.75 lbs.
ABOUT JOHNNY STANTON
Johnny Stanton was born in 1943 in Manhattan, the son of Irish immigrants from Galway. He was an altar boy and Eagle Scout who attended Catholic schools and eventually graduated from Columbia University, where he fell in with many poets and writers of the New York School, including Kenneth Koch, Ted Berrigan, Ron Padgett, and Paul Auster. He published many of them, some for the first time, in his Siamese Banana Press, which started as a newspaper in 1972 and ended as a performance gang in 1978. He is the author of many short stories and the novel Mangled Hands, neglected by critics yet highly acclaimed by the readers who discover it. He has lived in the East Village for 30 years with his wife, the poet Elinor Nauen, a cat (currently Lefty), and a lot of art. (Source: George Salis's review of Mangled Hands on The Collidescope: https://thecollidescope.com/2020/09/27/mangled-hands-by-johnny-stanton/)
WHERE THE MONEY WILL GO
As with all my previous Kickstarter projects, my goal is simply to break even and get the book out there. For this campaign to be successful, I will need to raise $1,717. In the interest of full disclosure, here's how it all breaks down, assuming 101 U.S. pledges of $17 each:

ABOUT TOUGH POETS PRESS
Tough Poets Press, founded in 2015, is a one-person independent publisher of new and rediscovered offbeat and neglected literary fiction, poetry, and non-fiction. To date, I've published 27 books, 26 of them thanks to the generous support of the Kickstarter community. Tough Poets Press was featured last fall in Publishers Weekly in an article titled "The One-Man Press Resuscitating Forgotten Classics." Read it here: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/81830-the-one-man-press-resuscitating-forgotten-classics.html

campaign.story:
Hello again! I'm a visual artist obsessed with art technology, and more specifically the alchemy of hand-prepared, natural materials. From the most precious blue that has to travel all the way from Afghan mountains, to the humble and bountiful acorn, the making of colour to write or paint with is a magical process. Last year I made a book dedicated to historical art materials: Inks & Paints of the Middle-East, and you can check out the project and updates for a clear idea of what to expect from Wild Inks. This year, the focus is on preparing colours from foraged plants—and some kitchen scraps—but also all sorts of art-useful products that can also be homemade, from glue to bamboo pens.
Wild Inks is a very approachable handbook even for beginners, but it covers all the ground that a professional would want to know. Before starting on colour materials, you will learn about natural binders (why, what, how), colour modifiers, preservation, as well as what to expect from botanicals in terms of longevity (and ways to extend it, if any). You'll learn how to identify and prepare the plants covered, as well as how they can be stored for later use (if possible). 
The obvious weakness of such a book is its connection to place: the materials it covers are those I can forage or obtain in the South-East of england where I live. They tend to be common from West Asia to North America, but that leaves out a large part of the planet: however, these other ecosystems do have counterparts to my local plants, containing the same pigments. Therefore it's especially important to clarify the chemistry behind it all, so that the methods can be tried on anything, anywhere.
Foraging (responsibly) is a wonderful practice, and also a deeply reassuring one in a world that's become so volatile and frankly insane: the cycle of seed, blossom, fruit and seed again proceeds no matter what, year after year. Falling into step with seasonality is equally transformative and an antidote to the artificially fast pace that is inflicted upon us. The practice of making one's own materials expands an artist's creative process, but it also cuts down on plastic and the chemical processes by which synthetic colours are prepared. Many of the pigments covered in my previous book are toxic minerals, but nothing hazardous is involved in Wild Inks. This means responsible children, who can be trusted to follow instructions and not put things in their mouth, can take part in the gathering and preparation.
The book's outline is still growing, but here's where it stands at the time of launch. Recipes/how-tos are included for everything that can be made:
PART 1: INTRO
Foraging ethics
Tools
Safety
Binders
Modifiers
Wet and dry preservation
Lakes
Testing for lightfastness
PART 2: DYE PLANTS
Chemistry of plant colours
Dye extraction
SPRING PLANTS
SUMMER PLANTS
AUTUMN  PLANTS
WINTER PLANTS
INGREDIENTS FROM THE PANTRY
Dyeing paper
PART 3: PIGMENTS (Forageable or home-makeable only)
Ochres
Whites
Blacks
PART 4: SUNDRIES
Bamboo pens
Quill pens
Glue
Soap
Sample info page (may evolve as we go)
In terms of rewards, I'm following last year's tiers closely but keeping it simple more than ever. Postage has been raised three times over the past year and I have a feeling it's not over. I don't want folks to part with more money than strictly necessary, so I've planned all the reward tiers, save the highest, to fit the cheaper Large Letter postal format. If backers want more add-on items, these can be looked into and added to the campaign along the way.
Finally, I shared a lot of work processes and experiments in my updates last year, and you can expect more of that this time around!

It’s rude to constantly express your impatience, frustration, and anger. So, let the Peeved Paisleys do it for you.
The design of this bandana features oodles of paisleys who are clearly peeved, aggravated, and irked. 
A seemingly serene symmetrical design contains plenty of peeveded paisleys.
Like my previous BADbandanas, I’m going to reproduce this drawing as a 21-inch square bandana. With white paisleys on a dignified gray background, these bandanas will be 100 percent cotton printed right here in the good-old USA using duplex printing like the quality bandanas I grew up with. (Dyed—not that obnoxious silkscreening we all hate.)
What do you get? Each bandana contains a couple dozen annoyed paisleys combined in a serenely symmetrical composition that is an homage to the classic bandanas of the past.
Package of three. (Makes a great gift.)
Packed in sets of three so you’ll have spares for gift giving. Bandanas make convenient masks to discourage inconvenient viruses and they have many uses in fashion, personal hygiene, and pet decoration. No one is going to want just one. So I’m offering reward levels of BADbandanas in packs of three.

Don says, “I love traditional bandanas but they need more pizzazz. I doubt you have any bandanas in your drawer quite like this—peeved paisleys!” 
BADbandanas make superb gifts. Even if you aren’t a big fan of bandanas, you may want to get a bunch to share. Great gifts for friends, family, neighbors who are angry, annoyed, or vexed.
Do you need a reminder of how you can use your BADbandanas?
Don and dog model BADbandana uses. (Don’s the one wearing glasses.)

What the critics are saying...
 “A perfect expression of my current mood. This design is ideal for these troubled times.” 
“One can never have too many clean bandanas.”
 “Excellent gift for friends—especially those who are miffed...and who isn’t?” 
 “Is that pizza sauce on your chin? No problem. Mop it up with your BADbandana.”
 “A perfect blend of silly and practical. An enhancement to any wardrobe.” 

SCHEDULE
Lightning fast. If there are no calamities, you should have your BADbandanas by April, 2021. Perhaps sooner. Sponsors of this project will receive periodic updates through Kickstarter as the project unfolds.
SHIPPING
Just the local neighborhood. Because shipping is extra slow and troublesome these days, we are limiting rewards to residents of the U.S. and Canada only. Later, some extras of these BADbandanas will be available at our online store. So, anyone excluded from the Kickstarter project will be able to get Peeved Paisleys there.
Tracking. You will receive a tracking number when we ship, so track your package daily to make sure it doesn’t get hung up in the system and returned to us. Don’t just assume it will show up at your door. Shipments have a way of getting stalled, and monitoring the status of the tracking number allows you to intervene promptly.
Customs. Sometimes, but not always, shipments to Canada get hit with customs duties. I have no way of predicting if they’ll apply to your shipment. Customs inspections are very arbitrary and willy-nilly. Most packages sail through without any duty, but some are selected seemingly by chance and the recipient gets hit with a duty fee. So if you can’t tolerate the risk that your shipment might get selected for extra costs, you should probably not support this project. Or arrange to have your reward shipped to a friend in the U.S. who can bring your Peeved Paisleys during their next trip.
Shipping is provided by our capable and multi-talented partners at Fulfillrite. Our Fulfillrite friends are fast and they do things right the first time.
Where are you? When the rewards are ready to ship, we’ll send out a Kickstarter address survey. If you don’t respond to that survey within 6 months, we’ll assume you no longer want your reward. I don’t have the space to hold your reward in perpetuity or until the cows come home.

LOOSE ENDS
Updates and progress reports. Sponsors of this project will receive periodic updates through Kickstarter as the project unfolds but not so often that you think I’m an obnoxious pest.
Questions? Send me your questions and I’ll add them and the answers to the FAQ section at the bottom of this page.
Thanks for your amazing support.
Leftovers from my previous Kickstarter projects are available while supplies last at www.calamityware.com. Not only is this a good place to find some unusual gifts, but it is the only place you’ll find the world’s greatest shower curtain.
Don—Pittsburgh, January 6, 2021

campaign.story:
U-JOINTS project
An international research project on the theme of connections in design and architecture.
A joint – the union of two or more parts – is a fundamental element in almost any designed object, be it a famous bridge, the coffee maker in your kitchen, or a revolving office chair.
The joint comes in every possible size and material: nanoscale or the size of a room; plastic, steel, carbon fibre, wood or wool. A joint might be ingeniously engineered or the result of garage tinkering. Designers, architects and engineers alike appropriate standard connectors; they assemble and personalise them. Sometimes, they invent new joinery from scratch. Truly multivalent, the joint is the kind of detail that holds the world together.
But because a joint is often invisible, hidden elegantly within an object, it can be overlooked. U-JOINTS sheds light on these hidden details in an in-depth survey of joints.

U-JOINTS - Equations of a universal lifestyle exhibition, Salone del Mobile, Milano, 2018 ©Delfino Sisto Legnani
U-JOINTS - Equations of a universal lifestyle exhibition, Salone del Mobile, Milano, 2018 ©Delfino Sisto Legnani
U-JOINTS background
The U-JOINTS research project was initiated in 2018 with an exhibition. Called U-JOINTS – Equations of universal life, it took shape as an eclectic introduction to the topic of connections. Curators Andrea Caputo and Anniina Koivu broke joints open, organised them by material and production processes, reassembled them into prototypes, and used them in real-world applications. For eight days, U-Joints featured 919 exhibits by 50 international designers and industry professionals. On show was everything from the most common joints to design’s most innovative ones, as well as those that have had the greatest influence on contemporary design and architecture.
Encouraged by the exhibition’s success and the remarkable attention and endorsement it garnered, the team launched an extensive research challenge: a comprehensive review of the world’s joints and how they hold things together.
Employing an inclusive and collective approach from the very beginning, the ongoing research is shared with the public through a series of exhibitions in which contemporary designers, researchers, institutions and critics are invited to share their work with joinery.
Each show reads like the chapter of a book.
In 2019, A taxonomy of nails, screws, rivets, bolts and nuts looked at basic fasteners and was held at Galerie l’elac of ECAL/University of Art and Design Lausanne in Switzerland.
Next, Adhesives and Fusions will open to the public on 6 March 2021 at the Gewerbemuseum Winterthur. Further exhibitions are being planned.
Finally, after almost three years of work, we are excited to launch our comprehensive book on the topic. U-Joints – A taxonomy of connections will come out in 2021.
U-JOINTS - A taxonomy of nails, screws, rivets, bolts and nuts exhibition, ECAL, Lausanne 2019 ©Calypso Mahieu
U-JOINTS - A taxonomy of nails, screws, rivets, bolts and nuts exhibition, ECAL, Lausanne 2019 ©Calypso Mahieu
 U-JOINTS  the book
U-JOINTS – A taxonomy of connections is an encyclopedic publication that looks at human history through its details, and invites us to see our built environment in whole new ways.
Weighing in at more than 900 pages, this is the most far-reaching book ever published on the topic of joints. Comprehensive and interdisciplinary, the book features technical information about joinery as well as stories and commentaries. The heart of the book is a vast taxonomy of more than 1300 joints, organized into six main chapters: Basic fasteners, Mechanical joints, Knits and Knots, Wood joints, Adhesives, and Fused joints.
Each chapter traces the macrocosm of joinery. Together, they create a vast overview of the most common joints as well as insight into joinery’s unique solutions, historical and contemporary. Little known surprises and forgotten connecting methods abound.
Furthermore, the book features 80 essays and interviews, as well as 120 anecdotes. These share the often-unknown stories of joints, from how they were invented to their many inventive applications. The book also includes more than 1000 images, 240 illustrations and numerous patents. 15 new photographic works by young and upcoming photographers reframe the overlooked details for readers to discover.
The book was compiled by a team of more than 50 authors, photographers, illustrators, researchers, experts, scholars, scientists and story tellers, enthusiasts, users, designers, architects, artists, writers and critics, dreamers and makers. Together we hope to bring the many fascinating facets of joints to life.
This is a prototype. The final cover and product may slightly differ. ©Margot Sparkes


This is a prototype. The final cover and product may slightly differ.
A sample spread of the Taxonomy section, featuring more than 1300 joints and connections.
The Taxonomy includes most common joints as well as unique solutions from history. ©Margot Sparkes
Photographers were commissioned to shed light on the often hidden details of an object.
A new generation of photographers produced more than 15 portfolios of joints and connections.
More than 50 authors contributed essays and interviews with international architects, designers, artists, inventors, scholars, makers and users of well-designed products and architectures.
The publication includes more than 80 in-depth articles on connections in design, architecture and art.
Eleonora Castellarin is the mastermind behind the extensive Taxonomy.
Graphic Thought Facility created the straightforward and simple layout that presents an immensity of information effortlessly.
Contributors, subjects and authors include: AATB, Johanna Agermann Ross, Anni Albers, Florian Amoser, Ant Farm, Ron Arad, Archigram, Inés Ariza, ARUP, Clifford Ashley, Margherita Banchi, Anne Bates, Luca Becchetti, Elizabeth Bisley, Philippe Block, Raul Gonzales Bravo, Barbara Brondi, Franco Bulian, Gabriela Burkhalter, Marianne Burkhalter, Jacques Carelman, Marco Casino, Charlie Chaplin, Pierre Charpin, Brendan Cormier, Matthieu Cortat, Marco Costantini, Thomas Demand, Benjamin Dillenburger, Pierre Doze, Delphine Drouin-Prouvé, Norman Foster, Buckminster Fuller, Fabrizio Gallanti, Ilaria Giannetti, Fabio Gramzio, Susanne Graner, Sam Grawe, Maxime Guyon, Sebastian Hackenschmidt, James Hennessey, Yngve Holen, Clare Hunter, Dylan Iwakuni, Philippe Johnson, Hella Jongerius, Jane Joyce, Hettie Judah, Eliyahu Keller, Ruby Kitching, Matthias Kohler, Kengo Kuma, Shiro Kuramata, Tiffany Lambert, Mike Lane, Sergio Leone, Liam, Daisy and Dave, Miles Lewis, Vico Magistretti, Enzo Mari, Michael Marriott, Allegra Martin, Sally McGrane, Angus McGuyver, Alberto Meda, Leonardo Mosso, Marc Newson, Claes Oldenburg, Damian Ortega, Victor Papanek, Des Pawson, Gaetano Pesce, Tom F. Peters, Philippe Petit, Marta Pezzoli, Francesca Picchi, Mariana Popescu, Jean Prouvé, Piercarlo Quecchia, Marco Rainò, Peter Rice, Peter Lymburner Robertson, Richard Rogers, Nadja Rottner, Simone Sandahl, Delfino Sisto Legnani, Bruce Sterling, Oli Stratford, Deyan Sudjic, Christian Sumi, Superstudio, Skylar Tibbits, Margaret Tudor, Alice Twemlow, Jonas Villinger, Justinas Vilutis, Konrad Wachsmann, Hans Wegner, Yves Weinand, Richard Wiborg, Mark Whitby, Lebbeus Woods, Frank Lloyd Wright, Marco Zanuso, Peter Zumthor, and many more!

Each chapter constitutes a proposal: by looking at particular details, we can help you understand the constructed world a little better. As a result, this publication is many things: a manual in a workshop, an encyclopedic reference guide for scholars and design enthusiasts, as well as an indispensable resource for students of architecture and design.

 U-JOINTS press and comments
Paola Antonelli, senior curator, MoMA: "U-Joints has been my favorite stop in Design Week. Curated by Andrea Caputo and Anniina Koivu, it is an outstanding exhibition on joints and connections. It features an obsessive taxonomy and a thorough timeline. Unadulterated curatorial delight!”
Alice Rawsthorn, design expert: “You may never confuse a clamp with a coupling, or a dovetail with a rivet again.”
Alice Stori, design curator: “If you have to see one thing this Salone make it the U-Joints exhibition curated by Andrea Caputo and Anniina Koivu! Every designer and design student should bring their sketch book and get down to basics.”
Zoë Ryan, director of the Institute of Contemporary Art, University of Pennsylvania: “U-Joints […] examines a multitude of simply that – ways to join things together – through 50 designers’ experiments, prototypes and products. Great show.”
Disegno magazine: “Curators Andrea Caputo and Anniina Koivu are to be applauded. On paper, their pitch for U-Joins sounds dry and inaccessible: an exhibition examining a history of the joint and other connecting technologies within design. The results, however, are anything but. U-Joints is engrossing and animated, while nonetheless not shirking the inherent technicality and geekery of its subject matter; it manages the delicate balance of being both a real designer’s design exhibition, while also remaining of interest to a general audience.”
Modern Design Review: “U-Joints is not only one of the best shows of this year’s Salone, it’s one of the best shows to be presented at the Salone for a long time.”

Format: 21x26.9 cm (8,25x10,59 in)
Volume: 900+ pages
Language: English

Project planning  

Editors
Andrea Caputo is an architect and researcher living in Milan. He combines his professional practise with ongoing research in the architectural and urban planning fields, and has published numerous editorial projects and articles. In 2011, Andrea opened his award-winning architecture studio in Milan and three years later, in 2017, he opened another in Shanghai. His work is recognised for its unexpected solutions, often juxtaposing different materials, which draw attention to the smallest of architectural details. The studio works internationally, developing complex projects on all scales, in collaboration with a qualified network of specialist consultants. His first investigation into urban culture’s aesthetic and social influences was published as All City Writers (Critique Livre, 2009) and soon became a sought-after reference work for street culture. From 2018-19, he edited Domus magazine's "Studio Visit" column, which explored contemporary architecture studios’ practices. Currently, Andrea’s studio is engaged on behalf of the Vastushilpa Foundation of Ahmedabab to conduct a vast survey on the architecture of Balkrishna Doshi, Pritzker Prize 2018. https://www.andreacaputo.com

Anniina Koivu is a design writer, curator, consultant and teacher, who divides her time between Milan and Lausanne. She works across a number of fields, from curation to art direction, product development, and editorial and research projects, which she develops for clients such as Kvadrat, Iittala, Vitra, Camper and the Shorefast Foundation of Fogo Island. Her latest publication is Vico Magistretti: Stories of Objects (Ecal/Triest, 2020), the result of an investigation of the little-considered moment in the lifespan of design products when production ends, with a focus on the reasons that lead up to this ‘death’ of the design object. She wrote the comprehensive monograph on Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec Works (Phaidon, 2011) and has edited and contributed to a number of publications such Materialising Colour: Journeys with Giulio Ridolfo (Phaidon, 2020), Atlas of Furniture Design (Vitra Design Museum, 2019), Industrial Facility (Phaidon, 2018), Arita 2016/ (Phaidon, 2017), The Walking Society (Lars Müller, 2015) and Pierre Charpin's Entre Les Vases (Birkhäuser, 2009) among others. Serving as editor-in-chief, Anniina launched the first print issue of Interwoven (Kvadrat, 2020), an (online) magazine on contemporary culture and independent criticism. Among her recent curatorial works are Tehdas – Fabrik – Factory (Fiskars Village Art & Design Biennale, 2019), an exhibition exploring the diversity of contemporary design production, and Typologie: the wine bottle and the cork stopper (Milan, 2019). She has been a speaker, moderator and juror at international design competitions and events. She is Head of Master Theory at University of Art and Design Lausanne ECAL. www.anniinakoivu.com
