campaign.story:
The problem:  Greenhouses in a cold climate need heat, so they consume energy and require human discipline. Plus, on a sunny day, they can get hot enough to kill everything inside.  
The solution:  We have a plan to create a greenhouse that requires no heat & will never overheat. We will use the heat from summer to keep the structure warm through winter. If we have excess heat, we will passively store it and save it for later - with no harm to the plants & no need for human discipline (See the designs below). We will build and test the greenhouse, share the progress interactively and make a movie about it.
 Once upon a time we created an event called “the Permaculture Technology Jamboree."  We made a podcast about all the cool stuff we were gonna do.  And then canceled it because of the pandemic. We went back to our regular projects, but some people seemed frustrated that one of the projects in particular would not be built RIGHT NOW! Eventually someone suggested that we do a Kickstarter for this project!
The idea started out pretty simply. We wanted to install a greywater system so water from a kitchen sink could go to plants instead of a septic tank. Except those plants will be dormant in winter - so any funky sink stuff would just build up and be gross.
How about if we made a small greenhouse? Greenhouses are famous for needing more heat than homes - all that glass is a very poor insulator. Plus they can get too hot on a sunny day and kill everything in the greenhouse.
Well, we have a lot of projects here doing amazing things to solve heating problems. So can we invent a greenhouse that never gets too cold or too hot? Maybe we can use some elements of Mike Oehler’s greenhouse design and some elements of our wofati design.  And maybe a few other ideas.
Our design starts with the general shape of Mike Oehler’s design from The Earth Sheltered Solar Greenhouse Book. He grew tomatoes in December, off-grid, with no heat of any kind, in Northern Idaho. The genius of his design includes 3 improvements over a traditional greenhouse.
basic greenhouse
 Improvement #1: reduce the size of the air space with a trench 
a basic greenhouse with a trench
Improvement #2: an earth berm on the north side (thus, some added insulation and less glass)   
an earth berm greenhouse
Improvement #3: most importantly, the 5 foot deep trench under the walkway.    
Oehler-style greenhouse
I have visited a dozen greenhouses that claimed to follow the Oehler design, only to discover that they were missing at least 2 of these elements.
I think that the trench adds a big dose of superpowers that most people overlook. If the deep ground temperature is a constant 50 degrees, then whenever the temperature in the greenhouse drops below 50, the 50 degree air from the trench will rise up & the colder air will sink down.
Before he died, I talked to Mike about another possible improvement:
Improvement #4: What if a copper pipe was blackened, shaped to follow the glass vertically and drop down to near the bottom of the trench. When the sun hits the greenhouse, the top of the pipe would heat up and act like a  straw to pull cold air from the bottom of the trench. Eventually, the hot air at the top of the greenhouse would be pulled into the trench and warm it. I called it a destratification pipe. Mike agreed that this would probably help a lot!    
destratification greenhouse
Improvement #5: A common farmer trick is to put 20 feet of well casing into the ground, then put a watering trough on top of that. When the outdoor temperature is negative 25 degrees (F), the water doesn't freeze. When the water gets cold, it cools the air at the top of the hole. So the 50 degree air from underground rises to the top & the colder air right below the trough sinks. There is so much air exchange that the water remains warm enough not to freeze. With this trick plus the previous improvements, maybe we can circulate enough heated air from the greenhouse through the pipe to get the temperature at the bottom of the hole closer to 70 degrees instead of 50!  
destratification greenhouse with well casing
Improvement #6: Our wofati house design attempts to use heat from summer to heat a home through winter. We do this by berming dry earth against & on top of the structure and keep it dry with a membrane we call “the umbrella." We are still experimenting with these structures, but so far they have had no freeze, even in our Montana winters. So let’s add dry dirt to the roof, the west side & the east side - and an umbrella to keep that thermal mass dry.    
wofati greenhouse
Improvement #7: Our original mission was to design a year-round greywater system for a cold climate. In this case, “the problem is the solution”: greywater tends to be warm. If part of the greenhouse is dedicated to accepting greywater, then there is a constant stream of warmth pouring into the greenhouse.
greywater greenhouse
full design of the greenhouse
We have the blueprints drawn up:
We have the people here now to do this project (click here to learn more about joining our permaculture bootcamp).
Permaculture Bootcamp at Wheaton Labs
We have experience designing & building structures like this. We have recently built this wofati:  
Allerton Abbey Wofati at Wheaton Labs
And this berm shed:  
Berm Shed at Wheaton Labs
 We have a strong preference for using materials that are already here (like trees and mud) rather than buying materials.
To pull off this greenhouse project, complete with video bits, we need . . .   
 Other Kickstarters offer "good vibes" or something at this level. To me, this might be the most important level. You are putting actual money into this project! And you are trusting me to come through in the future. This makes you super cool. And with all the ugly around, I just wanna tell you how glad I am that you are stepping up and doing good. Thanks. Thanks, thanks, thanks! I wish to express how grateful I am that you support me by providing you with something tangible. Many tangible, significant things.  
This will be a brand new short documentary about building our "berm shed" - a 1500 square foot shed made mostly out of trees from our property. An exploration of round wood timber framing joinery. It looks like a grassy hillside on one side and beautiful log-work on the other. Oodles of dry storage! 
The 17-podcast review of Gaia’s Garden by Toby Hemenway covers all the chapters of the amazing Gaia's Garden plus 4 podcasts of discussion with the late, great Toby Hemenway himself!  
This PEP ebook rough draft was created as a reward for last year's kickstarter. It is currently in a bit of a draft state, and the curriculum is still being developed. We are now working on a new book called SKIP (Skills to Inherit Property) that will include PEP and several other things. 
This book talks about Mike Oehler in his last years trying to find somebody with proven skills to will his land to - somebody who would really do something with it  after he died. 
"Permaculture Experience according to Paul" (PEP) is one of many possible parallel programs (PEN, PEJ, etc.) each with a different designer. And the program would consist of a list of short tasks which could be verified, one task at a time, for free, in order for a person to receive a PEP1 certification.  And then a person like Mike could  verify that someone they want to leave their land to has the skills to make good use of it. PEP already has a lot of interest from people with land and people looking for land.   
The 19 skiddable structures microdoc is a 36 minute movie about small skiddable structures. Lots of commentary about the structures & lessons learned 
The Wofati microdoc is a 30-minute video about wofatis in general, plus information on the current status of the two wofatis at Wheaton Labs. The greenhouse this Kickstarter is all about will be built next to Allerton Abbey, the smaller of the two.   
The Rocket Oven Cooking microdoc is from my kickstarter for the Rocket Ovens DVD. This short movie is about starting & tending a rocket oven, complete with footage of delicious food coming out of the oven. A rocket oven has a lower energy footprint than any other kind of oven. A rocket oven can run on nothing but the sticks that fall in your yard - truly off grid.
Hugelkultur: The microdoc is from the kickstarter for the 3-DVD set "World Domination Gardening.” This short movie covers hugelkultur, a gardening technique that builds amazing soil & can completely eliminate the need for irrigation. 12 different hugelkulturs are featured.  
Other Kickstarters offer "thanks" which is nothing, or post it to social media to be instantly forgotten. We post it to our thread at permies.com where we have perennial discussions. Thousands of people will actually look at the list for years to come. And we give you a chance to be as creative and as silly as you want. While some people will post their names, or their kids' names, or maybe plug their business, you can also divulge your plans for world domination and give yourself all the galactic titles you want. Check out the thanks page from the last Kickstarter and the one before that.
Building a Better World in Your Backyard, Instead of Being Angry at the Bad Guys was my 8th Kickstarter. This book is a rich collection of things you can do at home that make a huge, positive, global difference. Without politics or being angry at bad guys. This book focuses on adding luxury to your life instead of sacrifice. And the frosting on the cake is saving a lot of money. I believe that if 100 million people read my book, most global problems would disappear.  
"Ponds" is one of three movies in the World Domination Gardening DVD set. The cool thing is that we weren't even done building the pond when it rained on the second night of the workshop - and we woke up to a full pond. We finished the pond the next day, and there wasn't another drop of rain for four months - but there was still water in the pond. 
"Building a Cob Style Rocket Mass Heater" is a 2-hour movie from the 8-DVD Better Wood Heat: DIY Rocket Mass Heaters set. It features the build of the cob-style rocket mass heater at Cooper Cabin, and another cob-style rocket mass heater at the tipi. The coolest thing about the tipi footage is the interview with its occupants in the tipi at 26 degrees below zero (F). Spoiler: they were warm and toasty. 
Join our past Kickstarter supporters in a place where you can talk about stuff without the prying eyes of google or "them. 
You get the movie in HD streaming - the movie this Kickstarter is all about! You can watch it over and over for many years. 
Rather than wait until May for the whole movie, you get Part 1: Design in September, and Part 2: Build in November--and then in May you get the full movie, including Part 3: Test.
You can still watch the full movie in HD streaming whenever you want, but at this level you can also download the SD version. This smaller size is nice for cell phones and tablets. 
You will get formal plans (as a PDF) drafted by an engineer (Kyle) to convey the nitty-gritty details to you.
You will get to watch (at least!) three full design meetings, and find out the thought processes, science, & engineering behind the design. There will be at least one design meeting focusing on the greywater system with our expert Art Ludwig, author of Create an Oasis with Greywater. And there will be at least one design meeting focusing on the roundwood timber framing joinery.
Each Friday at 3 PM, there will be a formal build review session with the builders, on-site. This could include some video of the progress to that point. We will attempt to have this video available to you within a few days.
You can still watch it in HD streaming whenever you want, but at this level you can also download the SD version and/or the HD version. Nice for off-line viewing.   
This is the level for people who want to participate in the process.
In the trailing credits we will say something like "Thanks to our Kickstarter supporters!" And your name will be there! You can be as silly or as official as you like. Include a web site if you want. You will be limited to 65 characters.
In the first week after the Kickstarter, the plan is to do three design meetings using Zoom.
Each Friday at 3 PM (Mountain Time) during the build, our build leaders will pause and take an hour or two to participate in a live update with you. 
Each Monday and Wednesday afternoon at 3 PM (Mountain Time) during the build, somebody here will hold a Zoom session via cell phone to give people updates and answer questions.  
The greenhouse project is happening about 40 feet away from Allerton Abbey. You will get to participate in a Zoom call informal tour of Allerton Abbey, the new greenhouse, and all the gardens.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my 9th Kickstarter, so I have a lot of experience down this road. We have built a lot of roundwood timber-framed structures, and we have made a LOT of videos. At the same time, my experience is that it is wise to get 80% of the work done before doing the Kickstarter. But this is a different flavor of Kickstarter - this was something where people said “Don’t do the boring things you are doing! We wanna see you do this cool thing instead!” “Well, I don’t really have the time and coin to do that right now.” “We’ll give you monies and stuff!” “Really? How much are we talking about here?” And that conversation quickly led to “Do a kickstarter! You’ll see!” 

Once funded, we will have about 95% of the work left to do. That’s a big bite. So I’m nervous about the many flavors of comedy to come. Especially with a lot of innovation mixed in. I think we will be fine because of our experience, but when you ask about “risks and challenges,” I have to say that I prefer to start the Kickstarter with only 20% of the final project left to do.

campaign.story:
Candlelight is a role playing game about the restless spirits of treasure hunters reckoning with their dark past and seeking hope in a haunted forest that wants to trap them there. It is a one-shot, rules-light game, focusing on collaborative and thematic storytelling and is designed to be flexible in how you bring it to the table:
An epilogue for any fantasy game following character death - especially a TPK!
A world-building prologue for any game needing a haunted forest or other cursed place. 
A stand-alone game exploring themes of dark fantasy and supernatural horror - with a glimmering of hope and redemption. 
(Test print. Dice, adventuring equipment and escape from the forest not included).
 Candlelight is a game for 1 or more players and a GM. Character creation is simple, taking place as part of the game introduction. The game uses six-sided dice of 2 colors (light and dark) and each session runs approximately 3-4 hours. While the game is based on dark fantasy and horror themes, conversations about player expectations and the use of safety tools are encouraged to best fit the tone of game you want at the table. Ghost stories can be bleak, dreadful, terrifying - but also reflective, inspiring and even hopeful. The paths you choose through the forest are up to you and your group.
Candlelight is Rooted in Trophy, using the core system of Trophy Dark to tell as story of desperate characters pushing their luck in a place that constantly threatens to overwhelm them. The key difference here is that the characters have already met their doom - while Trophy Dark progresses through a series of Rings and escalating horror, Candlelight starts at that final Ring where the characters have just died. It is at the dark heart of the forest that they will begin their journey, retracing the steps they took while living, seeking hope and an escape from the forest before they become a monstrosity that haunts it forever.
To explore a wide range of fantasy-horror stories, Candlelight is compatible with any of the incursions (scenarios) from Trophy Dark. Detailed instructions are included for adapting your favorite Trophy Dark incursion for Candlelight, and any character creation options from Trophy are easily transferrable to Candlelight.
The following are some of the core mechanics adapted from Trophy Dark:
 Occupations are now Memories, skills or significant experiences from your life.
Your Doom is similar to a Background (an insight gained from the way you died).
 Rituals are now Dirges, terrible outpourings of anguish and dread that have the power to alter the physical world around the spirits.
 Risk Rolls work much the same, although spirits are much weaker without their physical bodies...
 Ruin Rolls are called Reckonings and work similarly - occasionally used as flashbacks to learn what occurred during the failed incursion of the treasure hunters.
 Devil’s Bargains are now Desperate Prayers, offered to the darkness without knowing what ancient entities of the forest may answer - or what the cost of drawing their attention might be.
 Hope and Despair are elements adapted from Quietus, with Despair replacing Ruin, and Hope offering a glimpse at something like redemption. 
 Reduction Rolls are called Haunts, which have a chance to lower your Despair. 
 Conditions are called Manifestations which result from increases to either Hope or Despair.
You may have noticed the looming growth of the Trophy RPG on Kickstarter. Candlelight joins the scene as another way to explore this fantastic game. 
Candlelight is a complete, stand alone game which includes rules for play, tips for running the game and a series of tables to quickly add character creation and story options to your game with little preparation.
Sample layout and test print
Sample layout and test print
Sample layout and test print
Candlelight will be printed in black and white at an estimated 32 pages. Successfully reached stretch goals will expand the page count. The zine will contain:
Rules for the game, a blank Character Sheet, tips for running the game including principles of play and safety tools.
Detailed instructions for adapting Trophy Dark incursions for Candlelight.  
Expanded tables for Dirges (Rituals), Drives of the spirit characters, options for your Doom (backgrounds), Memories (including extensive options related to relationships, identities and roles), Lures (story threads to draw the spirits out of the forest), Beliefs of the Afterlife and many more evocative elements to inspire your game. 
Design and layout featuring the atmospheric textures of B. Zentz. 
 Additional tables by guest authors (UNLOCKED!)
Gorgeous ink illustrations by Ezra Rose - with additional art (UNLOCKED!)
Streamlined options for adapting characters from D&D and other games.
An introductory scenario for playing the game.
art by Ezra Rose
Shipping - worldwide shipping is included in the cost of all physical pledges. As the printed zines will be under 3.5 oz shipping weight, they are considered letter-size for First-Class Mail International so this should be relatively straightforward.  
A game of Candlelight begins with a brief introductory story created during a conversation between players and GM, outlining the recent events which led to the death of the treasure hunters. Each player then begins character creation by naming their character and establishing how they died (their Doom). Answering a few more prompts, they will list a few significant skills or occupations they had when alive (Memories) and what they hope to resolve by escaping the forest (Drive). As the game progresses, players will attempt to enact powerful changes on their environment by unleashing Dirges. They will face Reckonings when they come across something from their dark past, increasing their Hope or Despair as a result. Eventually one of these states will reach a tipping point and signal the epilogue for that character.
Characters are built in much the same way as Trophy Dark. While many terms have been adapted for a game of desperate spirits instead of living treasure hunters, Candlelight encourages you to use your favorite Rituals, Occupations, Backgrounds and Drives from any Trophy Dark incursion.  
(Sample layout and character sheet)
FUNDED! $1200 - The Awakening. Additional tables for Candlelight, providing vivid details to include in your game and written by some fantastic guest authors:
 Omens and Portents by Sarah Rowan  
 Obstacles and Attachments by Madeleine Ember  
 Cursed Treasures by Nicholas Masyk 
FUNDED! $1700 - The Journey. More tables for Candlelight written by guest authors, full of evocative examples to inspire your game:
 Strange Denizens of the Forest by Linda Codega 
 Manifestations of Hope and Despair by Oli Jeffrey  
 Ancient Entities and their Demands by Jamila R. Nedjadi  
FUNDED! $2200- The Revelation. Additional Art! 
Candlelight will feature MORE fantastic ink illustrations by Ezra Rose.
FUNDED! $2700- The Reckoning. A new Exodus (Incursion) will be written specifically for Candlelight by Gabriel Robinson, designed as an introduction to the game.
FUNDED! $3200 - Song of the Forest - Character Resurrection Guide and Theme Song 
 Candlelight will include a guide for converting your character from D&D and other games, with tables written by Natalie Ash. This is intended as an easy entry point for groups playing a campaign, players new to role playing games, or anyone wanting to revisit a character from a past game (living or otherwise). 
 The game will also include a unique Candlelight theme song by Skye Zentz, sent to backers at all pledge levels as an MP3. That’s right - an RPG zine with its own song! Skye will write and record a haunting, atmospheric ballad narrating the journey of spirits through the haunted forest. The song will provide an introduction to the game and will be a great way to set the tone for play. 
FUNDED! $3700 - Share the Story - Increased Pay for All Contributors to Candlelight, plus Set of Compact Character Sheets 
At this level, all Candlelight contributors (art, layout and stretch goal writers) will receive an increase in pay (approximately 20%) - this project would not have got this far without their contributions!
Additionally, all physical reward tiers ($12 and above) will come with a printed set of 4 compact character sheets for your table. These will be printed separately from the zine itself, double-sided for easy distribution at the table. These sheets will be included in the PDF as well for easy printing and copying.
FUNDED! $4200 - additional character options by Madeleine Ember and professional editing for Candlelight!
$5000 - Solo Variant. Candlelight will include an option for solo play, using it's introspective themes to write your own tragic tale as you revisit the memories of a doomed character and find your way to some form of hopeful resolution.
 33 "Remembrance" Retweets - Pre-generated Characters. 
Upon reaching 33 retweets of the Candlelight project page, the game will include a series of sample characters for Candlelight, thematically grouped together in parties for quick play (and narratively connected backgrounds).
How to Participate: Retweet the project link for Candlelight and tell us about the death of one of your characters from any roleplaying game, using the following format:
"I was (name/title). I was known for (famous deed or memorable quirk). 
In the end, my doom was (manner of death). Who will remember me? #ToTheLost" bit.ly/candlelight-rpg" 
 (We are currently at 10/33 retweets with character remembrances!)
art by Ezra Rose
Read a preview of Candlelight by Clayton Notestine on The Explorer's Company here: https://www.theexplorersco.com/home/2020/candlelight/zinequest
Reviews:
"After a game of Trophy Dark where everyone dies, Candlelight is the perfect answer to the question: What now? And not only is the answer elegant and satisfying, it provides a surprising point of light in a world otherwise wrapped in darkness. Fans of ghost stories of all kinds will find much to love in Candlelight."
-Jesse Ross, Creator of the Trophy RPG
“We ended up publishing three of Gabriel’s Trophy Dark scenarios because they are really, really good. Gabriel is a terrific, evocative writer. There’s a lot of poetry in everything he writes, and I can’t wait to see Candlelight.” 
-Jason Cordova, Founder of The Gauntlet and publisher of the Trophy RPG.
"Candlelight is a ghost-story game, but told in a completely new direction: from the perspective of the ghosts and backwards in time. By focusing on the characters reckoning with events that have already happened, it enacts a story that goes beyond the story-focused questions of agency and narrative, and confronts what those actions mean in the context of a character’s identity and the often-overlooked contradictions identity holds.  In a fun and engaging way, Candlelight reminds us that death is not the end of story; there is the question of what that story meant that remains to be explored."
-Natalie Ash, Ember and Ash Games
"Such a thoughtful and emotionally evocative theme- by playing as ghosts, we get to be gently reminded of how very alive we are."
-Skye Z. (playtester) 
 Gabriel Robinson (writing and game design) carries memories of dark forests and tide pools from his childhood in the Pacific Northwest. He lives in Norfolk, VA with his wife and their small creatures, where he writes, works in healthcare and runs therapeutic role playing games. His incursions Gift of the Sea, The Forbidden Archives and Temple of the Sky are being published in the Trophy RPG, currently on Kickstarter.
 Ezra Rose (art) is an illustrator, zinester & mixed/multi-media creator living on a small farm in Western Massachusetts with queer chosen family. Their art explores monsters, magic, queer/trans identity and Jewish culture, celebrating the marginal and connecting to the symbols and stories of both past and present. Ezra's work has appeared in tabletop games, comics anthologies, and other small/indie press. | ezra-rose.com / @magpietongue |
B. Zentz (design and layout) became a fan of graphic design through album cover art, magazine layout, punk rock fanzines, action figure packaging, skateboard graphics, and rave & club flyers. He has worked as a freelance designer, copywriter, and in-house designer. Despite the state of digital world domination, he remains stubbornly committed to printed matter.
Stretch Goal Writers: 
 Sarah Rowan (@EchoingLaughter) is a game designer who likes writing tabletop games of all varieties, LGBT representation, buff sword women, and cryptic poetry. She has a degree in Game Design, a black belt in Tae Kwon Do, and an awesome wife who inspires her daily.
 Madeleine Ember (@MadeleineEmber) writes, illustrates, and generally makes a nuisance of herself at any opportunity. She lives with her partner and two cats in Camas, WA; where they together create many strange things.
 Linda Codega (@_linfinn) is a queer, nonbinary writer living by a mountain in the Hudson Valley. They are a speculative fiction author and narrative game designer. Their work has appeared in various anthologies, magazines, and blogs, and you can find a selection of their games on their itch page: http://lhcodega.itch.io.
 Nicholas Masyk (@nicholasmasyk) (he/him) is a roleplaying game designer and longtime GM from Montreal, Quebec, Canada, and creator of Monkey's Paw Games. His games seek to inject anti-colonial, anti-racist and anti-fascist narratives into the lens of science fiction, fantasy, and horror through projects such as numerous Trophy Dark Incursions as well as his own works such as UNCONQUERED, Chalice, and SMILE, which can be found at https://monkeys-paw-games.itch.io/. 
 Oli Jeffrey (@ojeffery) is a games designer and fan of all things macabre and maudlin. Yes, he was a teenage goth. He's best known for the RPG Quietus, and is a frequent contributor to Codex magazine. Look for his upcoming project Night Reign coming to Zinequest!
 Jamila R. Nedjadi  (@temporalhiccup) believes in the power of ghost stories, and in telling these stories together. They have written a few ghostly story games, as well as other games that focus on emotional connection and intuitive creativity. You can check out their games at https://temporalhiccup.itch.io/ or support them through https://www.patreon.com/swordqueengames 
 Natalie Ash is one-half of the creative team behind Ember+Ash, a small-press publisher of rpg content. When not serving her two feline overlords, she creates worlds that are broken, beautiful, and entirely terrible. She talks about RPGs and other nonsense at @theNatalieAsh.
 Skye Zentz (@skyezentz) is a professional songwriter and music educator who has served as composer and lyricist for the Emmy nominated WHRO environmental  series “Green Beats”. Skye teaches songwriting & ukulele at The Muse Writers Center in Norfolk Virginia, and loves iced coffee, a good cheese plate, and all friendly, fluffy creatures.
Candlelight, and my dive into writing for role playing games, has been extensively inspired by Trophy. Much gratitude to Jesse Ross for creating such an elegant and evocative game and encouraging others to contribute their ideas and create hacks of their own.
 This project also would not have been launched without the support of Jason Cordova and The Gauntlet. Codex magazine has been an inspiration for creating the kind of games I'm passionate about sharing with others and I am very excited for Candlelight. Thank you for supporting my work and the many other Trophy-related projects underway.
Thanks also to the many fantastic writers in the Trophy and indie RPG community for your inspired writing, thoughtful feedback and encouragement! I look forward to our future collaborations.
Thanks to Skye for such grounded support and for being a guiding light during the times I have found myself walking a more winding path than necessary.

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone! I hope you're all safe and well in the new year. While it continues to be a trying time for all of us, to say the least, I hope you've been able to play some games with friends online and continue to find things that bring you joy.
On that note, I'm excited to share that my next project, TOKEN, is coming to Zinequest on February 9th! 
TOKEN is a GM-less duet game Rooted in Trophy and inspired by dark fairytales and tragic ballads. It tells the story of a failed hero entering a haunted place and the transformed monster who dwells there, each seeking each other for reasons that change as the story unfolds. Both characters offer each other tokens symbolizing their intentions, and as they discover the bonds they share in common, their drive changes. The game ends when they meet at last, and both characters narrate the epilogue. Like Candlelight, TOKEN will be a deeply atmospheric and collaborative game which tells beautiful and tragic stories. I've got a fantastic team working on this project and think you're really going to love it.

Hi everyone, A quick update here to mention that print zines have begun to arrive at their destinations—its been wonderful to see your posts of physical copies. If you have a moment to share pictures of yours, review the game on Itch.io or talk about how your session of Candlelight went, I'd love to know. Thanks again for your patience with shipping, and please message me if you have any issues with your rewards!
Secondly, as a member of Cold Hearth Collective (https://www.coldhearthcollective.com/our-mission), I'm very excited to announce Alchemy (https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/coldhearthcollective/alchemy-1?ref=clipboard-prelaunch), a hardbound collection of alchemically-themed incursions for Trophy Dark, launching 9/22/2020 on Kickstarter! Alchemy will feature original Trophy Dark incursions written by a team of super talented writers including: Amalie Mckee (https://twitter.com/MaenadMags), Madeleine Ember (https://twitter.com/MadeleineEmber), Michael Van Vleet (https://twitter.com/signalstation), Natalie Ash (https://twitter.com/theNatalieAsh), Pam Punzalan (https://twitter.com/TheDovetailor), Nicholas Masyk (https://twitter.com/nicholasmasyk), Speak the Sky ( https://twitter.com/SpeaktheSky), Jamila Nedjadi (https://twitter.com/temporalhiccup) and yours truly.

campaign.story:
Let's start with this: Kickstarter employees have been working for months to get their union recognized, and faced a lot of pushback from senior Kickstarter leadership. Recently they were able to hold a vote to decide on the formation of this union, and while we will not know the results of that vote for some time, I still stand in support of those workers and recognizing KSRU. 
In compliance with the discussions they've been having with senior leadership their social media has gone dark, but you can still find out more at their website.
Hi! I'm Kales! I write games under the name A. Fell, and I publish them as Paradoxical Press! This game is built on the back of a story I have been telling, over and over again, with two dear friends of mine over the last two years. It's truly the result of a labor of love, and I'm so excited to turn it into something real and tangible you can hold in your hands and share with your friends, much like the tokens in the game proper.
Memoria is a game telling sprawling character histories over long periods of time. Inspired by such games as Microscope by Ben Robbins and Mobile Frame Zero: Firebrands by D. Vincent Baker, it tells the kinds of stories I like to tell best-- jumping around through time, dealing with the ever evolving relationships between characters and only as much politics as you want to exist, with a very freeform structure to scenes themselves. It is a game that explicitly and deliberately refuses to engage with major character death as a source of angst within the story itself. Yes, the game can take place over centuries; no, you don't have to explain how if you don't want to. The point is the characters.
The intro to gameplay, featuring one of the art pieces done by Serj.
The game uses small remnants of memory at its foundation-- tokens and echoes. Tokens are tangible-- gifts, letters, random knick-knacks, even scars and tattoos. Echoes are less tangible, more sense memory than anything else, but they carry the same weight. You call tokens and echoes in scenes shared with other characters as well as solitary moments you narrate alone. You can move in and out of scenes as your  characters or as the rest of the world, building an epic history of friends to enemies back to friends to lovers-- just as an example-- as the world shifts and pivots around you.
Currently, you can find Memoria on Itch as a digital-only download; however for the purposes of Zinequest I'll be offering the PDF only at half its usual price and producing a 5.5x8.5 (roughly A5 size) zine so you, too, can hold this game in your hands! They'll be printed and bound by me (time to flex the bookbinding skills I learned working in the library in college) and should hopefully be shipped by June, if not earlier.
The zine features beautifully done art by Lu which will span the entire front and back cover, inset pieces by Serj, and a gorgeous piece of art by Sam (which you can see a snippet of in the header for this project.) 
At the $15 tier, you can get the zine as well as a PDF of the game, which will have the new cover art and some interior layout tweaks. (If you already own the PDF, never fear-- the updated PDF will become available on the Itch page when the updated PDF goes out to backers, and you can always get the physical version only for $12.)
For $20, you can donate a physical copy to someone who might not be able to afford it. (Those will be available on a first-come first-serve basis, and will cost nothing on your end.) For every additional $10 over the base tier you pledge I'll add another physical copy to the pool (so a $40 pledge will donate three copies).
If you're international and outside one of the countries listed, message me! I will work something out with you as much as I can.
The budget may look a little small, but that's because I laid out the game myself and made some art happen already. Here is a breakdown of where the money is going:
 $100 for the new cover art, done by the lovely Lu, and other small pieces of art, including the header image which was done by Sam! 
 $50 for the art in the game already, done by Sam and Serj, as royalties for the work they did to help make this book beautiful.
 $150 for the printing, binding, and shipping, which I will be doing all myself (not using a third-party printer or fulfillment service).
 $50 compensation for myself.
 $50 for Kickstarter fees.
and $50 as a buffer.
We're fully funded! That's incredible! Let's talk about stretch goals!
You might be saying to yourself: Memoria exists as a game already! What more could we want! If you were following me during the several months or so I was writing this  game, you'll remember I was talking about a supplemental, featuring scene frameworks and potential dynamic seeds to serve as a jumping off point for players. One of those scene frameworks made it to Itch (a dance, a duel, which you can download right now for PWYW.) 
I've always been planning on writing it, but it would be really, really neat to be able to print it as well. If we can reach $800 I'll release the supplemental, containing Firebrands-style scene frameworks, character dynamic seeds, and an additional variant (or perhaps two) as a PDF bonus to all backers. That money will go towards paying for the writing and layout of the supplemental, which I estimate will be at least another eight to ten pages of content.
But you all are here for physical zines. So here's my promise. If we can reach $1000, I'll be able to print and bind the supplemental for all physical backers. It's a bit of a hefty goal, but it'll cover the costs of printing and shipping the additional weight.
If the project funds but a stretch goal is not reached, any extra funds will go towards the following things:
Paying my artists more for the work they've done.
My day-to-day work for bringing the game to you in its best state possible.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The game is already fully written, apart from the supplemental, so the real risk here is with fulfillment being done on time. For the sake of transparency, I have projected fulfillment to be complete by June since I am planning to move states in April, and that will suck up a lot of the time I could be spending binding zines. I know myself well and I know I will want to get a head start on fulfillment sooner, but I have given myself wiggle room in case of unforeseen circumstances.

campaign.story:
Drown Your Heroes.
The stories we tell are often not of gallant survivors but of the hard-pressed, star-crossed crestfallen. They are the poetry of the broken and the inhuman breakers: haunting things, deep and dark and bellowing things, unfathomable things that consume all that edges to their precipice.
Sunken is a tabletop roleplaying game about these things.
It is a tabletop roleplaying game about these things and the sea.
It is a tabletop roleplaying game about how your characters find their doom among these things while at sea.
Sunken shifts the focus of the world of Trophy onto – and below – the vast and treacherous Salt Sea, expanding "That Silent Howl" from Codex: Void into a full stand alone system that remains rooted in the mechanics of Trophy Dark.
What's It Like?
Return of the Obra Dinn, The Terror, Alien, Bioshock, Sunless Sea, Rime of the Ancient Mariner ... Sunken frames naval and sci-fi horror in a world of dark fantasy. 
How Does It Play?
As a Rooted in Trophy game, Sunken heels toward evocative storytelling over a simple framework – perfect for dramatic one-shot sessions. The original Trophy ruleset has been modified to put emphasis on the themes of dreadful ocean expeditions while keeping the overall structure lean and straightforward.
Character creation is a simple spin of the cypher: Choose your background, your job, your faction, and – if you choose to believe in that kind of thing – a patron saint.
Sunken's magic comes in the form of answered prayers to eerie saints
You might be the estranged heir of a great family, turned marine under the black-skull flag, hoping to regain the worth of your heredity. Or maybe you're secretly a Company automaton, stationed as a surgeon with that crew of vagabonds, ensuring through subterfuge that valuable secrets stay within corporate hulls.
Each voyage is divided into five tides, a series of distinct acts that uniquely raise the stakes and tension of your adventure. As you take risks to weather these tidal terrors, you'll roll dice to determine outcomes. Accumulate dice across three pools:
 The Flesh – For each skill you're able to utilize from your background and occupation, roll a die from this pool.
 The Deep – Decide how much the power of the sea drives your action, but with each die you take, increase the chances that you lose some sanity. As your mind succumbs to the depths, find yourself steered more and more by the call of the sea.
 The Heavens – An icon of hope amidst the torrent. Your fellow players can offer you divine intervention: extra effect applied to a success. If the Heavens rolls low, lose some faith in a higher power and hasten your descent into the deep.
Sunken's design heightens the feeling of navigating a capsizing character, encouraging you to pull power from the void while sliding you down an accelerating slope to your doom. 
What's Included?
Whether digital, print, or both, you get:
 Rules – A standalone nautical hack of Trophy.
 Voyages – Three in total. Inky beasts, bred with dark magic. A utopia built within the carcass of a leviathan. A fateful run-in with a cursed hive mind. 
 Shanties – Splinters of the history and lore of the Salt Sea, useful bits to fill your own voyages with.
The zine itself is:
A 8.5" x 5.5" staple-bound zine in classic zine glory, for print backers.
Gorgeous, with cover art by Gianna Meola, endpapers by Jenny Neale, and historical etchings for good measure.
Accompanied by a second mini-zine called The Drowning Scriptures – one of the campaign's stretch goals.
Sunken's layout blends historical and modern design – evoking the setting while providing clear information design. Chapters will be divided by original patterns. Note: This is mockup and not a final spread.
Which Three Voyages?
 A Covenant of Silence – A prequel/sequel/reboot of "That Silent Howl", where your crew finds itself infested with the East Passage Company's most profitable – and predatory – cargo. Find the nearest friendly face and hug them dearly.
 This Colossus Beneath – A hard-fought tip leads to the rumored dwelling of the Company's missing founder: a submerged utopia architected within the corpse of a leviathan. The timely shock of a breaching insurrection may provide opportunity to poach this belly of the beast.
 Futility's Wreck – Slogging through the icing shawl of the south, the crew of Futility find themselves not half a league from a hulking barge inhabited by cultists adorned in death's mark. This cursed band think and breathe as one, and they collect proselytes unfettered by the hardening sea.
Are There Stretch Goals?
Oh, heavens yes. 
And they've been hit by the generous backers that have come before you.
Richard Ruane (Barrow Keep) and Natalie Ash (Richter: The Rotting City) will be adding their haunting storytelling to the zine's Shanties & Lore section, adding characters, settings, and terrors in the form of found fragments.
A second mini-zine will be included with all reward levels, with a Kickstarter-exclusive print run being delivered to print backers. The Drowning Scriptures explores the eerie gothic faith of Sunken's seafarers, and includes:
More lore fragments, backgrounds, and apocryphal saints
A voyage by Madeleine Ember (Richter: The Rotting City) ... a pilgrimage following the miracles and martyrdom of a major saint
Additional artwork by cover artist Gianna Meola 
Whatever else we can pack in with the final run of backing funds
Who Is Involved?
Our core contributors represent all of America's coasts: the Great Lakes, the Gulf, the Atlantic, and Pacific.
Mike Martens – Designer, writer, creator. I'm a brand and UX copywriter transplanted to Los Angeles, applying the skills of my trade to my love for games and genre fiction.
Gianna Meola – Cover artist. Gianna is an illustrator and cartoonist, currently living and working in Brooklyn, NY. When she's not drawing she likes to volunteer with animals.
Jenny Neale – Pattern artist. Jenny is an artist and illustrator based in The Sunshine State. Shes enjoys yoga, good food and adventures in nature.
Etchings in the public domain, including work by Gustave Doré and John Flamsteed. Ocean recording in preview video by Mike Koenig (CC BY 3.0 US).
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Frankly: This is my first Kickstarter, so there are certainly question marks.

That said, my decade+ background as a professional creative gives me a firm understanding of production processes and the surprises that arise in them. I have experience and support sources across the project workflow. And I've built the scale of this Kickstarter to minimize critical points of failure. 

Sunken's ruleset is complete with refinements already in testing, sped up by its reliance on the extensively tested and played Trophy system.

campaign.story:
I want to start by bringing attention to Kickstarter United, a collective of Kickstarter workers who have come together to create a union in their workplace. A vote was recently held to determine whether or not they will be successful, and during this process they are staying off social media, but I would urge you to stay informed by checking out their website and to be prepared to take action if they call for it in the future. 
This zine is made up of three different games. They're all based off the same single-player system, which uses a deck of cards and a six-sided die to generate prompts for the player to expand on. 
cover art from Alone Among the Stars
Alone Among the Stars is a solo adventuring game about exploring strange and fantastic planets and experiencing wondrous sights. I wrote it in the summer of 2018 while I was playing a lot of No Man's Sky really late at night. If you'd like to check it out before backing the zine, it's available for PWYW on my Itch.io page here. 
page 1 of my example playthrough of Alone Among the Stars
cover art from Alone in the Ancient City
Alone in the Ancient City was the first hack of AAtS that I wrote. It's about wandering through an old city with new eyes, and was inspired by trips to cities such as Venice and Montreal. If you'd like to check it out before backing this zine you can find the plaintext version on my Itch.io page here. 
Alone Among the Twisting Trees is a new game I'm writing for inclusion in this zine! It's about getting lost in a mysterious forest and the strange artifacts that you find inside. It was originally conceived through playstorming with Quinn Vega and Avi Margolis as an adaptation of another game I wrote, Alone on the Rocky Beach (not included in this zine).
In addition to these games, there are a ton of other hacks that have been inspired by Alone Among the Stars. If this zine doesn't stick out to you but you're still looking for a cool single-player experience, I'd recommend checking out the rest of these hacks! I've tried to compile all of them in this Itch collection, Alone at the Table. 
I think anyone can make a game, and hacking is a great way to get started. A number of the hacks in the Alone at the Table collection were made by first-time designers, and in order to make hacking the game even easier I'm including a template that you can fill in to make your own hack in the back of the zine, as well as a page or two of useful design tips to get you started. You could even use the journaling pages to start playtesting!
"In Alone in the Ancient City, designer Takuma Okada translates the melancholy, No Man’s Sky-esque galaxy-wide wandering of Alone Among the Stars into a more humble joy, one of discovering a city on your own. Ancient City captures the feeling of traveling through a place with a history and weight belonging to others, but wholly unfamiliar to you. Okada eschews the oft-trod territory of metropolitan tourism and spectacle in the pursuit of a more intimate exploration. This game is Urban Pastel at its finest." - Caro Asercion, designer of i'm sorry did you say street magic 
"Are you playing Alone Among the Stars? And following the Twitter account? Get on it. @among_stars_" - John Harper, designer of Blades in the Dark
Alone On A Journey: a collection of solo adventuring games is a 28 page zine featuring this amazing cover art by Shannon Kao. It will include these three Alone games in a new layout by Quinn, a blank template of an Alone game with some pointers so you can make your own hack, and blank journaling pages in the back of the book so you can start writing right away. 
the cover for the zine!
 The zine is 5.5"x8.5" and will be printed through Mixam. The cover will be color on 110 lb. paper with a matte finish, and the inside pages will be black and white on 80 lb paper. 
In the spirit of Zinequest, I've tried to keep the budget low while paying collaborators fairly. The total comes out to $500 given a 50 print run. 
$225 for printing, shipping, and fulfillment: This should cover a 50 zine print run and shipping related costs for a mix of US and International orders. 
$75 for the cover art by Shannon: The art is already paid for and completed, but this covers the amount that I paid out of pocket for it already.
$150 for layout by Quinn: This is a tentative layout budget for about 20 pages, some blank journaling pages, and a cover.
$50 for fees: This is to cover Kickstarter fees!
As you may have noticed, I haven't really budgeted for paying myself. This is partially because I've already made some money off these games selling them on Itch.io, but it's also because I really want this project to fund and put it out in the world. If it funds over the goal, the first thing I'll be doing is paying myself and upping the print run to 100 copies. Beyond that I've been throwing around some ideas for stretch goals but haven't settled on anything yet, and I don't really want to assume a huge overshoot given the nature of Zinequest. If it looks like we will though, I may announce some extra goals on this page. 
Hi! My name's Takuma Okada, and I'm a Japanese American writer, musician, and game designer. I started making games almost two years ago now, and I'm really excited to finally have the chance to make one of my first games into a physical zine! Some of my other games include Stewpot: Tales From a Fantasy Tavern, Chess: Two Kingdoms, and Etude of the Evening. I love beautiful places and strange objects and try to make them easy to find in my games.
Quinn Vega is a queer game designer, graphic designer, and musician based out of Portland, OR. Her games include For The Honor, Lightning Kissed, and cowriting Songs for the Dusk with Kavita Poduri. When she is not making or playing games she works making microphones and leading her band, The Variants. You can find her on twitter @Mx_quinn and her work at mxquinn.itch.io.
Shannon Kao is an artist from Seattle who works in comics and illustration. She's interested in stories about how places—real & imagined—shape the people in them. You can find more of her work on her website!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I want to lead this off by saying that I've never run a Kickstarter before. However, I've been a stretch goal contributor for several now and have experience meeting those kinds of deadlines. Two of the games are finished, the third is a hack of one I've already written and should come together shortly, the art is finished, and overall most of the game is done except for layout. I've received a lot of advice from people with experience running Kickstarters before and am talking to a lot of other designers doing Zinequest this year and I'm pretty confident in our ability to get this zine into your hands successfully!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
WHAT IS THIS PROJECT?
We've finished writing brand-spankin' new songs for our next album, and we are super excited about it.  We think it's our strongest work yet.  All of our previous recordings were done on shoe-string budgets, and we had to cut corners because of it.  Not this time. We are raising money to do this right.
WHAT IS THE MONEY FOR?
Firstly, we are only asking for $1,800, to play it safe, because we really want to achieve our goal. That said, we hope to surpass it.  Realistically, this album will cost us about $3,000.  Here's why:
>Recording & Studio Time:  Recording at Type Foundry Studios costs $250/day, but it's worth it. We'll be there for 4 days.
>Mixing & Engineering:  We will be working with Robby Moncrieff, who co-produced the Dirty Projectors albums(!).  He's a fantastic audio engineer, and is cutting us a deal, but he'll still need $1,500 plus.
>Mastering:  This costs about $500 for a full record, and is essential for producing a good-sounding album.
YEAH, BUT WHAT DO I GET OUTA' IT?
Well, aside from our appreciation, and the gratification of having helped us out, we are offering a bunch of cool rewards for your contributions.  Look, they're just over there, to the right.  Think of it as giving us an early Christmas present...
THANKS SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT. IT MEANS A LOT. REALLY.
XO - BRAINSTORM

campaign.story:
In September and October of 2011 I will be making my first ever voyage to Indonesia, at the invitation of YES NO WAVE MUSIC and curators involved with the Yogyakarta Museum of Contemporary Art. I will have several weeks’ residency in Yogyakarta where I will be teaching throat-singing workshops and creating murals while also rehearsing with local musicians to create an entirely new version of MALAIKAT DAN SINGA with an all-Indonesian band. In Jakarta we will have use of a recording studio where we will collaboratively compose and record new work. I have also been invited to prepare a book of whatever paintings are produced during my residency for publication in a limited edition artist monograph. The final weeks of my voyage will include a tour with the newly formed band, performing concerts in Jakarta, Malang, Bandung, Solo and Denpasar; some of these concerts will be documented by film maker Vincent Moon, famous for his work with A TAKE AWAY SHOW and LA BLOGOTEQUE/petits planetes.
I am seeking the support of friends, relatives, and fans of my music and artwork to help me cover travel expenses first and foremost. If I am able to raise funds beyond my initial goal of $2000, I would like to set aside some funds for the purchase of musical instruments from experimental musical instrument inventor and builder Wukir, based in Yogyakarta.
I intend to forge collaborative bonds with kindred spirits within Indonesia's experimental arts and performance scene through active engagement with other musicians, artists, and audiences. Through painting, creation of public murals, recording sessions and concerts, I also intend to create new work that transcends commonly defined boundaries of what constitutes low/high culture, East/West, spiritual/profane.
Saya ingin benar-benar baik dalam berbicara bahasa Indonesia, juga!

Hello Friends- 
You may not even remember this, but over a year ago you helped finance my trip in September 2011 to Indonesia. Thanks! I spent about six weeks working on art and playing music with a wide variety of Indonesian musicians in several different cultural traditions (and many working in avant-garde/experimental contexts as well!). 
I also worked with the incredible filmaker VINCENT MOON on a collaborative video piece documenting some of my adventures, and just today Vincent has released the final edit to public viewing! Please take about fifteen minutes to watch MERAPI GAYA, it takes us from the center of Yogyakarta to a small village on the volcano MOUNT MERAPI=

Just in case you totally can't wait, with slobbering, dripping anticipation- I just scanned in a few pages from the book "Songs of Psychic Fire" which is offered up as a reward to ALL backers donating $30 and ABOVE. They are all erotically-themed line drawings I did in a notebook while on tour in Belgium, France, and Italy last March. The booklets are photocopied and then hand-sewn with red thread and the front covers and several pages inside are then handpainted in eye popping metallic acrylic and gouache colors. 
http://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10150248913201432.323660.565856431&l=40901f7459&type=1

Thank you everyone! I'm kind of overwhelmed by all the enthusiasm and good vibes that this project is generating out there in the world. I'm really grateful to all of you and feeling really inspired, especially after this weekend at What the Heck Fest. A lot of people who had never even heard of Malaikat dan Singa were able to witness a performance on Sunday night that I am particularly proud of- I thought the band was in stellar form! There's a new video online, and I am also trying to edit my youtube channel so that some of the better videos will have ENGLISH SUBTITLES for the lyrics sung in Indonesian...

campaign.story:
What is TreeStory?
TreeStory is an innovative film with an ambitious plan to reconnect people to nature. Using a timeless form of activism: story-telling, it will explore the dramatic changes that can happen to people thanks to an experience with one important tree in their life.
Inspired by the felling of her favorite childhood tree, an African woman single-handedly creates a project to plant a billion trees worldwide.
A heroin addict overcomes a lifetime addiction and tells us it is because of a tree.
Humans need trees - whether we realize it or not, and TreeStory aims to fundamentally alter how we relate to them. Moving beyond seeing trees as resources, TreeStory will pose the question, what is a tree and what does it have to do with me? TreeStory is a film of heroic stories from around the world that will inspire activism by making it personal.
A famous cellist discovers the mahogany used to build his instrument is now endangered and sets out to do something about it.
A scientist receives a dowry gift of a tree. Inspired by it, he creates a reserve in Indonesia that is the last remaining home for Orangutans.
Why is such a film so critically needed now? For every second you’ve been reading these words, the earth has lost an area of forest the size of two football fields - tribal people all over the world are losing their land. If we keep on, the lungs of the planet will die and so will all of us who depend on them.
The problem can seem overwhelming. What can turn this tide? A change in consciousness is needed. In the face of overwhelming environmental problems, TreeStory will give people hope and inspire activism as only good stories can.
TreeStory explores the relationship between humans and trees from every conceivable angle: the scientific, the mythical, the practical, the cultural and the spiritual. Powered by powerful, personal stories, inspired by our oldest companions, TreeStory will change the way you see trees, and yourself, for good.
Everyone has a TreeStory
We have heard the stories of individuals fighting corporate greed; we have seen heroes standing up to protect their environment. What we are yet to experience is a film that directly connects the person on the screen with the person in the theatre. A film that shows how trees are as essential to the tribe in the rainforest fighting for its survival as they are to a person walking the sidewalks of New York.
What can happen when we tell a story about a special tree in our life? We've been asking people to do that. We've asked farmers and bankers, inner-city kids and people dying in hospitals, scientists, mythologists, priests, and loggers. And we are finding that by connecting people personally to one tree in their life a door opens for them to connect with and protect the forests around them.
TreeStory will collaborate with our audience to tell its stories. We will feature tree stories submitted on our Website. In addition our tree heroes include:
Alan Featherstone Watson – The activist who planted a million trees after accidently ring barking a spruce to death in his youth. We tell the story of ‘Trees for Life’ – Alan’s 250-year vision to reforest the highlands of Scotland.
Dr. Nalini Nadkarni, eminent tree biologist, who was married in the crown of a Fig tree, takes us into Cedar Creek prison in Washington where she’s training prisoners to become tree arborists.
Michael Meade, mythologist will take us to the original garden of Eden to tell us a revitalized story of the Tree of Knowledge and the Tree of Life.
Plus many more…
An experienced team
My last feature, The Heart of the Game, about a girl’s basketball team was a surprise hit, distributed by Miramax and praised by Ebert and Roeper as “an Oscar level piece of work.” I have produced 90 other short films for causes from the environment to women’s issues to the arts. But I have long felt that the most important stories today are environmental ones. That is why I have dedicated myself to TreeStory, a film I think can awaken a lot of people to our interdependence with nature. I have built a team that includes Larry Estes, the “quiet godfather of independent film,” producer Vicki Dunakin whose latest film Underground Rome was aired by National Geographic, singer-songwriter Pete Droge and Andy Shilabear the award winning cinematographer of the Planet Earth series.
The trees are calling for help
Now we (and the trees!) need your support. Thanks to the money from this Kickstarter campaign will be able to complete the critical research and development phase of our project in advance of shooting this year.
Let's change the way we see trees, and ourselves, for good. The trees need us now. For detailed information on the film, please visit our website www.treestorymovie.com

UPDATE #4:
Help us get to $40,000! We have four days to go and we want to get to $40k. We are using our fourth update to promote this new goal. In honor of the number four, we're adding a prize at $400 - a limited-edition Safecast t-shirt.
UPDATE #3:
Thank you, everyone, for helping us reach our goal! Any additional funds raised will help us purchase more Geiger counters to send to Japan.
We also wanted to clarify for our top donors. Anyone donating $1,000 will receive a Geiger counter. In addition to that, the Top 10 donors will also receive an iGeigie. So that would be two devices for the top 10.
UPDATE #2:
Our thank you cards will come in the shape of Field Notes books. See more here: 
Field Notes book as a Thank You card
UPDATE:
We've rebranded RDTN as Safecast. Here's an in-depth explanation behind the name change:
http://blog.rdtn.org/2011/04/24/rdtn-is-now-safecast/
And for some information about how the funding will be applied, see this post:
http://blog.safecast.org/2011/04/24/first-safecast/
About:
Safecast.org (formerly RDTN.org) is a website whose purpose is to provide an aggregate feed of nuclear radiation data from governmental, non-governmental and citizen-scientist sources. That data will be made available to everyone, including scientists and nuclear experts who can provide context for lay people. In the weeks following launch, it has become evident that there is a need for additional radiation reporting from the ground in Japan. This Kickstarter project will help us purchase up to 600 Geiger Counter devices that will be deployed to Japan. (The project minimum will fund about 100 devices). The data captured from these devices will feed into our website and will also be made available for others to use via Pachube, an open-source platform for monitoring sensor data globally. Our field members will be trained by ouradvisors to properly use these devices. The field members will be required to report to the website 8-10 times per day.
Open-Source Underpinnings:
We will make the raw data available from our network for anyone to use under Creative Commons 0 dedication. It is our goal that providing this data to non-profit organizations, governments and scientists will keep people and societies more informed in the current crisis as well as future incidents where data might otherwise be scarce. 
Phase 1 and Phase 2:
We want to eventually build our own network of devices. We recognize, however, that there’s an immediate need to get devices on the ground now. So our project has two phases. Phase 1 is about getting devices out to the areas with the least amount of data. Phase 2 will focus on  building a larger network of devices that will help governments, citizens and organizations understand immediate and long-term implications of radiation levels.
Where will they be deployed?
In looking at a map of radiation detection in Japan, there are many holes where no data is being captured whatsoever. Some of those are very close to Fukushima while others are well outside of Tokyo. The initial set of devices will be utilized in areas where coverage is sparse. We will deliver these devices to people on the ground who have been trained in how to use them. It could be a teacher, a university student, or a citizen scientist looking to contribute to the project.
Who will be using these devices?
We want to provide the device to someone who has an above-average understanding of technology, but not necessarily an expert. This should be someone who knows how to install an app on their iPhone or Android device, and is familiar with filling out forms on websites. No programming skills or engineering degree is required. Knowing how to set up a wifi-router is a plus.
Device List: (UPDATED)
We are currently working with a distributor of detection devices in order to get them at a discounted cost. Due to the ease of use of the CRM-100, we have decided to focus on this unit for our volunteers in Japan.
CRM-100
The CRM-100 is a general purpose geiger counter that measures alpha, beta, gamma, and x-radiation. It is intended for personal safety and educational purposes, not for professional applications. Like the popular Radalert 100, the CRM-100 features a 3-second update on its digital liquid crystal display (LCD). The LCD shows the current radiation level in your choice of milliroentgens per hour from .001 to 110 or counts per minute (cpm) from 0 to 350,000. When SI units are selected, the LCD shows readings in microsieverts per hour from .01 to 1100 or counts per second (cps) from 0 to 3,500. This instrument also offers an accumulated total and timer function, up to 9,999,000 counts and 40 hours. A red LED blinks and a beeper chirps with each count (the chirp can be muted).

Excerpt from The Feasts of Tre-mang:
Celebrated on the summer solstice, the New Year’s festivities on Tre-mang were colorful, loud, and delicious. At sundown Tre-manners carried lanterns into the streets and ceremoniously burned kitchen chairs. Decorated with bright paper and, occasionally, firecrackers, these chairs were symbolically burdened with the unwanted things of the previous year. After watching the chairs go up in flames, Tre-manners enjoyed a raucous street party over the cinders of things past. Beer and auspicious foods were passed around freely in the crowd. In the deep of the night, the more adventurous men vented a year’s-worth of steam by gathering in nearby woods to have “blind-fights.” These skirmishes in the dark often resulted in injury but never in hard feelings as the participants were careful not to disclose their identities. The next afternoon (the morning being spent coping with hangovers and black-eyes), each Tre-manner household bought or built a brand new chair and, ritually planting their buttocks into it, hoped for comfort and ease in the coming year.
New Year Recipes: Beer-Battered Eggplant Stuffed with Sun-Dried Tomato Pâté Mushroom Duck Tarts Spiced Pomegranate Cider

updates.update_content:
At last our journey to Tre-mang is complete. It took longer than any of us expected but I hope it has been a fulfilling adventure.
If you were expecting a book and haven't received one please let me know. 
Many of you have asked me about giving The Feasts of Tre-mang as a holiday gift. Don't give away your autographed copy! I'm happy to inform you that the book is now available for purchase. Ask your favorite local bookstore to order it. Or buy it online. (Links below.)

Your patience has paid off!
The last of the books has been sent and you should receive yours soon.
Thank you again for making The Feasts of Tre-mang a reality.

Your generosity is matched only by your patience. You will recall from the previous update that we’re all waiting on the final manifestation of The Feasts of Tre-mang. Those who are owed books will receive them. You remembered Tre-mang and she has not forgotten you.
In the meantime, though, I haven’t stopped working on it. In addition to completing a second draft, we now have all of the food photography finished. The samples you see here are courtesy of the talented Morgan Bellinger.

Thank you for your patience.
 Most of you have received your thank you gifts—but those of you who are due a digital or physical copy of the book are still waiting and for this I offer a humble apology.
 A few of you have asked about the progress of The Feasts of Tre-mang. I have good news and something of a bummer to report.
I’ve been working hard in the last two months polishing prose, salting soups, and examining artifacts--a first draft of the cookbook is near!

Many of you have already received your thank you gifts. To those of you waiting for the book itself, I thank you for your patience.
Work on the manuscript is proceeding at a frenzied pace and has uncovered new holidays like Tuttilang, the Tre-manner puppet festival, and new recipes like Perferlum Jad-zum, duck-mushroom tarts.
In the meantime please enjoy an interview of yours truly by the Kickstarter team:

updates.update_content:
If you’re a donor you recently received an en email with the title “Info Needed!” including a link to a survey form.
I need that information to deliver your thank-you gift—please fill it out! It’ll take you two minutes tops.
Where do we go from here? I’ll be working hard through the summer to complete The Feasts of Tre-mang, and I’ll post updates on Tre-mang.com as well as in a newsletter. If you don’t hear from me for awhile, it’s because I’m sweating over a hot stove or wracking my brain for the perfect words to describe a Tre-manner wedding ceremony.
